{"uri": "8259119682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:36:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:36:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:35:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.ludlowadvertiser.co.uk/news/national/24496915.pm-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-mosques-offered-emergency-support/", "title": "PM tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes after ugly scenes of anti-immigration rioters attacking police and smashing the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on Sunday as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person was already arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nStaffordshire Police warned people to stay away from the Holiday Inn, Tamworth, which was hit with \"violent acts of thuggery\" and one officer was injured.\n\nA spokesman said: \"A large group of individuals are in the area and have been throwing projectiles, smashing windows, starting fires and targeting police.\"\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, 17, is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nIt comes after far-right agitator Tommy Robinson was accused of stoking tensions from afar after he promoted a \"pro-UK\" rally and appeared to defend the unrest on social media while on holiday abroad.\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and insisted that despite plans to release some offenders from prison early, there is capacity to hand custodial sentences to violent rioters.\n\nBut the Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chairman of the federation Brian Booth told the PA news agency: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nConservative leader Rishi Sunak said the scenes had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and warned that \"violent, criminal behaviour has no place in our society\".\n\nStephen Parkinson, Director of Public Prosecutions, said extra lawyers had been drafted in over the weekend and would continue to work round the clock to ensure justice is served.\n\nHe has directed prosecutors to make immediate charging decisions where key evidence is in place \"and they are doing so\", he said.\n\n\"I am determined that we will act swiftly and robustly, giving the courts maximum ability to pass sentences that reflect what has occurred.\"", "source": {"uri": "ludlowadvertiser.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ludlow "https://www.ludlowadvertiser.co.uk/resources/images/18384663/", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9789876", "eventUri": "eng-9789876", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-08-444217522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:49:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:49:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/pm-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-as-mosques-offered-emergency-support-1658054.html", "title": "Starmer tells UK rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "UK prime minister Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence across England as the UK government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, Mr Starmer condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, he suggested rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the UK Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nMr Starmer indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes after ugly scenes of anti-immigration rioters attacking police and smashing the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on Sunday as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person was already arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nAnother Holiday Inn in Tamworth was later targeted, with Staffordshire Police warning people to stay away from the unrest after one officer was injured.\n\nSpecialist drone surveillance and the national police air service have been sweeping the area as part of efforts to identify those involved, a spokesperson said.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nUK home secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and police have government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, a 17-year-old from Lancashire, is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation, we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nMr Starmer said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, he said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nIt comes after far-right agitator Tommy Robinson was accused of stoking tensions from afar after he promoted a \"pro-UK\" rally and appeared to defend the unrest on social media while on holiday abroad.\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Mr Starmer's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Priti Patel saying the UK parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and insisted that despite plans to release some offenders from prison early, there is capacity to hand custodial sentences to violent rioters.\n\nBut the Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chair of the federation Brian Booth said: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nConservative leader Rishi Sunak said the scenes had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and warned that \"violent, criminal behaviour has no place in our society\".\n\nStephen Parkinson, Director of Public Prosecutions, said extra lawyers had been drafted in over the weekend and would continue to work round the clock to ensure justice is served.\n\nHe has directed prosecutors to make immediate charging decisions where key evidence is in place \"and they are doing so\", he said.\n\n\"I am determined that we will act swiftly and robustly, giving the courts maximum ability to pass sentences that reflect what has occurred.\"", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking {"uri": "8259150912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:22:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:22:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:19:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/national/24496930.pm-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-mosques-offered-emergency-support/", "title": "PM tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes after ugly scenes of anti-immigration rioters attacking police and smashing the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on Sunday as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person was already arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nAnother Holiday Inn in Tamworth was later targeted, with Staffordshire Police warning people to stay away from the unrest after one officer was injured.\n\nSpecialist drone surveillance and the national police air service have been sweeping the area as part of efforts to identify those involved, a spokesman said.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, a 17-year-old from Lancashire, is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nIt comes after far-right agitator Tommy Robinson was accused of stoking tensions from afar after he promoted a \"pro-UK\" rally and appeared to defend the unrest on social media while on holiday abroad.\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and insisted that despite plans to release some offenders from prison early, there is capacity to hand custodial sentences to violent rioters.\n\nBut the Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chairman of the federation Brian Booth told the PA news agency: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nConservative leader Rishi Sunak said the scenes had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and warned that \"violent, criminal behaviour has no place in our society\".\n\nStephen Parkinson, Director of Public Prosecutions, said extra lawyers had been drafted in over the weekend and would continue to work round the clock to ensure justice is served.\n\nHe has directed prosecutors to make immediate charging decisions where key evidence is in place \"and they are doing so\", he said.\n\n\"I am determined that we will act swiftly and robustly, giving the courts maximum ability to pass sentences that reflect what has occurred.\"", "source": {"uri": "southwalesargus.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "South {"uri": "8259288821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:56:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:56:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:53:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/1216785-uk-pm-promises-justice-as-racists-attack-mosques-ethnic-minorities", "title": "UK PM promises justice as racists attack mosques, ethnic minorities", "body": "LONDON: Prime Minister Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in England as the government announced emergency security for mosques as well the swift judicial action amid the threat of further disorder in next days.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the prime minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the prime minister said.\n\nHe said, \"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nHe told reporters that time has been spent over recent days working with police and the justice system to \"make sure that the necessary arrangements for law enforcement are in place\".\n\nIt means the system can get \"arrests, charge, remand and custody and conviction done very quickly\".\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country and we will bring them to justice,\" he said.\n\nAsked whether he thought everyone taking part in the riots were far-right thugs, he said: \"If you target people because of the colour of their skin or their face then that is far right and I'm prepared to say so. But it doesn't matter what apparent motivation there is. This is violence, not protest. It doesn't matter what the motivation is,\" he said.\n\nHe hit out at the \"marauding gangs intent on breaking the law or worse\", adding: \"There is no justification, none, for taking this action and all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon.\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\n17-year-old Axel Rudakubana is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far said they have been reassured by police that forces have the resources they need to respond to the violence.\n\nMeanwhile, the Muslim Council of Britain said British Muslims have been living with anxiety and fear as far-right mobs have terrorised Muslim communities across the country, attempting to attack mosques and individuals.\n\nZara Mohammed, Secretary General of the Muslim Council of Britain, said: \"The last week we have seen two Britains at play. The first is a mainstream, multicultural, and merciful Britain driven by hope. We saw it reflected on the streets of Southport when communities came together to clean up after protests outside a mosque. This spirit of solidarity was replicated throughout the country.\n\nThe second Britain is a fringe, fearful, and fractious Britain, driven by hatred of the other. Far-right thugs descended on Southport and elsewhere to spew hatred outside a mosque, falsely thinking the person who committed those terrible murders against the poor girls was a Muslim.\"\n\n\"What we saw on the streets of Britain the consequence of unchecked Islamophobia: acceptable, potent, and very real in our society today. The government is right to speak out against the extremism witnessed on our streets, but it has been silent on the Islamophobia fueling that extremism. Reports of terrifying Islamophobic and criminal behaviour have emerged this weekend, targeting local communities, including mosques, shops, and the police. These violent thugs have been damaging property, looting shops, and attacking innocent bystanders in what appear to be racially motivated attacks. Incidents include stabbings and smashed windows of refugee accommodations, accompanied by chants of Tommy Robinson. We commend the police for their bravery in dealing with this unprecedented level of violence and criminality. We are heartened by the hundreds who opposed this racism, protected mosques, cleaned up the streets, and reminded us of the importance of staying united.\"", "source": {"uri": "thenews.com.pk", {"uri": "8259008905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:10:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:10:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:09:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kidderminstershuttle.co.uk/news/national/24496868.pm-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-mosques-offered-emergency-support/", "title": "PM tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes after ugly scenes of anti-immigration rioters attacking police and smashing the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on Sunday as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person was already arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, 17, is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nIt comes after far-right agitator Tommy Robinson was accused of stoking tensions from afar after he promoted a \"pro-UK\" rally and appeared to defend the unrest on social media while on holiday abroad.\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and insisted that despite plans to release some offenders from prison early, there is capacity to hand custodial sentences to violent rioters.\n\nBut the Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chairman of the federation Brian Booth told the PA news agency: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nConservative leader Rishi Sunak said the scenes had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and warned that \"violent, criminal behaviour has no place in our society\".\n\nStephen Parkinson, Director of Public Prosecutions, said extra lawyers had been drafted in over the weekend and would continue to work round the clock to ensure justice is served.\n\nHe has directed prosecutors to make immediate charging decisions where key evidence is in place \"and they are doing so\", he said.\n\n\"I am determined that we will act swiftly and robustly, giving the courts maximum ability to pass sentences that reflect what has occurred.\"", "source": {"uri": "kidderminstershuttle.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8259481507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:36:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:36:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:35:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://citinewsroom.com/2024/08/uk-to-hold-top-emergency-meeting-after-widespread-violence/", "title": "UK to hold top emergency meeting after widespread violence", "body": "Downing Street has confirmed there will be an emergency response meeting on Monday after more than 150 people were arrested following violent disorder in UK towns and cities over the weekend.\n\nIt comes after Sir Keir Starmer condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would face \"the full force of the law\".\n\nPolice responded to violent scenes in Rotherham, Middlesbrough, Bolton and other parts of the UK on Sunday.\n\nThe Cobra meeting will come after a sixth day of escalating violence following the fatal stabbing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nIt is an emergency response committee, a get together of ministers, civil servants, the police, intelligence officers and others appropriate to whatever they are looking into.\n\nMonday's meeting of the emergency committee will be intended to provide the government with an update on the violence over the weekend and the response in the coming days. It will involve relevant ministers and police representatives.\n\nSources have suggested this should be seen in the context of meetings that have already taken place, such as one between the prime minister and police chiefs last Thursday, and a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday.\n\nDuring the prime minister's televised address on Sunday, he warned those involved that they would \"regret\" taking part.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the prime minister said.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Home Office offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nIn Rotherham, at least ten police officers were injured with one left unconscious after anti-immigration demonstrators threw planks of wood at officers and sprayed them with fire extinguishers, South Yorkshire police said.\n\nSome members of the group smashed windows to gain access to a Holiday Inn Express and a large bin was set alight.\n\nThe officer knocked unconscious suffered a head injury, the force said, adding that at least two others had suspected broken bones.\n\nHotel employees and residents, some of whom are asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", but no injuries were reported, police said.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper called the scenes \"utterly appalling\" and said police have government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nAt a second hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, officers said they had to deal with \"violent acts of thuggery\" on Sunday evening.\n\nOne officer was injured at the site as people threw missiles, smashed windows, and started fires, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers.\n\nIn Dorset, 600 people from opposing sides gathered on the seafront in Weymouth. Officers said there had been a \"small number of low-level incidents\", with one man arrested for a public order offence.\n\nAnd in Bolton, anti-immigration protestors were confronted by a group of up to 300 masked people shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" - or \"God is greatest\".\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order in the town which requires people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nThe violence followed similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests... and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track {"uri": "2024-08-443962149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:01:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/24496943.cobra-meeting-planned-thugs-target-hotels-housing-asylum-seekers/", "title": "Cobra meeting planned after thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Downing Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper will appear on news programmes on And he said he was not afraid to call those targeting people for the colour of their skin or their faith \"far right\".\n\nIn a message to rioters, Mr Starmer said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\" He added: \"This is not protest, it is organised violent thuggery and it has no place in our streets\".\n\nThe PM said the riots had seen \"Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques, other minority communities singles out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric\". He added: \"To those of you who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin of your faith, I know how frightening this must be. I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country and we will bring them to justice\"\n\nAnti-immigration demonstrators have attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel housing asylum seekers Rotherham, as unrest across the country intensifies over the weekend. Masked rioters launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express in the South Yorkshire town. Videos from social media appeared to show demonstrators storming into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday announced greater protection for mosques, with new emergency security that can be rapidly deployed. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said: \"The criminal, violent attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham is utterly appalling. Deliberately setting fire to a building with people known to be inside. South Yorkshire Police have full Government support for the strongest action against those responsible.\"\n\nDozens of arrests were made on Saturday after multiple towns and cities saw clashes between anti-immigration demonstrators and counter-protesters. There was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast which saw several police officers attacked and injured.\n\nThe string of violent incidents over the past few days began on Tuesday in Southport, after three girls were killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed holiday club. Axel Rudakubana, who was born in Cardiff, was charged with murdering the three girls. {"uri": "8259188678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:20:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:20:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:18:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/us/i-utterly-condemn-the-far-right-thuggery-uk-pm-keir-starmer-amid-violence20240805041927/", "title": "\"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery': UK PM Keir Starmer amid violence", "body": "London [UK], August 5 (ANI): Amid the ongoing protest in United Kingdom, Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the protest and stated that 'this is not a protest it is organised violent thuggery.'\n\nViolence broke out in several UK cities on Saturday, following a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga class for elementary school-aged girls. The incident sparked widespread unrest and riots in multiple cities, which were fueled by far-right groups\n\nAfter the incident, Starmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer further said \"there is no justification\" for the far-right violence, which has led to attacks on mosques and assaults on Muslims.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted. Attacks on mosques. Other minority communities were singled out. Nazi salutes in the street. Attacks on the police.\" Starmer said.\n\nFurther, the prime minister added that \"he won't shy away from calling it [the rioting] what it is\" and that is \"far-right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be,\" he said.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob does not represent our country and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motivation, we make no distinction. Crime is a crime and this government will tackle it,\" he added.\n\nEarlier in the day, far-right demonstrators vandalised a hotel housing asylum seekers in the northern England town of Rotherham, as the United Kingdom grappled with its worst riots in 13 years, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nOn Sunday, hundreds of people gathered at a Holiday Inn Express hotel used to house asylum seekers near Rotherham before throwing bricks at police, breaking several hotel windows, and then setting bins on fire.\n\nThe unrest is the latest bout of rioting in the UK that has gripped the nation, following a stabbing rampage at a dance class last week in the north of England that left three girls dead and several wounded, as per Al Jazeera.\n\nAccording to police officials, false rumours spread online that the young man in the Southport stabbing was a Muslim and an immigrant, fuelling anger among the far-right in the country. "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/crime/rotherham-riot-prime-minister-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-4728730", "title": "Prime Minister tells rioters \"you will regret it\"", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" taking part in \"far-right thuggery\" after a fifth day of violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nSign up for newsletters from The Star\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England .\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away as the atmosphere turned febrile.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office , on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \" Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we Those individuals who are involved in the disorder need to know that they will pay a price.\"\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least ten officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars, and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nProtests were held in London, Aldershot, Hartlepool, and Manchester last week.\n\nMore than 50 police officers were also hurt in the first wave of violence seen in Southport the day after the stabbings.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the prime minister said: \"I guarantee you will seekers", "body": "Cobra meeting planned after thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers\n\nGeorge Lithgow\n\n5 August 2024 at 7:59 am\n\nDowning Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/24496837.pm-tells-rioters-you-will-regret-it-mosques-offered-support/", "title": "PM tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "In a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes after ugly scenes of anti-immigration rioters attacking police and smashing the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on Sunday as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person was already arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\n17-year-old Axel Rudakubana is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and insisted that despite plans to release some offenders from prison early, there is capacity to hand custodial sentences to violent rioters.\n\nBut the Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chairman of the federation Brian Booth told the PA news agency: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"\n\nConservative leader Rishi Sunak said the scenes had \"nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport\" and warned that \"violent, criminal behaviour has no place in our society\".\n\nStephen Parkinson, Director of Public Prosecutions, said extra lawyers had been drafted in over the weekend and would continue to work round the clock to ensure justice is served.\n\nHe has directed prosecutors to make immediate charging decisions where key evidence is in place \"and they are doing so\", he said.\n\n\"I am determined that we will act swiftly and robustly, giving the courts maximum ability to pass sentences that reflect what has occurred.\"", "source": {"uri": "asianimage.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Asian {"uri": "8259662395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:57:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:57:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:57:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/urgent-cobra-meeting-called-after-29677217", "title": "Urgent Cobra meeting called after weekend of violence across the UK - Liverpool Echo", "body": "Police were attacked, buildings set on fire and shops looted in horrifying scenes\n\nDowning Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting today after thugs tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder. Addressing the nation on Sunday, Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would regret engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law.\"\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the emergency services response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes. The Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted. In Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\". Masked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed. People threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said. Greater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week. The widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets. Ministers have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country.\" In his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence. She told the Guardian: \"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time.\" Writing in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums.\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities. They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\". Shadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\". A fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk",
