"sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/starmer-hold-cobra-meeting-far-062042385.html", "title": "Starmer to hold Cobra meeting after far-right thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Downing Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nSir Keir Starmer\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the prime minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8259185520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:23:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:23:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:14:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/i-utterly-condemn-the-far-right-thuggery-uk-pm-keir-starmer-amid-violence/2207923/", "title": "\"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery': UK PM Keir Starmer amid violence", "body": "Violence broke out in several UK cities on Saturday, following a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga class for elementary school-aged girls. The incident sparked widespread unrest and riots in multiple cities, which were fueled by far-right groups\n\nAfter the incident, Starmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer further said \"there is no justification\" for the far-right violence, which has led to attacks on mosques and assaults on Muslims.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted. Attacks on mosques. Other minority communities were singled out. Nazi salutes in the street. Attacks on the police.\" Starmer said.\n\nFurther, the prime minister added that \"he won't shy away from calling it [the rioting] what it is\" and that is \"far-right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be,\" he said.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob does not represent our country and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motivation, we make no distinction. Crime is a crime and this government will tackle it,\" he added.\n\nEarlier in the day, far-right demonstrators vandalised a hotel housing asylum seekers in the northern England town of Rotherham, as the United Kingdom grappled with its worst riots in 13 years, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nOn Sunday, hundreds of people gathered at a Holiday Inn Express hotel used to house asylum seekers near Rotherham before throwing bricks at police, breaking several hotel windows, and then setting bins on fire.\n\nThe unrest is the latest bout of rioting in the UK that has gripped the nation, following a stabbing rampage at a dance class last week in the north of England that left three girls dead and several wounded, as per Al Jazeera.\n\nAccording to police officials, false rumours spread online that the young man in the Southport stabbing was a Muslim and an immigrant, fuelling anger among the far-right in the country. "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/cobra-meeting-planned-weekend-riots-053917251.html", "title": "Cobra meeting planned after weekend of riots sees far-right thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Sir Keir Starmer is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday morning after far-right thugs tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nThe Prime Minister vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which {"uri": "8259323427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:44:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:44:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:43:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-uk-riots-pm-keir-starmer-condemns-far-right-thuggery-amid-violence-says-i-guarantee-you-will-3100422", "title": "UK Riots: PM Keir Starmer condemns 'far right thuggery' amid violence, says, 'I guarantee you will...'", "body": "The incident sparked widespread unrest and riots in multiple cities, which were fueled by far-right groups\n\nAmid the ongoing protest in United Kingdom, Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the protest and stated that 'this is not a protest it is organised violent thuggery.' Violence broke out in several UK cities on Saturday, following a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga class for elementary school-aged girls. The incident sparked widespread unrest and riots in multiple cities, which were fueled by far-right groups.\n\nAfter the incident, Starmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer further said \"there is no justification\" for the far-right violence, which has led to attacks on mosques and assaults on Muslims.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted. Attacks on mosques. Other minority communities were singled out. Nazi salutes in the street. Attacks on the police.\" Starmer said.\n\nFurther, the prime minister added that \"he won't shy away from calling it [the rioting] what it is\" and that is \"far-right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be,\" he said.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob does not represent our country and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motivation, we make no distinction. Crime is a crime and this government will tackle it,\" he added.\n\nEarlier in the day, far-right demonstrators vandalised a hotel housing asylum seekers in the northern England town of Rotherham, as the United Kingdom grappled with its worst riots in 13 years, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nOn Sunday, hundreds of people gathered at a Holiday Inn Express hotel used to house asylum seekers near Rotherham before throwing bricks at police, breaking several hotel windows, and then setting bins on fire.\n\nThe unrest is the latest bout of rioting in the UK that has gripped the nation, following a stabbing rampage at a dance class last week in the north of England that left three girls dead and several wounded, as per Al Jazeera.\n\nAccording to police officials, false rumours spread online that the "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.mylondon.news/news/uk-world-news/keir-starmer-tells-rioters-you-29675968", "title": "Keir Starmer tells rioters 'you will regret it' and slams 'far-right thuggery'", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" taking part in \"far-right thuggery\" after a fifth day of violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nREAD MORE: New interactive map shows how many people have been arrested for rioting\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\n'We will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible'\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England. A library, which provided support for one of the most deprived communities in the country, was torched in Liverpool.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away as the atmosphere turned febrile.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office, on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal {"uri": "8259603188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:15:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:15:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:14:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/cobra-meeting-planned-weekend-riots-053917251.html", "title": "Forget about summer holidays you're being locked up, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper tells thugs who went on rampage", "body": "Violent thugs who went on the rampage in towns and cities in Britain were warned on Monday they face being locked up within days rather than heading off on summer holidays.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper stressed that police were getting the full backing of the Government to crack down on the violent protests.\n\nShe slammed the \"disgraceful scenes of criminal violence and thuggery\".\n\nVowing to deliver \"swift justice\" for the \"unacceptable disorder\", she emphasised that there would be a \"reckoning\" for the offenders, including \"serious prison sentences\" for the worst culprits.\n\n\"We simply can't stand for this,\" she told Sky News.\n\n\"So we should be clear there will be people who were thinking they were going on their summer holidays this week and instead they will face a knock on the door from the police, they will face arrest, and a police cell while they wait for trail in order to make sure that they do pay the price for what they have done.\"\n\nHundreds of people have already been arrested.\n\n\"We have made very clear to the police they have our full support in pursuing the full range of prosecutions and penalties including serious prison sentences, long term tagging travel bans and more,\" Ms Cooper added.\n\nThe full range of offenders would face justice, she added, from individuals who turned up at last minute and took part in looting to those who engaged in \"really dangerous arson, damage and criminal violence.\n\nSir Keir Starmer is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday morning after far-right thugs tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nThe Prime Minister vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.", {"uri": "8258935910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:43:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:43:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:42:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41450167.html", "title": "Starmer tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "In a televised address to the nation, the British prime minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Mr Starmer suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" Mr Starmer said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nHe indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham as the atmosphere turned increasingly febrile on the sixth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside a Holiday Inn Express, with some storming past a police line and into the ground floor, which was set on fire during the disorder.\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away.\n\nMeanwhile,a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nIt follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nCleveland Police has said nine arrests have been made so far.\n\nThe British home secreatary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office on Sunday offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nViolence has broken out in parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, with 147 arrests made since Saturday alone.\n\n17-year-old Axel Rudakubana is accused of the attack, but false claims spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker who had travelled to the UK by boat.\n\nThe far right have been widely condemned as the organising force behind the subsequent unrest, which has seen bricks pelted at police officers, community facilities including a library set on fire, mosques attacked and shops looted.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nMr Starmer said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nForces are bracing for further unrest, with Greater Manchester Police issuing a Section 60AA order in Bolton requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\" which will stay in force until 10pm.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nMinisters have so far said they have been reassured by police that forces have the resources they need to respond to the violence.\n\nThe Police Federation for England and Wales has voiced concerns that officers will be left unable to attend other incidents as they focus efforts on quelling the disorder, warning \"there is a cost to all this\".\n\nDeputy chairman of the federation Brian Booth told the PA news agency: \"Every day this continues means a certain amount of officer hours are being taken away from other policing duties. It has a massive effect on already significant under-resourcing.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "body": "PM tells rioters 'you will regret it' as mosques offered emergency support\n\nNina Lloyd, PA Political Correspondent\n\n4 August 2024 at 6:20 pm\n\nKeir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" taking part in \"far-right thuggery\" after a fifth day of violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away as the atmosphere turned febrile.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office, on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the The attack sparked violent protests in several cities.\n\nAfter the incident, Starmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer further said \"there is no justification\" for the far-right violence, which has led to attacks on mosques and assaults on Muslims.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted. Attacks on mosques. Other minority communities were singled out. Nazi salutes in the street. Attacks on the police.\" Starmer said.\n\nFurther, the prime minister added that \"he won't shy away from calling it [the rioting] what it is\" and that is \"far-right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be,\" he said.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob does not represent our country and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motivation, we make no distinction. Crime is a crime and this government will tackle it,\" he added.\n\nEarlier in the day, far-right demonstrators vandalised a hotel housing asylum seekers in the northern England town of Rotherham, as the United Kingdom grappled with its worst riots in 13 years, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nOn Sunday, hundreds of people gathered at a Holiday Inn Express hotel used to house asylum seekers near Rotherham before throwing bricks at police, breaking several hotel windows, and then setting bins on fire.\n\nThe UK has recently been engulfed by a surge of violence following a heartbreaking knife attack during a dance session in North England. The attack tragically took three young lives and left several others wounded, shaking the nation to its core. The situation worsened when inaccurate information spread on the internet incorrectly pinpointed the offender of the Southport stabbing as a Muslim immigrant. announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA protester uses a fire extinguisher on police officers as trouble flares in Rotherham, South Yorkshire (Danny Lawson/PA)\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\nA fire is extinguished by police officers outside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham (Danny Lawson/PA)\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nBritain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody action\".\n\nThe Home Office, on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who {"uri": "8259060855", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:17:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:17:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:16:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/starmer-condemns-far-thuggery-more-200505601.html", "title": "Starmer condemns 'far-right thuggery' after more violence", "body": "Violence erupted at far-right organised demonstrations in UK towns and cities on Sunday, prompting Keir Starmer to condemn \"marauding gangs intent on law-breaking and nothing else\".\n\nThe prime minister vowed to do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice\" as he addressed the nation following ongoing unrest across the country, telling those involved they will \"regret\" taking part.\n\nIn Rotherham, a group of 700 people surrounded a Holiday Inn Express hotel, where some lit a fire, smashed windows and managed to get inside the building where asylum seekers were staying.\n\nRiot police also responded to violent scenes in Middlesbrough, Bolton, Hull and Weymouth, among other parts of the UK.\n\nSir Keir vowed rioters would feel the \"full force of the law\" for engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in response to the fatal stabbing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the prime minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSince Saturday, 147 arrests have been made.\n\nIn Rotherham, at least ten police officers were injured with one left unconscious after anti-immigration demonstrators threw planks of wood at officers and sprayed them with fire extinguishers, South Yorkshire police said.\n\nSome members of the group smashed windows to gain access to the Holiday Inn Express and a large bin was set alight.\n\nThe officer knocked unconscious suffered a head injury, the force said, adding that at least two others had suspected broken bones.\n\nHotel employees and residents, some of whom are asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", but no injuries were reported, police said.\n\nOne person has been arrested on suspicion of public order offences.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper called the scenes \"utterly appalling\" and said police have government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers.\n\nIn Dorset, 600 people from opposing sides gathered on the seafront in Weymouth. Officers said there had been a \"small number of low-level incidents\", with one man arrested for a public order offence.\n\nAnd in Bolton, anti-immigration protestors were confronted by a group of up 300 masked people shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" - or \"God is greatest\".\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order in the town which requires people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\". It will stay in force until 10pm on Sunday.\n\nThe violence follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nIn a statement on Sunday, the Home Office offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions - as they did in 2011 - while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.", violence in England", "body": "DOWNING Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday following violent riots in England and Northern Ireland over the weekend.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nREAD MORE: Tommy Robinson hides out in luxury 5-star resort amid far-right riots\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nA car burns during an anti-immigration protest in Middlesbrough\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nHumza Yousaf meanwhile said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nStarmer (above) said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Could Scotland experience far-right riots like in Southport?\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nA fundraiser after thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Downing Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper {"uri": "8259426464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:42:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:42:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:40:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/uk/cobra-meeting-planned-after-thugs-target-hotels-housing-asylum-seekers-C3E4EG5IO5IATK2O27GH7AQ7ZU/", "title": "Cobra meeting planned after thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Widespread unrest continued for the sixth day in a row following the killing of three young girls in Southport.\n\nDowning Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.", "source": {"uri": "irishnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259047339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:01:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:01:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2485539/far-right-mob-sets-uk-hotel-ablaze-premier-warns-of-consequences", "title": "Far-right mob sets UK hotel ablaze, Premier warns of consequences", "body": "The British prime minister on Sunday called the violent rioters \"far-right thuggery,\" warning that those taking part in the violent disorder on the streets would \"regret.\"\n\nThe prime minister was addressing to the nation after a large anti-immigrant protest turned violent on Sunday as far-right demonstrators attacked a Rotherham hotel housing asylum seeker, smashing windows and setting the building on fire.\n\nIn his address to the nation on the ongoing violent disorder, Keir Starmer said there is \"no doubt\" that those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly, or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" the premier said, adding that \"this is not protest,\" but \"organized violent thuggery.\"\n\nStarmer declared that it has no place on UK streets or online, citing attacks on a hotel in Rotherham in which windows were smashed, the building was set ablaze, and guests and staff were terrified.\n\n\"There is no justification, none for taking this action, and all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence.\"\n\nA large anti-immigrant protest turned violent on Sunday as far-right demonstrators attacked a Rotherham hotel housing asylum seekers, smashing windows and setting the building on fire.\n\nThe incident took place just before midday and was marked by far-right demonstrators' intense clashes with police and counter-protesters.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe and yet we have seen Muslim communities targeted and attacks on mosques... So, I won't shy away from calling it what it is, far-right thuggery,\" said Starmer.\n\nHe added: \"If you target a person because of the color of skin, religion this is far-right.\"\n\n'Violent attack on hotel housing asylum seekers utterly appalling'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper decried the rioters who targeted a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham, calling it \"utterly appalling.\"\n\n\"Deliberately setting fire to a building with people known to be inside. South Yorkshire Police have full Government support for the strongest action against those responsible,\" she noted.\n\nScotland's First Minister John Swinney also expressed concern over the incidents in Rotherham, saying that they, like other events in recent days, are \"the product of far-right racist thuggery.\"\n\n\"Racism must be confronted whenever and wherever it appears,\" he wrote on X.\n\nMichelle O'Neill, Northern Ireland's first minister, said she spoke with Irish Prime Minister Simon Harris over the phone following Saturday's attacks on communities and businesses in Belfast.\n\n\"Racism and hatred have no place -- and will never have a place -- on our island,\" O'Neill noted, adding that she is committed to continuing to work with everyone to build a better, and more inclusive future for everyone.\n\nRishi Sunak, leader of the opposition Conservative Party, said the \"shocking scenes we're seeing on the streets of Britain have nothing to do\" with the tragedy in Southport.\n\n\"This is violent, criminal behaviour that has no place in our society. The police have our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly and they must face the full weight of the law,\" he added.\n\nEarlier, authorities reported at least 100 arrests following the eruption of violence, not only in Rotherham but across the UK, with more demonstrations planned for later on Sunday.\n\nSimilar protests are expected in Bolton, Lancaster, Middlesborough, Weymouth, and Newcastle upon Tyne.\n\nMasked rioters, some draped in England flags, gathered outside the hotel, which is known to house migrants.\n\nLocal authorities are on high alert, anticipating more violent protests across the country on Sunday.\n\nThe unrest follows the tragic killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, an event that has further strained community relations and sparked {"uri": "8259449030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:06:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:06:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:05:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/world/2024-08-05-no-10-to-hold-cobra-meeting-after-weekend-of-escalating-violence/", "title": "No 10 to hold Cobra meeting after weekend of escalating violence", "body": "Downing Street has confirmed there will be an emergency response meeting on Monday after more than 150 people were arrested following violent disorder in UK towns and cities over the weekend.\n\nIt comes after Sir Keir Starmer condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would face \"the full force of the law\".\n\nPolice responded to violent scenes in Tamworth, Middlesbrough, Hull and other parts of the UK on Sunday.\n\nThe Cobra meeting will come after a sixth day of escalating violence following the fatal stabbing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nCobra meetings, or Cobr meetings as they are often also called, are named after Cabinet Office Briefing Room A on Whitehall.\n\nIt is an emergency response committee, a get together of ministers, civil servants, the police, intelligence officers and others appropriate to whatever they are looking into.\n\nMonday's meeting of the emergency committee will be intended to provide the government with an update on the violence over the weekend and the response in the coming days. It will involve relevant ministers and police representatives.\n\nSources have suggested this should be seen in the context of meetings that have already taken place, such as one between the prime minister and police chiefs last Thursday, and a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday.\n\nDuring the prime minister's televised address on Sunday, he warned those involved that they will \"regret\" taking part.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the prime minister said.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Home Office offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nIn Rotherham, at least ten police officers were injured with one left unconscious after anti-immigration demonstrators threw planks of wood at officers and sprayed them with fire extinguishers, South Yorkshire police said.\n\nSome members of the group smashed windows to gain access to a Holiday Inn Express and a large bin was set alight.\n\nThe officer knocked unconscious suffered a head injury, the force said, adding that at least two others had suspected broken bones.\n\nHotel employees and residents, some of whom are asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", but no injuries were reported, police said.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper called the scenes \"utterly appalling\" and said police have government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nAt a second hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, officers said they had to deal with \"violent acts of thuggery\" on Sunday evening.\n\nOne officer was injured at the site as people threw missiles, smashed windows, and started fires, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers.\n\nIn Dorset, 600 people from opposing sides gathered on the seafront in Weymouth. Officers said there had been a \"small number of low-level incidents\", with one man arrested for a public order offence.\n\nAnd in Bolton, anti-immigration protestors were confronted by a group of up to 300 masked people shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" - or \"God is greatest\".\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order in the town which requires people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nThe violence followed similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests... and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track 'Far-right thugs' also tried to storm Holiday Inn hotels housing asylum seekers.\n\nLast night (Sunday), anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires in Rotherham. At least 10 officers were injured in the violent scenes, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police said.\n\nREAD NEXT: 'We're living in fear': As riots and protests bring havoc to UK, Manchester's religious leaders aren't surprised\n\nOne person was arrested, with police stating that others involved should 'expect us to be at their doors very soon'. Masked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after around 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth on Sunday night, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed. People threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nIn Middlesborough, a large crowd gathered outside a mosque. A group of rioters also smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said. In Greater Manchester over the weekend, large-scale demonstrations were held in both Manchester city centre and Bolton.\n\nA demonstration organised under the banner of 'Enough is Enough' in the city centre on Saturday became violent as attendees clashed with counter protesters and police. Fights broke out, a supermarket had to be closed and public transport was brought to a standstill.\n\nOn Sunday, a protest under the same name was held in Bolton. The arrival of around 300 counter protestors sparked chanting between the groups, with missiles thrown at police and several scuffles.\n\nAddressing the nation yesterday, Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would 'regret' engaging in 'far-right thuggery' and promised those involved in unrest would 'face the full force of the law'. Sir Keir said he wanted those who 'feel targeted because of the colour of their skin' to know 'this violent mob do not represent our country'.\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nToday's Cobra meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes. MPs, including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel, have said Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons can debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop 'thugs' causing disorder on the streets. Ministers have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nThe first of the major riots broke out in Southport last week following the tragic murder of three young girls at a school holiday dance event. {"uri": "8259734652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:47:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:47:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://guyanachronicle.com/2024/08/05/no-10-downing-street-to-hold-cobra-meeting-today/", "title": "No. 10 Downing Street to hold 'Cobra meeting' today - Guyana Chronicle", "body": "THERE will be an emergency response meeting in Downing Street today after more than 150 people were arrested following violent disorder in UK towns and cities over the weekend.\n\nIt comes after Sir Keir Starmer condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham, and promised those involved in the unrest would face \"the full force of the law.\"\n\nPolice responded to violent scenes in Tamworth, Middlesbrough, Bolton, Hull and Weymouth, among other parts of the UK.\n\nThe prime minister vowed to do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nToday's meeting of the emergency committee, known as Cobra, is intended to provide the government with an update on the violence over the weekend, and the response in the coming days.\n\nIt will involve relevant ministers and police representatives.\n\nSources suggested this should be seen in the context of meetings that have already taken place, such as one between the prime minister and police chiefs last Thursday, and a meeting of senior ministers on Saturday.\n\nDuring the prime minister's televised address on Sunday, he warned those involved that they will \"regret\" taking part.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targetted, attacks on mosques,\" the prime minister said.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: Far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Home Office offered mosques greater protection as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nThe Cobra meeting will come after a sixth day of escalating violence following the fatal stabbing of three young girls in Southport last Monday.\n\nSince Saturday, more than 150 arrests have been made.\n\nIn Rotherham, at least ten police officers were injured, with one left unconscious after anti-immigration demonstrators threw planks of wood at officers, and sprayed them with fire extinguishers, South Yorkshire police said.\n\nSome members of the group smashed windows to gain access to the Holiday Inn Express, and a large bin was set alight.\n\nThe officer knocked unconscious suffered a head injury, the Force said, adding that at least two others had suspected broken bones.\n\nHotel employees and residents, some of whom are asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", but no injuries were reported, police said.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper called the scenes \"utterly appalling\" and said police have government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nAt a second hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, officers said they had to deal with \"violent acts of thuggery\" on Sunday evening.\n\nOne officer was injured at the site as people threw missiles, smashed windows, and started fires, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nMeanwhile, a group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars, and hurled objects at officers.\n\nIn Dorset, 600 people from opposing sides gathered on the seafront in Weymouth. Officers said there had been a \"small number of low-level incidents\", with one man arrested for a public-order offence.\n\nAnd in Bolton, anti-immigration protestors were confronted by a group of up to 300 masked people shouting \"Allahu Akbar\", or \"God is greatest\".\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order in the town which requires people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nThe violence follows similar scenes of unrest in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and elsewhere earlier in the week.\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement, which means that we can get arrests... and convictions done very quickly,\" he said, adding:\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011, when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions, as they did in 2011, while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.
