regret it' as mosques offered emergency support", "body": "Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" taking part in \"far-right thuggery\" after a fifth day of violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nBritain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin\n\nA police helicopter circled overhead, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was carried away as the atmosphere turned febrile.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office, on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would 'regret' engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nToday's meeting at No 10 is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives and outline a response for the coming days to prevent further outbreaks of mob violence in towns and cities across the country, according to reports on PA. The Home Office announced at the weekend that mosques would be offered greater protection via a new 'rapid response process' designed to intercept the potential of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nSunday night saw a large crowd gather outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on and others have been targeted. In Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires and hurling chairs and other debris at police officers.\n\nREAD MORE\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should 'expect us to be at their doors very soon'. Masked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed. People threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: 'It's our f****** country.' There were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots. The former home secretary told Times Radio: \"I would not feel safe in some of the areas and communities where we've seen racism and thuggery on our streets.\n\n\"I grew up with people using the P-word against me. And I think some of the individuals that are now involved in this violence, disorder and racism that we are seeing in parts of the country - that's no different to the type of racism that I experienced when I was growing up, and I just think that there's no place for that in our amazing country,\" she added.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to 'remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance'. Violence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week. The former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop 'thugs' causing disorder on the streets.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who 'feel targeted because of the colour of their skin' to know 'this violent mob do not represent our country'. {"uri": "8259060844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:19:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:19:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:16:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/guarantee-regret-taking-part-starmer-201239407.html", "title": "I guarantee you will regret taking part, Starmer tells rioters", "body": "Sir Keir Starmer has told rioters they will regret taking part in disorder as unrest continued for a fifth day.\n\nIn an emergency address from Downing Street, the Prime Minister said that he would do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible\" amid violence that has spread since the Southport killings.\n\nSir Keir confirmed rioters will be held on remand, jailing them immediately after arrest.\n\n\"Charges will follow and convictions will follow,\" he added.\n\nThe move mirrors action taken following the 2011 riots when Sir Keir was Director of Public Prosecutions.\n\nHis remarks came as the Home Office announced that security is being stepped up around Britain's mosques in light of the rioting.\n\nProtesters are gathering outside a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, that houses asylum seekers.\n\nVideos posted on social media show dozens of demonstrators confronting riot-shield equipped police outside the building, with at least one police dog seen close to the main entrance.\n\nOther footage shows rioters breaking the hotel's windows by throwing objects at them.\n\nRioters have now started a bonfire in the middle of the road 500 metres from the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham and are throwing bins at police officers, Neil Johnston reports from the scene.\n\nPolice earlier dispersed rioters outside the hotel, but the agitators have since clashed with officers at a location farther down the road.\n\nDozens more riot police have arrived to stop a fresh assault on the hotel, where migrants are watching from the windows.\n\nThe mob threw a barrage of fences and fireworks at police, and spooked some of the force's horses.\n\nOfficers with riot-shields were seen lining up to face the crowd as a fire blazes in the background.\n\nBy Neil Johnston\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police has said that 10 officers were injured in the \"deplorable acts of violence\" at the Holiday Inn Express Hotel in Manvers, Rotherham earlier today.\n\nOne officer was left unconscious after a head injury, the force said, with other officers suffering suspected broken bones.\n\nThere have so far been no reports of injuries to hotel staff or residents.\n\nPolice said around 700 people had taken part in the disorder outside the hotel on Sunday.\n\nA Channel 4 news correspondent has shared footage of what appears to be a group of Asian men attacking a lone white male on the streets of Middlesbrough.\n\nPolice are reportedly playing a game of \"cat and mouse\" as groups of Asian and white men roam the streets looking for trouble.\n\nCleveland Police earlier said nine people had been arrested in connection with the disturbances in Middlesbrough.\n\nAn anti-immigration protest called 'Enough is Enough' is underway in Weymouth, where the BBC reports that 400 protesters from opposing sides are gathered on the seafront chanting at each other.\n\nThe broadcaster said that police officers have moved people off the beach because some anti-immigrant protesters had pushed through the police line.\n\nWe earlier reported that police had removed rioters from the Rotherham migrant hotel that was attacked and set on fire earlier in the day.\n\nOur reporter Neil Johnston writes that agitators have now begun to attack again the hotel via a different route:\n\nSir Keir Starmer held an emergency address from Downing Street on Sunday afternoon, where he said rioters \"will regret taking part in this disorder\".\n\nHe added that the police \"will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow\".\n\nThe Prime Minister also vowed that \"would not shy away\" from calling the disturbances \"far-Right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be. I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country and we will bring them to justice,\" he said.\n\nCleveland Police said officers have arrested nine people so far in relation to the ongoing disorder in Middlesbrough.\n\nThe force added that the main areas affected by disorder were Parliament Road, Waterloo Road, and the area around the university.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable David Felton said: \"We are urging members of the public to stay away from Middlesbrough while officers respond to violent disorder in the town.\n\n\"We have a high policing presence responding to the disorder, and the priority remains to protect people and communities.\n\n\"We will continue to make arrests and deal robustly with anyone shown to be intent on committing violence and causing harm.\"\n\nSir Ed Davey, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, said: \"Everyone across the UK was shocked and appalled by the dreadful attack in Southport on Monday, which took the lives of three innocent little girls.\n\n\"Most people have come together to grieve with love and compassion. But sadly, a minority of far-right extremists have disgraced themselves by exploiting this tragedy to commit appalling acts of violence, targeting Muslims, asylum seekers and communities of colour.\n\n\"I am deeply angered by the riots and disorder that we have seen these past few days and welcome the extra protections now in place. This lawlessness is unacceptable and it must be stopped and those responsible must face the full force of the law.\n\n\"And amidst these awful scenes, we should all take heart from the immense compassion, kindness and decency shown by the vast majority, not least those communities who are being specifically targeted. Their example is one we must all follow.\"\n\nRishi Sunak, the Conservative Party leader, has condemned the unrest gripping Britain as \"violent, criminal behaviour that has no place in our society\".\n\n\"The police have our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly and they must face the full weight of the law,\" he added.\n\nMore from Crime Editor Martin Evans on the ongoing disorder in Middlesbrough:\n\nMosques will now be able to request \"rapid response\" security under a new security scheme just announced by the Home Office.\n\nThe plans state that mosques, police and local authorities can ask for rapid security personnel to be deployed, which will \"allow for a return to worship as quickly as possible\".\n\nIn a statement, the Home Office said the scheme would \"build on the existing Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, with up to \u00a329.4 million already available this year to fund security at mosques and Muslim faith schools\".\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nElon Musk, the Tesla and X chief, has said that civil war in the UK is \"inevitable\".\n\nResponding to a clip posted on social media showing recent rioting in Britain, Mr Musk wrote: \"Civil war is inevitable.\"\n\nThe comment received over one million views.\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, has condemned the attack on a migrant hotel in Rotherham, calling it \"utterly appalling\".\n\n\"South Yorkshire Police have full Government support for the strongest action against those responsible,\" she added.\n\nThe BBC reports that a group of around 250-300 protesters chanting \"Allahu Akbar\" has clashed with police and Right-wing demonstrators in Bolton.\n\nAccording to the broadcaster, the group charged towards Bolton Town Hall, where protesters waving England flags had gathered.\n\nOn a further cry of \"Allahu Akbar\", the group began throwing eggs at the police before \"charging\" around streets in the town centre.\n\nThe two groups of protesters then skirmished on another street, where bottles and fireworks were exchanged, but both sides were kept apart by police lines.\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nMalaysia has issued a warning to its citizens travelling to or residing in the UK, advising them to \"remain vigilant\" and to \"stay away from protest areas\".\n\nThe warning, released on Sunday by the country's ministry of foreign affairs, also encourages Malaysian citizens to register with the country's high commission in London in order to receive assistance and information.\n\nHumza Yousaf, the former first minister of Scotland, has suggested that Sir Keir Starmer should send in the army to quell rioting across Britain.\n\nIn a post on X, Mr Yousaf wrote: \"How much worse does it have to get before the army is sent in @Keir Starmer?\n\n\"The Police clearly do not have a handle on this situation. This pogrom against Muslims and People of Colour is going to cost lives unless these far-right thugs are stopped.\"\n\nJames Cleverly, the MP for Braintree, and Tom Tugendhat, the MP for Tonbridge, have condemned the attack on a migrant hotel in Rotherham.\n\nIn a post on X, Mr Tugendhat wrote: \"This behaviour is abhorrent. We have got to put an end to the violence and disorder plaguing our streets. The government must use all the available resources to punish those responsible.\"\n\nMr Cleverly wrote: \"There is not and can never be any excuse, justification or rationale for behavior like this. This should be condemned by everybody, and those taking part should expect to be met with the full weight of the law.\"\n\nBy Martin Evans, our crime editor\n\nMore than 300 protesters marched through Middlesbrough after gathering at the city's Cenotaph.\n\nDemonstrators were seen carrying a banner saying: \"Tom Jones is Welsh, Axel Rudakubana isn't\" and chanted \"We want our country back\" as they made their way through the city.\n\nPolice used dogs to keep the group back and at least two people were taken away in handcuffs within the first half hour, while several pieces of slate were thrown, along with vapes and full plastic bottles.\n\nOur reporter Kevin Donald is on the ground in Middlesbrough. He reports that \"skirmishes\" have broken out between police and agitators.\n\nSarah Champion, the Labour MP for Rotherham, has described the ongoing riot at a migrant hotel in Manvers, Rotherham as \"horrendous\" in a post on social media.\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nSocial media footage shows rioters battling with mounted police on the streets of Bolton.\n\nGreater Manchester Police earlier issued a Section 34 dispersal notice covering Bolton until 10pm, which gives the force extra powers to remove people causing anti-social behaviour.\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a section 34 dispersal notice has been authorised covering Bolton until 10pm on Sunday.\n\nUnder a Section 34 notice, officers have extra powers to deal with anyone causing anti-social behaviour in defined areas.\n\nThe force said officers will be able to instruct anyone who is causing - or very likely to cause - harassment, alarm, or distress to leave an area immediately.\n\nChief Inspector Natasha Evans said: \"These powers have been authorised in response to increased protest activity.\n\n\"We have been working with organisers of pre-planned protests to help facilitate peaceful and lawful protests, to prevent serious disruption and ensure everyone can go about their lives without fear or risk of harm.\n\n\"We will continue to have an increased police presence around these areas to deal with any incidents that may arise, and with these additional powers, officers are more equipped to intervene early to ensure people feel safe and are safe.\"\n\nProtesters have gathered outside the Holiday Inn Express in Manvers, Rotherham, which has been used as an asylum hotel.\n\nBoth anti-immigration protesters and counter-protesters have been pictured outside the hotel in South Yorkshire (see our posts at 12.47pm and 12.07pm).\n\nThe number of protesters is not as large as was seen during Saturday's protests, but there is a police presence at the scene.\n\nTory leadership hopeful Robert Jenrick has said that Sir Keir Starmer should \"cancel this Nero-esque holiday\".\n\nIt would be \"completely wrong for the Prime Minister to holiday while parts of Britain are burning\", Mr Jenrick added.\n\nThe comments came after reports circulated that Sir Keir Starmer was set to take his first holiday as Prime Minister at the start of next week.\n\nHowever, sources close to No 10 have suggested to the PA news agency that Sir Keir will not be going on holiday with the prospect of further unrest looming.\n\nSpellow Hub library on County Road in Liverpool was set ablaze during far-Right rioting on Saturday (see our posts at 9.29am and 9.54am).\n\nMerseyside Police said that protesters attempted to stop firefighters at the scene putting out the blaze.\n\nStreet cleaning teams in Hull worked overnight to ensure the city would be open for business on Sunday, the city council said.\n\nVolunteers also arrived with brushes early on Sunday morning to assist the council crews.\n\nCouncillor Jack Haines of Hull City Council said: \"Yesterday we saw the worst of Hull but already today we have seen the best.\n\n\"The cleaning teams have made fantastic progress overnight. The main streets are largely clear and the interchange has reopened.\n\n\"We have already seen the power in our community with volunteers turning up from 7am this morning with brushes to assist council teams. I thank all volunteers and council staff.\n\n\"With the clean-up largely completed and areas clear, the best way anyone can help today is to come together, enjoy our city and support local shops and business.\"\n\nCleveland Police has denied rumours circulating online that a Muslim woman was attacked with acid in Middlesbrough during unrest on Saturday.\n\nThe force said it had not received \"any formal complaint\" from a victim or anyone on their behalf. It also said it had not received notification from medical colleagues of any such incident.\n\nOn Saturday, reports of the attack were shared on social media by Nick Lowles, chief executive of Left-wing group Hope not Hate, and Josh Fenton-Glynn, the Labour MP for Calder Valley.\n\n\"Reports are coming in of acid being thrown out of a car window at a Muslim woman in Middlesbrough. Absolutely horrendous,\" Mr Lowles posted on X.\n\nIn response to Mr Lowles' post, Mr Fenton-Glynn wrote: \"Far right cowards attacking women. When people show you who they are, believe them.\"\n\nBoth Mr Lowles and Mr Fenton-Glynn have since retracted their statements.\n\nThe owner of King Vape Store on County Road in Liverpool reviews CCTV footage of looters swarming around his shop and ransacking his stock.\n\nA cafe and a supermarket in south Belfast were badly damaged following unrest in the city on Saturday.\n\nCars were also set on fire as police attempted to deal with disorder in the Donegall Road area, which lasted through the night and into Sunday morning.\n\nThe supermarket's manager, Bashir, said that the Islamic community was being targeted.\n\n\"People attacked this place, racism against Islam and Muslims, especially the Muslim community,\" he said.\n\nHe added: \"All of that happened and the police did nothing, I am telling you the truth.\n\n\"What kind of police are letting the people burn everything down?\"\n\nThere is \"no need\" to bring in the army to deal with unrest in parts of the UK, a Home Office minister has said.\n\nDame Diana Johnson, the policing minister, told BBC News: \"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"As I say, the police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need.\"\n\nAsked about the spread of misinformation online, Dame Diana added: \"Obviously we need to do more because you're absolutely right there has been that spread of misinformation which has caused problems this week.\"\n\nA police leader has condemned the recent rioting and violence against police officers.\n\nTiffany Lynch, from the Police Federation of England and Wales, said on BBC Breakfast: \"It is an abhorrent, senseless act of violence against our police officers, towards our public buildings who are there to serve the community.\n\n\"[These acts are those of] a small minority and it doesn't represent the community of Great Britain. It is absolutely abhorrent.\"\n\nMs Lynch also said that everyday crime fighting would suffer due to police officers being redirected to tackle the riots (see our post at 9.41am).\n\nPolice forces across the UK will struggle to attend everyday crime incidents while officers are redirected to tackle rioting, a police leader told the BBC.\n\nTiffany Lynch, from the Police Federation of England and Wales, said on BBC Breakfast: \"We're seeing officers that are being pulled from day-to-day policing to... go out there and essentially protect our communities.\n\n\"But while that's happening, the communities that are out there that are having incidents against them - victims of crime - unfortunately, their crimes are not being investigated.\n\n\"We're not going to be able to attend all of the incidents that are coming in on the 999s because we're having to direct the priorities of what's happening on the streets.\"\n\nRioters torched Liverpool's new Spellow Hub Library in the Walton area of the city on Saturday.\n\nMerseyside Police said agitators prevented firefighters from putting out the blaze.\n\nPolice forces across the UK arrested more than 90 people in connection with anti-immigration rioting on Saturday.\n\nMerseyside Police said a total of 23 people were arrested, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two in connection with the unrest in Southport.\n\nIn Hull, Humberside Police said they had arrested 20 people.\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre.\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nStaffordshire Police said 10 people were arrested {"uri": "8259986159", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:25:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/keir-starmer-hold-cobra-meeting-33396051", "title": "Keir Starmer to hold Cobra meeting after far-right riots across England", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nKeir Starmer will hold a Cobra emergency response meeting in Downing Street today after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder. The Prime Minister addressed the nation on Sunday and has vowed that the rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face full force of the law\".\n\nMonday's meeting will bring together relevant ministers and police representatives to discuss the response that will follow in the next few days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes. The Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires. At least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later. The force said one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident occurred at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed. People threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\" There were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nThis unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nDame Priti told Times Radio: \"I would not feel safe in some of the areas and communities where we've seen racism and thuggery on our streets. I grew up with people using the P-word against me.\n\n\"And I think some of the individuals that are now involved in this violence, disorder and racism that we are seeing in parts of the country - that's no different to the type of racism that I experienced when I was growing up, and I just think that there's no place for that in our amazing country.\"\n\nThe Tory MP said that claims that there is \"two-tier policing\" in Britain, where right-wing protests are dealt with more harshly than left-wing ones, are \"not correct\".\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nThe former First Minister of Scotland, Humza Yousaf, said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets. Ministers have insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\". In his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence. \"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for whoever took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\nShe said: \"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities. They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification. Writing in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser launched by Stand Up To Racism, which it called an Emergency Unity Fund to \"stop the far right\" raised \u00a37,910 in its first 11 hours.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond. The hotel is believed to have been housing asylum seekers.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police said. The forced added that one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\". Masked men hurled huge pieces of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after around 700 people gathered.\n\nSome of the crowd were heard chanting \"get them out\" as they launched into their attack on the hotel. Now, a new clip taken by the Mirror shows the barrage of attacks faced by police, with objects seen strewn across the road and a large fire lit by protesters. One of the items which appears to have been thrown is a large plank of wood painted with a rainbow and the words: \"Keep safe.\"\n\nDowning Street is expected to hold a Cobra emergency response meeting on Monday after a weekend of escalating disorder also saw intense clashes in Liverpool, Bolton, Belfast, Middlesbrough and Stoke-on-Trent. A fire was lit at a second hotel housing asylum seekers in Tamworth, as projectiles and fireworks were thrown at police.\n\nThe National Police Chiefs' Council said around 150 arrests have been made across England since Saturday evening, with the number expected to rise further. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has vowed that rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and on Sunday promised those involved in unrest would face the full force of the law\n\nHe said: \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests. Individuals will be held on remand. Charges will follow. And convictions will follow.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder. Whether directly or those whipping up this action online, and then running away themselves. This is not protest. It is organised, violent thuggery. And it has no place on our street or online.\"\n\nToday's Cobra meeting is due to involve top ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes. The Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/night-violence-thugs-target-hotels-230113310.html", "title": "Night of violence as thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Night of violence as thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers\n\nGeorge Lithgow, PA\n\n5 August 2024 at 1:01 am\n\nViolence continued into the night on Sunday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nSir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\", and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nAnti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside.\n\nSome 700 people had gathered, the force said.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into the evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 35 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper will appear on news programmes on Monday morning, where she is likely to be asked how the government plans to tackle the continued disorder.", "source": \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser {"uri": "8259492108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:45:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:45:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:44:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/uk/2024/08/05/starmer-calls-emergency-meeting-as-far-right-violence-flares-across-uk/", "title": "Starmer calls emergency meeting as far-right violence flares across UK", "body": "Hundreds of rioters clash with police in Rotherham as hotel housing asylum seekers is attacked and fire started\n\nBritish prime minister Keir Starmer has called an emergency security meeting today in a bid to quell far-right, anti-immigrant violence that has rocked communities across the United Kingdom.\n\nViolence erupted in towns and cities including Rotherham, Blackpool and Bristol over the weekend. The disorder has been fuelled by an online misinformation campaign since an attack a week ago left three young girls dead. The far right falsely accused the suspect of being a Muslim migrant to stoke anti-immigrant and Islamophobic sentiment.\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Mr Starmer described the riots as \"far-right thuggery\" and said those who took part will face \"the full force of the law.\"\n\nThe prime minister will today hold an emergency Cobra meeting with senior ministers and police chiefs, according to a government official.\n\nThe prime minster is preparing emergency court sittings, getting prosecutors to work longer hours and weekends to process cases, and the redeployment of police if necessary.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper announced additional measures to protect the mosques and pledged \"full backing\" for the police in dealing with the unrest. \"Anyone who gets involved in criminal disorder and violent thuggery on our streets will have to pay the price,\" she said in a video posted to X.\n\nIn Rotherham, South Yorkshire, rioters on Sunday attacked a hotel housing asylum seekers and started a fire, injuring around a dozen police officers. Around 150 arrests have been made in England's worst rioting in over a decade.\n\nAbout 700 people gathered outside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, before clashing with police. Some rioters hurled pieces of wood, bottles and chairs, and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers.\n\nSouth Yorkshire police said at least 10 officers had been injured, including one who was left unconscious with a head injury.\n\nFootage from the scene showed a bin on fire and people, some draped in St George and union flags, chanting: \"Get them out.\" The demonstrators appeared at one point to storm into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside, and people peering out of windows.\n\nProtests at the Holiday Inn Express began at midday, immediately turning into a riot when a mob of far-right individuals, mostly men, smashed windows and set a stairwell in the building alight, temporarily overwhelming police.\n\nShabnam Shabir, who came as part of a group of counter-protesters, said she had been left traumatised after her group was surrounded by the mob, who chanted racist words. \"It was a lot of angry, angry, angry far right,\" she said. \"This is very scary.\"\n\nShe was left stranded in her car outside the hotel, unable to leave until the rioters did. \"And we have people inside of the hotel who are scared for their lives so it's terrifying.\"\n\nTensions have been rising since the stabbing attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party in Southport, near Liverpool, on July 29th. Police have said the suspect, Axel Rudakubana (17) was born in Britain in an attempt to counter false claims spread on social media that he was a Muslim migrant.\n\nAround 300 people were involved in disturbances in the Walton area of Liverpool on Saturday night, according to Merseyside Police. The force, also responsible for Southport, said that a local convenience store was set on fire and that a library was damaged, while firefighters who attended to the scene had a missile thrown at their vehicle.\n\nIn Hull, demonstrators gathered outside a hotel that houses asylum seekers, a number of windows were smashed and bottles thrown. In videos uploaded to social media many of the protesters can be heard chanting \"stop the boats,\" a reference to crossings made from the European Continent by migrants attempting to get to Britain.\n\nMany police forces across the country have issued so-called dispersal orders to try to break up and deter rioters. There were also disturbances in Leicester, Stoke-on Trent, Nottingham, Manchester and Middlesbrough, as well as Belfast in Northern Ireland. - Agencies", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "Violence continued into the night on Sunday after \"thugs\" tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nSir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\", and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nAnti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside.\n\nSome 700 people had gathered, the force said.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into the evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 35 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nI guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the It was then they drew their thumb over their throat.\n\nThe footage comes in the wake of rioters attempting to storm the hotel. A total of 10 police officers were injured, while one was knocked unconscious suffering a head injury, police said.\n\nHave protests broken out in your area? Get in touch at webnews@reachplc.com\n\nHotel employees and residents, some of whom are asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", but no injuries were reported, police said. One person has been arrested on suspicion of public order offences.\n\nRioters threw planks of wood at officers and sprayed them with fire extinguishers, before smashing hotel windows to gain access to the Holiday Inn Express, South Yorkshire Police said.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield said: \"Today in Rotherham we have seen our officers attacked and at least 10 injured, significant damage caused and a fire set outside a hotel full of terrified residents and staff.\n\n\"The behaviour we witnessed has been nothing short of disgusting. While it was a smaller number of those in attendance who chose to commit violence and destruction, those who simply stood on and watched remain absolutely complicit in this.\"\n\nMs Butterfield said officers are reviewing \"considerable\" online imagery and that assailants can \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nPrime minister Sir Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" after a sixth day of escalating violence in England as the Government announced emergency security for mosques amid the threat of further disorder. More info\n\nKeir Starmer has warned rioters they will \"regret\" their actions, branding them as \"far-right thuggery\", following a sixth consecutive day of escalating violence across England. The Government has also announced emergency security measures for mosques in response to the threat of further disorder.\n\nIn a national televised address, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and assured that those involved in the unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nAddressing the nation from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that those inciting riots on the streets and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face repercussions.\n\nRead more: Shocking scenes in Middlesbrough in 19 pictures as disorder breaks out when protest turns to violence Keep up to date with all the latest breaking news and top stories from the North East with our free newsletter\n\nIn the meantime, the Home Office has announced that mosques will be provided with enhanced protection under a new \"rapid response process\" aimed at swiftly addressing the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister stated on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir hinted that the response to the violence could reflect elements of how the 2011 riots were managed, during which time he served as director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he added.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nGovernment officials have hinted at the possibility of courts operating round-the-clock to expedite prosecutions a measure previously implemented in 2011 while police forces are prepared to call in additional officers to manage potential disturbances.\n\nThis follows the disturbing scenes witnessed in Rotherham on Sunday, where anti-immigration rioters attacked police and vandalised a hotel's windows. The situation escalated on the sixth day of unrest across England.\n\nMasked individuals were seen hurling pieces of wood and discharging fire extinguishers at officers stationed outside a Holiday Inn Express. Some managed to breach the police line and enter the ground floor of the building, which was subsequently set ablaze.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police later confirmed that at least 10 officers sustained injuries, with one losing consciousness. They also reported one arrest and warned those involved to \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nIn Middlesbrough, another group of rioters damaged residential and vehicle windows and threw objects at police on Sunday afternoon. One individual was heard shouting a racial slur, while another told officers: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThese incidents follow similar outbreaks of disorder in Southport, Belfast, Hartlepool, Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Sunderland and other locations earlier in the week.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper expressed her horror at the intentional arson of a hotel with people inside, branding it \"utterly appalling\" and affirming that the police have full government support to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nIn response to the recent events, the Home Office announced on Sunday a new initiative offering \"rapid security\" measures to mosques, aiming for a swift resumption of worship services.\n\nFollowing the tragic deaths of three young girls in Southport on Monday, unrest has erupted in parts of England and Northern Ireland.\n\nThe far-right elements orchestrating the chaos have faced widespread condemnation. The violence has included hurling bricks at law enforcement, setting community buildings like libraries ablaze, assaulting mosques, and looting retail stores.\n\nMs Cooper stated: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\"\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259978835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:22:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:22:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:21:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/International/uk-police-clash-rioters-wake-deadly-knife-attack/story?id=112564079", "title": "UK police clash with rioters in the wake of deadly knife attack at dance event", "body": "Violence has shaken the U.K. as riots led by far-right groups have gripped multiple cities across the country, leading to nearly 150 arrests, according to officials.\n\nThe disorder spread from Islamophobic and anti-immigrant riots on Saturday called for by far-right groups seeking to exploit the knife attack that killed three young girls at a Taylor Swift-themed dance party on July 29 in the town of Southport, a seaside town about 20 miles north of Liverpool, authorities said.\n\nThe protests that quickly turned violent have been fueled by disinformation circulated online by right-wing commentators falsely claiming the suspect in the stabbing attack was a Muslim illegal immigrant.\n\nSince Friday, the riots have hit most major northern cities, including Liverpool, Manchester, Leeds and Sunderland, but also Bristol in southern England, and Belfast in Northern Ireland, the worst outbreak of public disorder in more than a decade. The U.K.'s Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Sunday condemned the violence as \"far-right thuggery,\" pledging swift prosecution of those involved.\n\nHundreds of extremist demonstrators have attacked police and set fire to mosques and shops, with hundreds of masked individuals rampaging through city centers.\n\nIn the northern English town of Rotherham on Sunday, a mob of hundreds of people attacked a hotel that was housing asylum seekers. The rioters assaulted police protecting the hotel, smashing windows and then trying to set it on fire. At least 10 police officers were injured, South Yorkshire Police said, calling the violence \"deplorable.\"\n\n\"We absolutely condemn the scenes of disorder we witnessed, with a total of around 700 people in attendance,\" the police added.\n\nSeveral small fires were started, but South Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Services \"worked to extinguish these quickly,\" according to officials.\n\nA heavy police presence was expected to stay outside the hotel and the surrounding area for the rest of Sunday evening and into Monday, according to the police.\n\nSouth of Rotherham, another hotel in Tamworth, England, was targeted by rioters. Police in the area urged the public to stay away while they worked on controlling the situation. One officer was injured, the police said Sunday night.\n\n\"We're urging members of the public to avoid the area around the Holiday Inn, Tamworth, as specialist officers continue to deal with violent acts of thuggery,\" Tamworth Police said in an update Sunday evening local time.\n\nOn Saturday, police said they rescued a Black man in Manchester who was being kicked and punched as dozens of men surrounded him. In Sunderland, hundreds of Muslim men gathered to protect a local mosque as groups of individuals targeted the religious building.\n\nPrime Minister Starmer held crisis talks on Saturday with his government discussing measures to shut down the violence.\n\nStarmer released a statement Sunday condemning the violence and vowing to \"do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice.\"\n\n\"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend,\" Starmer said. \"Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law,\" he added.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" Starmer said. \"This is not a protest, it is organized, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\"\n\nStarmer said more arrests would follow and prosecutions would be swift. The government is moving to have courts open 24 hours a day to rapidly process the arrested. The government has also offered increased protection for mosques.\n\nU.K. authorities have accused far-right groups of coordinating the violence. Following the deadly knife attack in Southport, far-right groups and commentators quickly spread false claims on social media, particularly X, that the attacker was a Muslim migrant who crossed illegally on the so-called \"small boats\" from Europe.\n\nHowever, Axel Muganwa Rudakubana, a 17-year-old boy from Banks, a coastal village in Lancashire, just outside Southport, was arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder, police said. {"uri": "8259242638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:45:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:45:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:43:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-i-utterly-condemn-the-far-right-thuggery-uk-pm-keir-starmer-amid-violence-6163848.html", "title": "World News |", "body": "London [UK], August 5 (ANI): Amid the ongoing protest in United Kingdom, Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the protest and stated that 'this is not a protest it is organised violent thuggery.'\n\nViolence broke out in several UK cities on Saturday, following a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance and yoga class for elementary school-aged girls. The incident sparked widespread unrest and riots in multiple cities, which were fueled by far-right groups\n\nAlso Read | Bangladesh Unrest: 76, Including 13 Police Officers Killed As Fresh Protests Rock Nation (See Pics).\n\nhttps://x.com/keir_starmer/status/1820135066711761047?s=46&t=WnjyJyC971ItJhbOMQlj-Q\n\nAfter the incident, Starmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nAlso Read | Nepal Road Accident: Woman Killed, 4 Others Injured As Tractor Carrying Bolbom Festival Pilgrims Returning From India Falls Into Canal in Sarlahi District.\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer further said \"there is no justification\" for the far-right violence, which has led to attacks on mosques and assaults on Muslims.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted. Attacks on mosques. Other minority communities were singled out. Nazi salutes in the street. Attacks on the police.\" Starmer said.\n\nFurther, the prime minister added that \"he won't shy away from calling it [the rioting] what it is\" and that is \"far-right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be,\" he said.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob does not represent our country and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motivation, we make no distinction. Crime is a crime and this government will tackle it,\" he added.\n\nEarlier in the day, far-right demonstrators vandalised a hotel housing asylum seekers in the northern England town of Rotherham, as the United Kingdom grappled with its worst riots in 13 years, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nOn Sunday, hundreds of people gathered at a Holiday Inn Express hotel used to house asylum seekers near Rotherham before throwing bricks at police, breaking several hotel windows, and then setting bins on fire.\n\nThe unrest is the latest bout of rioting in the UK that has gripped the nation, following a stabbing rampage at a dance class last week in the north of England that left three girls dead and several wounded, as per Al Jazeera.\n\nAccording to police officials, false rumours spread online that the young man in the Southport stabbing was a Muslim and an immigrant, fuelling anger among the far-right in the country. {"uri": "8259520326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:11:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:11:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:09:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41450362.html", "title": "UK government to hold emergency meeting after thugs target hotels housing asylum seekers", "body": "British prime ministerKeir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\" and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\" as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nThe UK's home pffice announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our f****** country.\"\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nI guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Mr Starmer's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying the UK parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nStarmer said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters he said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nSara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n\"The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,\" she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, UK home secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,\" she said.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.\"\n\nShe said those responsible would be \"paying the price for years to come\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available resources\".\n\nA fundraiser into the night after demonstrators tried to storm hotels housing asylum seekers on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer vowed rioters would \"regret\" engaging in \"far-right thuggery\", and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nAnti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham before starting fires.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should \"expect us to be at their doors very soon\".\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside.\n\nSome 700 people had gathered, the force said.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into the evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers yesterday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: \"It's our country.\"\n\nThere were 35 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to \"remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance\".\n\nViolence has broken out in several parts of England and Northern Ireland following the killing of three young girls in Southport last week.\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Mr Starmer's leadership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Priti Patel saying parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop \"thugs\" causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources they need to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nMr Starmer said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nSara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right will 'regret' their actions, calls them 'far-right thuggery'", "body": "'If you target a person because of colour of skin, religion this is far-right,' says Keir Starmer over ongoing far-right riots in some UK cities, towns\n\nThe British prime minister on Sunday called the violent rioters \"far-right thuggery,\" warning that those taking part in the violent disorder on the streets would \"regret.\"\n\nIn his address to the nation on the ongoing violent disorder, Keir Starmer said there is \"no doubt\" that those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly, or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" the premier said, adding that \"this is not protest,\" but \"organized violent thuggery.\"\n\nStarmer declared that it has no place on UK streets or online, citing attacks on a hotel in Rotherham in which windows were smashed, the building was set ablaze, and guests and staff were terrified.\n\n\"There is no justification, none for taking this action, and all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence.\"\n\nA large anti-immigrant protest turned violent on Sunday as far-right demonstrators attacked a Rotherham hotel housing asylum seekers, smashing windows and setting the building on fire.\n\nThe incident took place just before midday and was marked by far-right demonstrators' intense clashes with police and counter-protesters.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe and yet we have seen Muslim communities targeted and attacks on mosques... So, I won't shy away from calling it what it is, far-right thuggery,\" said Starmer.\n\nHe added: \"If you target a person because of the color of skin, religion this is far-right.\"\n\nEarlier, authorities reported at least 100 arrests following the eruption of violence, not only in Rotherham but across the UK, with more demonstrations planned for later on Sunday.\n\nSimilar protests are expected in Bolton, Lancaster, Middlesborough, Weymouth, and Newcastle upon Tyne.\n\nMasked rioters, some draped in England flags, gathered outside the hotel, which is known to house migrants.\n\nLocal authorities are on high alert, anticipating more violent protests across the country on Sunday.\n\nThe unrest follows the tragic killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday, {"uri": "8258883652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:46:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:46:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:45:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/24496781.pm-vows-rioters-will-regret-taking-part-far-right-thuggery/", "title": "PM condemns 'far right thuggery' and vows rioters will be swiftly brought to justice", "body": "In a televised address to the nation, the Prime Minister condemned an attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and promised those involved in unrest would \"face the full force of the law\".\n\nSpeaking from Downing Street, Sir Keir suggested that rioters taking to the streets, and those \"whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" would face consequences.\n\nMeanwhile, the Home Office announced mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques,\" the Prime Minister said on Sunday.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests, charge remanded in custody and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nMinisters have suggested that courts could sit 24 hours to fast-track prosecutions while police forces have measures in place to draft in extra officers to tackle potential unrest.\n\nIt comes as anti-immigration rioters attacked police and smashed the windows of a hotel in Rotherham on the fifth day of unrest in England.\n\nMasked men launched lengths of wood and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside a Holiday Inn Express and some stormed into the hotel, with reports of a fire inside.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper said the deliberate torching of a hotel where people were known to be inside was \"utterly appalling\" and South Yorkshire Police have Government backing to take \"the strongest action\".\n\nThe Home Office, on Sunday, offered mosques greater protections as part of a new process, under which it said \"rapid security\" deployment can be requested in order to allow a return to worship as fast as possible.\n\nMs Cooper said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"", "source": {"uri": "heraldscotland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The
