{"uri": "8259894796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:29:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:29:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:28:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://easternmirrornagaland.com/pm-keir-starmer-calls-emergency-meeting-over-far-right-thuggery-on-uk-streets/", "title": "PM Keir Starmer Calls Emergency Meeting Over 'far-right Thuggery' On UK Streets - Eastern Mirror", "body": "LONDON -- British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has called an emergency COBRA meeting of senior ministers and police chiefs at 10 Downing Street here on Monday after a weekend of riots across several cities in the country, which he termed a \"far-right thuggery\" that will face the full force of the law.\n\nHundreds of arrests have been made as police officers in riot gear responded to violent scenes in Rotherham, Middlesbrough, Bolton and other parts of the UK on Sunday, after days of some of the worst rioting seen on the streets of the country in the wake of the fatal stabbings of three schoolgirls in Southport, north-west England.\n\nHotels housing asylum seekers and mosques have been among the targets of the anti-immigrant mobs after initial false claims spread online regarding the stabbing suspect being an immigrant who arrived in the country illegally.\n\n\"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law,\" said Starmer in a statement on Sunday.\n\n\"There is no justification - none - for taking this action, and all right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe and yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques, other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, (and) wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric. So, no, I won't shy away from calling this what it is: far-right thuggery,\" he said.\n\nUK police question teenage suspect after 2 children killed, 9 injured in stabbing\n\nHe will chair the emergency Cabinet Office Briefing Room A (COBRA) meeting with UK Home Secretary Yvette Cooper to discuss the future course of action to curb the violence. The Home Office has also announced that mosques will be offered greater protection with new \"emergency security\" that can be rapidly deployed to respond to violent disorder targeting places of worship.\n\n\"They do not speak for our communities. It's a total disgrace, and there has to be a reckoning. Those individuals who are involved in the disorder need to know that they will pay a price,\" said Cooper, as she indicated that additional prosecutors and courts are on standby to charge those being arrested for a series of offences.\n\n\"We have made very clear to the police that they have our full support in pursuing the full range of prosecutions and penalties, including the serious prison sentences, long-term tagging, travel bans and more,\" she said.\n\nDuring clashes over the weekend, cars were set alight, windows smashed, large bins burnt and hurled at officers and stores looted. Masked anti-immigration mobs broke into a hotel housing asylum-seekers in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, and rocks and long pieces of wood were thrown at police officers who lined up in front of the building as they tried to protect it.\n\n\"The mindless actions of those today have achieved nothing other than sheer destruction and leaving members of the public and the wider community in fear,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield of South Yorkshire Police.\n\nSeveral police officers have suffered injuries as they faced off with the mobs, who are being fuelled by misinformation being spread online. The riots started in Southport, near Liverpool, last week following the stabbing of a group of young children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on July 29.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, 17, who has been charged with three murders and other attempted murders, was born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents. However, initial misinformed social media posts claimed he was a refugee who arrived last year on a small boat. Southport residents, including the mother of one of the girls who died, have called for the protesters to stop and that they do not speak for them.", "source": {"uri": "easternmirrornagaland.com", CNN geolocated footage shows demonstrators attacking and burning two Holiday Inns in northern England on Sunday: one in Rotherham and one in Tamworth, which had previously been criticised by a local lawmaker for hosting asylum seekers.\n\nLocal officials said that demonstrators in Tamworth injured one police officer by throwing projectiles, smashing windows, and starting fires.\n\nMeanwhile, police in Rotherham reported that demonstrators broke windows, flung wooden planks, attacked policemen with fire extinguishers and set fire to other objects in an attempt to enter the premises.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield said in a statement that the hotel in Rotherham was at the time \"full of terrified residents and staff,\" according to CNN.\n\nThe UK's minister of police has stated that far-right rioters who have caused disturbances will be dealt with \"nick them quick,\" but he has also stated that the army is not necessary.\n\nJust weeks after taking office, Keir Starmer's Labour government faces a formidable battle from the violent upheaval, which is the worst since the 2011 riots.\n\nIn reaction to recent attacks, the UK Home Office declared on Sunday that mosques would receive \"greater protection with new emergency security\" in the country.\n\nUnder the new arrangements, \"the police, local authorities and mosques can ask for rapid security to be deployed, protecting communities and allowing for a return to worship as quickly as possible,\" the Home Office said, according to CNN.\n\nStarmer shared a post on X and wrote, \"I utterly condemn the far-right thuggery we have seen this weekend. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow. I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" said the UK PM.\n\n\"This is not a protest. It is organised violent thuggery. And it has no place on our streets or online. Right now, there are attacks happening on a hotel in Rotherham. Marauding gangs intent on law-breaking. Or worse, windows smashed. Fire set ablaze,\" he added. The stabbing deaths of three young girls in Southport, northwest England, earlier this week catalyzed the violence, according to CNN.\n\nTo incite anti-Muslim and anti-immigration demonstrations, the far right has exploited and disseminated a surge of misinformation, including unfounded allegations that the assailant was an immigrant.\n\nAlso Read | North Korea's Kim Jong Un Unveils 250 New Tactical Ballistic Missile Launchers.\n\nThe suspect was born in Britain, according to police. Be in no doubt: those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law.\"\n\nIn his video message on X, he issued a stern warning to those involved in the recent violence and riots and emphasized that the full force of the law would be brought to bear on individuals who participated in the violence, whether directly or indirectly.\n\n\"Be in no doubt, those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. {"uri": "8259124003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:43:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:43:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/uk-going-through-its-worst-wave-of-riots-in-13-years/3295065", "title": "UK going through its worst wave of riots in 13 years", "body": "The UK is going through its worst wave of riots in 13 years, with far-right demonstrators targeting asylum seekers and ethnic minority communities across the country.\n\nA storm of anti-Muslim disinformation on social media has fueled Islamophobic and far-right violence in the aftermath of the fatal stabbing attack in the northern English seaside town of Southport on July 29.\n\nFalse reports spread by extremist far-right social media accounts claimed the suspect was a Muslim and a migrant, which were echoed in the mob's Islamophobic vitriolic chants.\n\nPolice have so far said the suspect is a 17-year-old man who was born in Cardiff, the capital of Wales, and lived in a village near Southport.\n\nJuly 29: In the seaside town of Southport, northwest England, three girls aged six, seven, and nine are fatally stabbed.\n\nJuly 30: Riots erupt in Southport overnight. A mob of up to 300 people, including members of the English Defense League - an anti-Muslim far-right group, targets a mosque in the town, attacks police, torches cars and destroys properties, leaving at least 50 officers injured. Merseyside Police arrest four people.\n\nJuly 31: The disorder spreads to Newton Heath, in north Manchester. Rioters target a Holiday Inn hotel that is believed to house asylum seekers, throwing missiles at police and attacking a bus driver. In Hartlepool, over 100 people clash with police, with some shouting anti-Islamic slurs. Violent scenes also unfold outside Downing Street in London, with rioters attacking police and throwing flares, resulting in over 100 arrests. A mob of about 200 people gathers outside a hotel in Aldershot that houses asylum seekers.\n\nAug. 2: Sunderland witnesses a lengthy riot in its city center. A car and a Citizens Advice Bureau are set ablaze, injuring several police officers.\n\nAug. 3: Far-right rallies spread to more cities across England and Belfast, Northern Ireland, resulting in over 100 arrests.\n\nAug. 4: The violence continues to escalate. In the northern town of Rotherham, hundreds of far-right demonstrators vandalize a Holiday Inn Express housing asylum seekers. Protesters throw bricks at police, break hotel windows, and set bins on fire. Assistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield of South Yorkshire Police condemns both the rioters and those who spread misinformation online. At least 10 officers have been injured, including one who has been left unconscious.\n\nIn addition to the chaos in Rotherham, protests break out in Bolton, Greater Manchester, Middlesbrough, and other towns.\n\nIn Bolton, police issue a dispersal order as several hundred demonstrators and counter-demonstrators clash, throwing missiles and escalating tensions. In Middlesbrough, 300 protesters break through a police line in the city center, hurling projectiles and vandalizing cars, police vans, and buildings.\n\nThe National Police Chiefs' Council announces the deployment of 4,000 extra officers across the country to handle the widespread disorder.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemns the targeting of Muslim and other ethnic minority communities, including attacks on mosques, and decries \"wanton violence\" by people displaying Nazi salutes.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police release a statement strongly condemning the violent acts in Rotherham.\n\n\"Those who simply stood on and watched the rioting were absolutely complicit in this,\" says Assistant Chief Constable Butterfield. The police emphasize that people who spread hate and misinformation online must take responsibility for inciting violence.\n\nAs the UK grapples with these violent demonstrations, more than 140 people have been arrested since Saturday night. The situation remains volatile, with authorities on high alert to prevent further outbreaks of violence.", "source": {"uri": "aa.com.tr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anadolu Ajans\u0131"}, Hundreds of far-right protesters squared up to police shields at Middlesbrough's Cenotaph, throwing bricks cans and pots at officers as a Holiday Inn housing asylum seekers was stormed by crowds.\n\nREAD MORE Bottles and 'missiles' thrown as police given extra powers to calm town centre violence\n\nIn Bolton, bottles and 'missiles' were thrown at cops who descended on the town centre to manage an ongoing protest, with a dispersal order later put in place by police.\n\nIt followed further unrest on Saturday (August 3) in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast, which saw several police officers injured.\n\nAt an emergency press conference on Sunday, Sir Keir condemned the disorder as 'far-right violence'.\n\nHe told reporters: \"If you target people because of the colour of their skin or their faith then that is far-right and I'm prepared to say so. This is violence. It is not protest. It doesn't matter what the motivation is.\n\n\"The motivation for the vast majority of people in this country is to see their streets safe - and that is what I am determined we will deliver.\n\n\"I think there needs to be the full force of the law and it needs to be swift. What happened in 2011 was that we were able to see individuals who took part in violence arrested, charged, remanded and convicted very swiftly.\n\n\"Standing arrangements are in place for that and we will do whatever it takes to ensure that the message is absolutely clear - that if you are taking part in this violence you will regret it and you will be brought to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nHe said those participating in violence, including those 'whipping up this action online', would 'regret' it.\n\nAddressing the nation, Sir Keir added: \"Be in no doubt, those that have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests. Individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves. This is not a protest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\n\n\"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this assault of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe. To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country, and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Daily Trust", "body": "UK leader Keir Starmer is due to hold an emergency response meeting on Monday after more far-right riots broke out across England over the murder of three children last week.\n\nThe prime minister will chair a meeting bringing together ministers and the police to discuss how to quell the violence that first broke out in Southport, northwest England, on Tuesday.\n\nPolice have arrested hundreds of people in towns and cities nationwide, with anti-immigration demonstrators and rioters facing off against police and counter-protestors, including groups of Muslims.\n\nThe unrest follows last Monday's tragedy in Southport in which three young girls were killed and five more children critically injured during a knife attack as they attended a Taylor Swift-themed dance class.\n\nStarmer on Sunday warned rioters they would \"regret\" participating in England's worst disorder in 13 years, while his interior minister Yvette Cooper told the BBC on Monday that \"there will be a reckoning\".\n\nPolice have blamed the violence on supporters and associated organisations of the English Defence League, an anti-Islam organisation founded 15 years ago whose supporters have been linked to football hooliganism.\n\nSome of the worst scenes on Sunday broke out in Rotherham, northern England, where masked rioters smashed several windows at a hotel that has been used to house asylum seekers.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, said South Yorkshire Police.\n\nThere were also large scuffles in Bolton, northwest England, and Middlesbrough, northeast England, where mobs smashed windows of houses and cars, leading to 43 arrests.\n\nProtesters there seized a camera from an AFP crew and broke it. The journalists were not injured.\n\nLate Sunday, Staffordshire police said another hotel known to have sheltered asylum seekers was targeted near Birmingham.\n\n\"A large group of individuals\" have been \"throwing projectiles, smashing windows, starting fires and targeting police\" at the hotel in the town of Tamworth, with one officer injured, said the statement.\n\nShops looted, burnt\n\nThe violence is a major challenge for Starmer, elected only a month ago after leading Labour to a landslide win over the Conservatives.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder. Whether directly or those whipping up this action online, and then running away themselves,\" Starmer said on Sunday.\n\nThere was \"no justification\" for what he called \"far-right thuggery\", promising to bring the perpetrators \"to justice\".\n\nMPs from all sides have urged Starmer to recall parliament from its summer holiday, including Conservative former interior minister Priti Patel, Labour MPs Diane Abbott and Dawn Butler, and Reform UK leader Nigel Farage.\n\nPolice have said more than 150 people were arrested over the weekend.\n\nRioters threw bricks, bottles and flares at police - injuring several officers - and looted and burnt shops, while demonstrators shouted anti-Islamic slurs as they clashed with counter-protesters.\n\nThe violence is the worst England has seen The protests reached a climax during the weekend.\n\nNational Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order, BJ Harrington, said on Sunday that since Saturday night, there have been 147 arrests connected to violence. He said he expected that the number would rise in the coming days.\n\n\"Disinformation is a huge driver of this appalling violence, and we know a lot of those attending these so-called protests are doing so in direct response to what they've read online,\" Harrington said.\n\nFollowing violent protests in major cities including London, Manchester, Liverpool, Bristol, Leeds, Nottingham, Sunderland and Belfast on Saturday, riots were seen in places such as Middlesbrough, where burning wheelie bins were thrown at police, and Rotherham, where at least one police officer was injured as rioters hurled missiles and stormed a Holiday Inn Express thought to have housed migrants. In Bolton, police have been given extra powers to calm violence after bottles and missiles were thrown at them.\n\nReferring to the violent attack on the Rotherham hotel, Starmer said: \"There is no justification for taking this action.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister said he would not \"shy away from calling it what it is\" and called the violence \"far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a press conference on Friday, Starmer urged big social media companies to take responsibility for combatting misinformation and disinformation.\n\nFormer UK Prime Minister and leader of the opposition Conservative Party, Rishi Sunak said the unrest across the country is \"violent, criminal behaviour that has no place in our society.\"\n\n\"The shocking scenes we're seeing on the streets of Britain have nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport,\" Sunak said on X, adding that the police have \"our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly.\"\n\nHumza Yousaf, former first minister of Scotland, said on X Far-right groups have exploited the situation, spreading false claims that the suspect was an immigrant and radical Islamist. However, police have clarified that the suspect was born in Britain and are not treating the incident as terrorism.\n\nIn Rotherham, South Yorkshire, masked anti-immigration demonstrators vandalized a hotel used to house asylum seekers. The protests have spread to cities including Liverpool, Bristol, and Manchester, resulting in numerous arrests, vandalism, looting, and injuries to several police officers. On Sunday, hundreds of anti-immigration protesters assembled near another hotel in Rotherham, which the UK's interior minister confirmed was housing asylum seekers.\n\nREAD MORE: Torrential Downpours Devastate Pakistan, Result In 22 Deaths\n\nIn a TV address, Keir Starmer stated, \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder. Whether directly or those whipping up this action online, and then running away themselves.\" He emphasized that there was \"no justification\" for what he described as \"far-right thuggery\" and vowed to bring the perpetrators \"to justice.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister has convened an emergency security meeting to address the escalating anti-immigrant protests.\n\nBBC footage revealed rioters breaking into a Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham and pushing a burning bin into the building. It remains unclear whether asylum seekers were present inside, according to AFP. Although ten police officers were injured, local authorities confirmed that no hotel staff or guests were harmed.\n\nIn Middlesbrough, hundreds of protesters confronted riot police with shields, hurling bricks, cans, and pots. Protesters also seized and damaged a camera belonging to an AFP crew, though the journalists were unharmed.\n\nThis outbreak of violence is the most severe England has experienced since the summer of 2011, when riots erupted following the police shooting of a mixed-race man in north London. stabbing, AFP\n\nUK leader Keir Starmer is due to hold an emergency response meeting on Monday after more far-right riots broke out across England over the murder of three children last week.\n\nThe Prime Minister will chair a meeting bringing together ministers and the police to discuss how to quell the violence that first broke out in Southport, northwest England.\n\nPolice have arrested hundreds of people in towns and cities nationwide, with anti-immigration demonstrators and rioters facing off against police and counter-protesters,.\n\nThe unrest follows last Monday's tragedy in Southport in which three young girls were killed and five more children critically injured during a knife attack as they attended a Taylor Swift-themed dance class.\n\nStarmer on Sunday warned rioters they would \"regret\" participating in England's worst disorder in 13 years, while his interior minister Yvette Cooper told the BBC on Monday that \"there will be a reckoning\".\n\nPolice have blamed the violence on supporters and associated organisations of the English Defence League, an organisation founded 15 years ago whose supporters have been linked to football hooliganism.\n\nSome of the worst scenes on Sunday broke out in Rotherham, northern England, where masked rioters smashed several windows at a hotel that has been used to house asylum seekers.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured, including one who was knocked unconscious, said South Yorkshire Police.\n\nThere were also large scuffles in Bolton, north west England, and Middlesbrough, north east England, where mobs smashed windows of houses and cars, leading to 43 arrests.\n\nProtesters there seized a camera from an AFP crew and broke it. The journalists were not injured.\n\nLate Sunday, Staffordshire police said another hotel known to have sheltered asylum seekers was targeted near Birmingham.\n\n\"A large group of individuals\" have "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/news/national/uk-today/24496965.cobra-meeting-planned-response-weekend-riots/", "title": "Government plan emergency Cobra meeting in response to escalating riots", "body": "Police responded to violent scenes in Rotherham, Middlesbrough, Bolton and other parts of the UK on Sunday (August 4).\n\nHotels that were believed to be housing asylum seekers in Rotherham and Tamworth were targeted, with windows smashed and fires started.\n\nMore than 150 people were arrested across the UK with some police officers injured and property damage caused.\n\nIt was part of a sixth day of disorder following the killing of three young girls in Southport on Monday (July 29).\n\nMonday's meeting is due to involve relevant ministers and police representatives who will discuss the response in the coming days to ensure there is no repeat of the violent scenes.\n\nCobra meetings, or Cobr meetings as they are often also called, are named after Cabinet Office Briefing Room A on Whitehall, BBC News reports.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer gave a televised address on Sunday and warned those involved that they would \" regret\" taking part.\n\nHe added: \"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nSir Keir indicated that the response to the violence could mirror elements of how the 2011 riots were handled, at which time he was the director of public prosecutions.\n\n\"We do have standing arrangements for law enforcement which means that we can get arrests... and convictions done very quickly,\" he said.\n\n\"I myself was part of that in 2011 when I was director of public prosecutions, and I'm determined we will do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible.\"\n\nThe Home Office also announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new \"rapid response process\" designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nRecommended reading:\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said \"there will be reckoning\" for people who took part in the unrest and those who \"whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums\".\n\nShadow minister for security Tom Tugendhat, a candidate for the leadership of the Conservatives, described the violence as \"abhorrent acts\" with no justification.\n\nWriting in the Daily Express, he called on the Government to \"get a grip\" by offering police \"all available {"uri": "8259911799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:39:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:39:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:38:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://news.abplive.com/news/world/uk-to-hold-emergency-response-meeting-amid-anti-immigration-violence-1708150", "title": "UK To Hold Emergency Response Meeting Amid Anti-Immigration Violence", "body": "The meeting has been called as recent riots are some of the worst clashes that the UK.Source : X/@Target_Reporter\n\nThe Keir Starmer government in the UK will hold an emergency response meeting on Monday on the anti-immigration violence under way in parts of England (Rotherham, Middlesbrough and Bolton) and Northern Ireland. The protests began after last month's attack on a children's dance class where three young girls were stabbed to death. The identity of the minor attacker has not been revealed.\n\nSo far, more than 150 people have been arrested in connection with the violence, the BBC reported. According to the report, Starmer has condemned the attack this weekend on a Rotherham hotel housing asylum seekers. He said those involved in the clashes would face \"the full force of the law\", describing the violence as \"far-right thuggery\".\n\nEmergency response meetings in the UK are referred to as 'Cobra' or COBR meetings after the Cabinet Office Briefing Room A on Whitehall. \"It is an emergency response committee -- a get together of ministers, civil servants, the police, intelligence officers and other officials appropriate to the situation they are looking into,\" BBC reported.\n\nMonday's meeting, BBC reported, will be intended to provide the government with an update on the violence over the weekend and the response in the coming days. The meeting has been called as the riots are some of the worst clashes that the UK has witnessed in recent years.\n\nDuring a televised address on Sunday, the prime minister said people \"in this country have a right to be safe\". \"And yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques. Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery,\" he added.\n\nAt least 10 police officers were injured during the clashes in Rotherham this weekend, with one left unconscious after anti-immigrant demonstrators threw planks of wood at police and sprayed them with fire extinguishers.\n\nSome members of the 700-large group smashed windows to gain access to a Holiday Inn Express and a large trash bin was set alight. The officer who was knocked unconscious suffered a head injury, and at least two others are suspected to have suffered broken bones, the force said, according to BBC.\n\nHotel employees and residents, including asylum seekers, were \"terrified\", although no one is said to have been injured.", "source": {"uri": "news.abplive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "english"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-08-443997867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:31:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:31:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/world/antiimmigration-protests-rage-in-uk-hotels-shops-torched-in-worst-riots-in-13-years-top-10-highlights-11722822563319.html", "title": "Anti-immigration protests rage in UK; hotels, shops torched in worst riots in 13 years | Top 10 highlights | Today News", "body": "The UK is experiencing widespread unrest, with violent anti-immigration protests erupting in various cities, including Birmingham, Rotherham, and Middlesbrough.\n\nBirmingham witnessed significant violence as part of a broader wave of unrest sweeping across the UK, according to media reports. This upheaval is linked to anti-immigration protests, exacerbated by misinformation and heightened tensions.\n\nUK Prime Minister Keir Starmer addressed the nation with a stern warning to far-right protesters, asserting they would \"regret\" their participation in the disturbances. Starmer emphasised there is \"no justification\" for the violent actions, which he condemned as \"far-right thuggery.\" He promised that those responsible would be brought to justice.\n\nIn Rotherham, South Yorkshire, masked demonstrators attacked a hotel housing asylum seekers. The attackers smashed windows and set fires, causing significant damage. Although ten police officers were injured during the clashes, there were no reports of injuries to hotel staff or residents.\n\nThe violence has spread across multiple towns and cities, fueled by misinformation regarding a mass stabbing in Southport last Monday.\n\nThe incident, which occurred at a children's dance class, led to the deaths of three young girls. False rumours on social media suggested the suspect was a radical Islamist migrant, although police confirmed the suspect was British-born.\n\nIn Middlesbrough, protesters clashed with riot police, leading to injuries among officers and considerable property damage.\n\nProtesters threw bricks, cans, and other objects at the police, escalating the violence.\n\nSince Saturday, more than 150 arrests have been made following violent far-right rallies in cities including Liverpool, Manchester, and Bristol. Rioters have looted shops, set fires, and hurled bricks and flares at police, resulting in substantial property damage and numerous injuries.\n\nIn response to the unrest, Christian, Muslim, and Jewish leaders in Liverpool issued a joint appeal for peace, urging communities to remain calm and united.\n\nThe government has been quick to respond, with Interior Minister Yvette Cooper and Prime Minister Keir Starmer both condemning the violence. ExBulletin", "body": "Britain's prime minister has labelled those who staged violent riots on Sunday \"far-right thugs\" and warned those who take part in violent chaos on the streets \"will regret it\".\n\nKeir Starmer has said there is \"no doubt\" those involved in the violence will face the full force of the law in a national address to the nation about the ongoing violence.\n\n\"Whether you take part in this chaos yourself, or encourage it online and then walk away, you will regret it,\" the prime minister said, adding: \"This is not a protest, this is an act of organised violence.\"\n\nCiting incidents at a Rotherham hotel where windows were smashed, the building was set ablaze and guests and staff were terrified, Starmer declared such behaviour had no place on Britain's streets or online.\n\n\"There is absolutely no justification for taking such actions, and all decent people should condemn this kind of violence.\"\n\nOn Sunday, a large anti-immigrant protest turned violent, with far-right protesters attacking a Rotherham hotel housing refugees, smashing windows and setting fire to the building.\n\nThe incident took place just before noon and was recorded as violent clashes between far-right protesters, police and counter-protesters.\n\n\"The people of this country have the right to be safe, but we have seen Muslim communities being targeted, mosques being attacked... so I wouldn't shy away from calling it far-right violence,\" Starmer said.\n\n\"If you're targeting people because of their skin color or their religion, that's far right,\" he added.\n\n'The violent attack on the refugee camp is absolutely horrific'\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper has condemned the mob that targeted a hotel housing refugees in Rotherham as an \"absolutely appalling\" incident.\n\n\"The deliberate setting of a fire to a building with people known to be inside. The police have our full support to deal with these criminals quickly and they must face the full weight of the law,\" he added.\n\nAuthorities earlier reported at least 100 people had been arrested as violence erupted across the UK, not just in Rotherham, with more protests planned for later on Sunday.\n\nSimilar protests are expected in Bolton, Lancaster, Middlesborough, Weymouth and Newcastle upon Tyne.\n\nA masked mob, including several waving British flags, gathered outside a hotel known to be housing immigrants.\n\nLocal authorities are on high alert, expecting more violent protests across the country on Sunday.\n\nThe riots follow the tragic murder of three young girls in Southport on Monday, an incident that has further strained community relations and sparked further unrest in several cities across the UK.\n\nThe Anadolu Agency website contains only a summary of some of the news articles provided to subscribers by the AA News Broadcasting System (HAS). {"uri": "2024-08-444100194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:35:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:35:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:22:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/uk-pm-condemns-far-right-thuggery-as-riots-continue-across-country/", "title": "UK PM condemns 'far-right thuggery' as riots continue across country", "body": "London, Aug 5 (VOICE) The United Kingdom (UK) Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned \"far-right thuggery\" in his televised address as riots continue across the country following the deadly knife attack in Southport.\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, either directly or those whipping up this disorder online,\" Starmer said on Sunday.\n\nThree children died, and multiple others were injured after the attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop in Southport last Monday, reports news agency.\n\nA 17-year-old boy named Axel Rudakubana, born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents has been charged with murder.\n\nHowever, disinformation spreading online about the nationality of the boy and his religious affiliation has fueled hatred towards Muslims and the immigrant population in general, leading to violent clashes between far-right protesters and police officers across the UK. The protests reached a climax during the weekend.\n\nNational Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order, BJ Harrington, said on Sunday that since Saturday night, there have been 147 arrests connected to violence. He said he expected that the number would rise in the coming days.\n\n\"Disinformation is a huge driver of this appalling violence, and we know a lot of those attending these so-called protests are doing so in direct response to what they've read online,\" Harrington said.\n\nFollowing violent protests in major cities including London, Manchester, Liverpool, Bristol, Leeds, Nottingham, Sunderland and Belfast on Saturday, riots were seen in places such as Middlesbrough, where burning wheelie bins were thrown at police, and Rotherham, where at least one police officer was injured as rioters hurled missiles and stormed a Holiday Inn Express thought to have housed migrants. In Bolton, police have been given extra powers to calm violence after bottles and missiles were thrown at them.\n\nReferring to the violent attack on the Rotherham hotel, Starmer said: \"There is no justification for taking this action.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister said he would not \"shy away from calling it what it is\" and called the violence \"far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a press conference on Friday, Starmer urged big social media companies to take responsibility for combatting misinformation and disinformation.\n\nFormer UK Prime Minister and leader of the opposition Conservative Party, Rishi Sunak said the unrest across the country is \"violent, criminal behaviour that has no place in our society.\"\n\n\"The shocking scenes we're seeing on the streets of Britain have nothing to do {"uri": "8259124489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:47:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:47:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:43:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://english.news.cn/20240805/f4de4786b5d94631a4e0a9d78505bf5a/c.html", "title": "Roundup: UK PM condemns \"far-right thuggery\" as riots continue across country", "body": "LONDON, Aug. 4 (Xinhua) -- The United Kingdom (UK) Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Sunday condemned \"far-right thuggery\" in his televised address as riots continue across the country following the deadly knife attack in Southport.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, either directly or those whipping up this disorder online,\" Starmer said.\n\nThree children died and multiple others were injured after the attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance workshop in Southport on Monday. A 17-year-old boy named Axel Rudakubana born in Cardiff to Rwandan parents has been charged with murder.\n\nHowever, disinformation spreading online about the nationality of the boy and his religious affiliation has fueled hatred towards Muslims and the immigrant population in general, leading to violent clashes between far-right protesters and police officers across the UK. The protests reached a climax during the weekend.\n\nNational Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order BJ Harrington said on Sunday that since Saturday night there have been 147 arrests connected to violence. He said he expected that number to rise in the coming days.\n\n\"Disinformation is a huge driver of this appalling violence and we know a lot of those attending these so-called protests are doing so in direct response to what they've read online,\" Harrington said.\n\nFollowing violent protests in major cities including London, Manchester, Liverpool, Bristol, Leeds, Nottingham, Sunderland and Belfast on Saturday, riots were seen in places such as Middlesbrough where burning wheelie bins were thrown at police, and Rotherham where at least one police officer was injured as rioters hurled missiles and stormed a Holiday Inn Express thought to have housed migrants. In Bolton, police have been given extra powers to calm violence after bottles and missiles were thrown at them.\n\nReferring to the violent attack on the said Rotherham hotel, Starmer said: \"There is no justification for taking this action.\"\n\nThe prime minister said he would not \"shy away from calling it what it is\" and called the violence \"far-right thuggery.\"\n\nIn a press conference on Friday, Starmer urged big social media companies to take responsibility in combatting misinformation and disinformation.\n\nUK's former Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, leader of the opposition Conservative Party, said the unrest across the country is \"violent, criminal behavior that has no place in our society.\"\n\n\"The shocking scenes we're seeing on the streets of Britain have nothing to do with the tragedy in Southport,\" Sunak said on X, adding that the police have \"our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly.\"\n\nHumza Yousaf, former first minister of Scotland, said "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/guarantee-regret-taking-part-starmer-201239340.html", "title": "I guarantee you will regret taking part, Starmer tells rioters", "body": "I guarantee you will regret taking part, Starmer tells rioters\n\nDaniel Hardaker\n\n4 August 2024 at 10:12 pm\n\nSir Keir Starmer has told rioters they will regret taking part in disorder as unrest continued for a fifth day.\n\nIn an emergency address from Downing Street, the Prime Minister said that he would do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible\" amid violence that has spread since the Southport killings.\n\nSir Keir confirmed rioters will be held on remand, jailing them immediately after arrest.\n\n\"Charges will follow and convictions will follow,\" he added.\n\nThe move mirrors action taken following the 2011 riots when Sir Keir was Director of Public Prosecutions.\n\nHis remarks came as the Home Office announced that security is being stepped up around Britain's mosques in light of the rioting.\n\n08:43 PM BST\n\nWatch: Protest outside Holiday Inn in Tamworth\n\nProtesters are gathering outside a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, that houses asylum seekers.\n\nVideos posted on social media show dozens of demonstrators confronting riot-shield equipped police outside the building, with at least one police dog seen close to the main entrance.\n\nOther footage shows rioters breaking the hotel's windows by throwing objects at them.\n\n08:05 PM BST\n\nRioters start bonfire and throw bins at police near Rotherham migrant hotel\n\nRioters have now started a bonfire in the middle of the road 500 metres from the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham and are throwing bins at police officers, Neil Johnston reports from the scene.\n\nPolice earlier dispersed rioters outside the hotel, but the agitators have since clashed with officers at a location farther down the road.\n\nDozens more riot police have arrived to stop a fresh assault on the hotel, where migrants are watching from the windows.\n\nThe mob threw a barrage of fences and fireworks at police, and spooked some of the force's horses.\n\nOfficers with riot-shields were seen lining up to face the crowd as a fire blazes in the background.\n\n07:38 PM BST\n\nAsylum seekers describe experience of Rotherham hotel attack\n\nBy Neil Johnston\n\nA group of men inside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham said they had fled war zones and other hostile countries but did not expect to see violence in the UK which they thought was a \"safe country\".\n\nA man speaking on behalf of several asylum seekers including Kurds, Afghans and Iranians told The Telegraph he heard screams as rioters broke in and fire alarms went off.\n\n\"We were told to stay in our rooms, the staff locked the hotel,\" he said.\n\n\"We then heard them breaking in. We could hear the breaking of mirrors, glass and doors. It was terrible. We only knew the fire had started when the fire alarms went off.\n\n\"It was so terrible for us and this is the first experience we've had like this.\n\n\"These people in here are from all different countries. They are Arabic, Kurdish, Afghanistan, from Iran.\n\n\"We thought we had finally got a safe life here. We saw them running from one side to another. We could not move from our rooms. We were worried, we thought some people would come into the hotel and fight with us.\"\n\nHe said that they were terrified what would happen if they made it beyond the ground floor.\n\n\"We were really scared of these people. We did think we could die.\n\n07:31 PM BST\n\n10 police officers injured in Rotherham hotel violence\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police has said that 10 officers were injured in the \"deplorable acts of violence\" at the Holiday Inn Express Hotel in Manvers, Rotherham earlier today.\n\nOne officer was left unconscious after a head injury, the force said, with other officers suffering suspected broken bones.\n\nThere have so far been no reports of injuries to hotel staff or residents.\n\nPolice said around 700 people had taken part in the disorder outside the hotel on Sunday.\n\n07:23 PM BST\n\nWatch: Mob attacks man in street in Middlesbrough\n\nA Channel 4 news correspondent has shared footage of what appears to be a group of Asian men attacking a lone white male on the streets of Middlesbrough.\n\nPolice are reportedly playing a game of \"cat and mouse\" as groups of Asian and white men roam the streets looking for trouble.\n\nCleveland Police earlier said nine people had been arrested in connection with the disturbances in Middlesbrough.\n\n06:53 PM BST\n\nPictured: Police try to hold back protesters on Weymouth beaches\n\nAn anti-immigration protest called 'Enough is Enough' is underway in Weymouth, where the BBC reports that 400 protesters from opposing sides are gathered on the seafront chanting at each other.\n\nThe broadcaster said that police officers have moved people off the beach because some anti-immigrant protesters had pushed through the police line.\n\n06:45 PM BST\n\nPictured: Police officers detain protester in Weymouth\n\n06:41 PM BST\n\nPictured: Police dogs attack a man during anti-immigration protest in Rotherham\n\n06:37 PM BST\n\nRioters attempting to attack Rotherham hotel from different angle\n\nWe earlier reported that police had removed rioters from the Rotherham migrant hotel that was attacked and set on fire earlier in the day.\n\nOur reporter Neil Johnston writes that agitators have now begun to attack again the hotel via a different route:\n\nRioters are pelting police using rectangular riot shields with missiles around 200 yards from the hotel. They were dispersed down the road but are now attempting to attack the hotel from a different angle using fireworks.\n\n06:19 PM BST\n\nMan charged after attempting to set fire to police van, Merseyside Police say\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nMerseyside Police said a man had been charged after allegedly attempting to set fire to a police van during violence in Liverpool on Saturday.\n\nThe van had been parked on William Brown Street and the flames were quickly extinguished before significant damage or harm could be caused.\n\nA police spokesman said: \"Declan Geiran, 29 years, of Kelso Road, Liverpool has been charged with violent disorder and arson (to a police vehicle). He has been remanded into custody to appear at Liverpool Magistrates Court at 9.45am on Monday 5 August.\"\n\n06:17 PM BST\n\nPolice remove rioters from Rotherham migrant hotel\n\nBy Neil Johnston\n\nPolice have cleared rioters from the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham which was vandalised and set on fire earlier in the day.\n\nThey are continuing to push back far right protestors who are still in the area.\n\nDozens of police vans are on the scene and a helicopter is flying overhead.\n\nWindows are pins the building have been smashed and a family can be seen looking through the remains of one window.\n\n06:08 PM BST\n\nPictured: Prime Minister addresses the nation as unrest continues for fifth day\n\nSir Keir Starmer held an emergency address from Downing Street on Sunday afternoon, where he said rioters \"will regret taking part in this disorder\".\n\nHe added that the police \"will be making arrests, individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow\".\n\nThe Prime Minister also vowed that \"would not shy away\" from calling the disturbances \"far-Right thuggery\".\n\n\"To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be. I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country and we will bring them to justice,\" he said.\n\n05:56 PM BST\n\nNine arrested in Middlesbrough, police say\n\nCleveland Police said officers have arrested nine people so far in relation to the ongoing disorder in Middlesbrough.\n\nThe force added that the main areas affected by disorder were Parliament Road, Waterloo Road, and the area around the university.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable David Felton said: \"We are urging members of the public to stay away from Middlesbrough while officers respond to violent disorder in the town.\n\n\"We have a high policing presence responding to the disorder, and the priority remains to protect people and communities.\n\n\"We will continue to make arrests and deal robustly with anyone shown to be intent on committing violence and causing harm.\"\n\n05:50 PM BST\n\n'Minority of far-Right extremists have disgraced themselves,' says Ed Davey\n\nSir Ed Davey, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, said: \"Everyone across the UK was shocked and appalled by the dreadful attack in Southport on Monday, which took the lives of three innocent little girls.\n\n\"Most people have come together to grieve with love and compassion. But sadly, a minority of far-right extremists have disgraced themselves by exploiting this tragedy to commit appalling acts of violence, targeting Muslims, asylum seekers and communities of colour.\n\n\"I am deeply angered by the riots and disorder that we have seen these past few days and welcome the extra protections now in place. This lawlessness is unacceptable and it must be stopped and those responsible must face the full force of the law.\n\n\"And amidst these awful scenes, we should all take heart from the immense compassion, kindness and decency shown by the vast majority, not least those communities who are being specifically targeted. Their example is one we must all follow.\"\n\n05:47 PM BST\n\nSunak condemns 'violent, criminal behaviour'\n\nRishi Sunak, the Conservative Party leader, has condemned the unrest gripping Britain as \"violent, criminal behaviour that has no place in our society\".\n\n\"The police have our full support to deal with these criminals swiftly and they must face the full weight of the law,\" he added.\n\n05:38 PM BST\n\nRioters target Kurdish businesses in Middlesbrough\n\nMore from Crime Editor Martin Evans on the ongoing disorder in Middlesbrough:\n\nIn the Gresham area of Milddlesbrough groups of masked youths smashed the windows of cars and houses.\n\nThe gang targeted Parliament Rd where some of the shop and restaurant owners began fighting back.\n\nA group of Kurdish business owners armed themselves with wooden staves and some rioters were attacked.\n\nOne youth with a bloodied head was seen being escorted away from the area by a business owner.\n\nOne Parliament Road shop owner said: \"we're acting to protect what is ours. They have come here to attack our vehicles and our property, we have the right to defend ourselves.\"\n\n05:22 PM BST\n\nMosques to get 'rapid response' security, Home Office announces\n\nMosques will now be able to request \"rapid response\" security under a new security scheme just announced by the Home Office.\n\nThe plans state that mosques, police and local authorities can ask for rapid security personnel to be deployed, which will \"allow for a return to worship as quickly as possible\".\n\nIn a statement, the Home Office said the scheme would \"build on the existing Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, with up to \u00a329.4 million already available this year to fund security at mosques and Muslim faith schools\".\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme, alongside the support from local police forces and we repeat that anyone involved in this disorder and violence will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"As a nation we will not tolerate criminal behaviour, dangerous extremism, and racist attacks that go against everything our country stands for.\"\n\n05:13 PM BST\n\nPictured: Riot police detain man in Middlesbrough\n\n04:44 PM BST\n\nMasked thugs push burning wheelie bins into police\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nIn Middlesbrough some masked thugs set fire to wheelie bins and pushed them into a line of riot police containing protestors on Linthorpe Road.\n\nThe blazing bins were quickly extinguished without injury and a woman who had been pushing one of them was arrested.\n\nThe majority of the demonstrators have now dispersed but around 150 people, many in masks and hoods have remained in the town centre.\n\n04:42 PM BST\n\n'Civil war is inevitable,' says Elon Musk\n\nElon Musk, the Tesla and X chief, has said that civil war in the UK is \"inevitable\".\n\nResponding to a clip posted on social media showing recent rioting in Britain, Mr Musk wrote: \"Civil war is inevitable.\"\n\nThe comment received over one million views.\n\n04:33 PM BST\n\nRotherham violence 'utterly appalling', says Home Secretary\n\nYvette Cooper, the Home Secretary, has condemned the attack on a migrant hotel in Rotherham, calling it \"utterly appalling\".\n\n\"South Yorkshire Police have full Government support for the strongest action against those responsible,\" she added.\n\n04:29 PM BST\n\nGroup chanting 'Allahu Akbar' clashes with protesters and police in Bolton\n\nThe BBC reports that a group of around 250-300 protesters chanting \"Allahu Akbar\" has clashed with police and Right-wing demonstrators in Bolton.\n\nAccording to the broadcaster, the group charged towards Bolton Town Hall, where protesters waving England flags had gathered.\n\nOn a further cry of \"Allahu Akbar\", the group began throwing eggs at the police before \"charging\" around streets in the town centre.\n\nThe two groups of protesters then skirmished on another street, where bottles and fireworks were exchanged, but both sides were kept apart by police lines.\n\n04:21 PM BST\n\nHouses and cars attacked in Middlesbrough\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nHouses and cars were attacked at random in Middlesbrough as the demonstrators descended on the Gresham area, home to much of the town's immigrant population.\n\nMasked youths used metal and wooden bars to smash the windows of terraced houses and the windscreens of cars.\n\nThere were chants of \"smash the p***s\" as the cheering mob left destruction in its wake.\n\nOne victim, a white man in his 40s, had his living room window smashed.\n\nHe said: \"I'm born and bred in Middlesbrough and these morons target my house just for the hell of it. I could hear them yelling about immigrants but they were smashing car and house windows indiscriminately. They're the scum of the earth.\"\n\nThe protestors returned to the cenotaph where riot police came under fire from bricks and bottles as they tried to force them back down Linthorpe Rd.\n\n04:18 PM BST\n\nMalaysia issues UK travel warning\n\nMalaysia has issued a warning to its citizens travelling to or residing in the UK, advising them to \"remain vigilant\" and to \"stay away from protest areas\".\n\nThe warning, released on Sunday by the country's ministry of foreign affairs, also encourages Malaysian citizens to register with the country's high commission in London in order to receive assistance and information.\n\n04:01 PM BST\n\nHumza Yousaf suggests the army should be sent in to quell riots\n\nHumza Yousaf, the former first minister of Scotland, has suggested that Sir Keir Starmer should send in the army to quell rioting across Britain.\n\nIn a post on X, Mr Yousaf wrote: \"How much worse does it have to get before the army is sent in @Keir Starmer?\n\n\"The Police clearly do not have a handle on this situation. This pogrom against Muslims and People of Colour is going to cost lives unless these far-right thugs are stopped.\"\n\n03:45 PM BST\n\nTwo Tory leadership candidates condemn Rotherham riot\n\nJames Cleverly, the MP for Braintree, and Tom Tugendhat, the MP for Tonbridge, have condemned the attack on a migrant hotel in Rotherham.\n\nIn a post on X, Mr Tugendhat wrote: \"This behaviour is abhorrent. We have got to put an end to the violence and disorder plaguing our streets. The government must use all the available resources to punish those responsible.\"\n\nMr Cleverly wrote: \"There is not and can never be any excuse, justification or rationale for behavior like this. This should be condemned by everybody, and those taking part should expect to be met with the full weight of the law.\"\n\n03:38 PM BST\n\n'Stand up for our country, our kids and our families,' says Middlesbrough march organiser\n\nBy Martin Evans, our crime editor\n\nIn Middlesbrough, march organiser Jake Wheatley addressed the crowd before the march began, saying: \"You are all here today lads for the three kids who were killed in Southport and the future of our country, it is not about race or colour or religion.\n\n\"Let's all keep it right today and stand up for our country, our kids and our families.\"\n\nDespite skirmishes en route with police the march arrived at Central Square without any serious violence or damage being caused.\n\nThe marchers dispersed into smaller groups and some left the area, although hundreds remained in the town centre.\n\n03:31 PM BST\n\nPictured: Police dog attacks a protester in Rotherham\n\n03:29 PM BST\n\nMore than 300 protesters march through Middlesbrough\n\nMore than 300 protesters marched through Middlesbrough after gathering at the city's Cenotaph.\n\nDemonstrators were seen carrying a banner saying: \"Tom Jones is Welsh, Axel Rudakubana isn't\" and chanted \"We want our country back\" as they made their way through the city.\n\nPolice used dogs to keep the group back and at least two people were taken away in handcuffs within the first half hour, while several pieces of slate were thrown, along with vapes and full plastic bottles.\n\n03:15 PM BST\n\nSkirmishes break out in Middlesbrough\n\nOur reporter Kevin Donald is on the ground in Middlesbrough. He reports that \"skirmishes\" have broken out between police and agitators.\n\nAs the crowd began to march through the town to chants of \"we want our country back\" skirmishes broke out between masked thugs and police.\n\nRocks were thrown and fireworks ignited In the crowd.\n\nA number of arrests were made as police were forced to draw truncheons to contain demonstrators who tried break through police lines.\n\n03:02 PM BST\n\nRotherham MP responds to attack on migrant hotel\n\nSarah Champion, the Labour MP for Rotherham, has described the ongoing riot at a migrant hotel in Manvers, Rotherham as \"horrendous\" in a post on social media.\n\n02:52 PM BST\n\nWatch: Fire started at Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n02:49 PM BST\n\nSection 60 orders issued in Liverpool and Southport\n\nBy Crime Editor Martin Evans\n\nMerseyside Police said two more Section 60 Orders have been introduced in Liverpool and Southport for 12 hours following the violence and disorder seen in Liverpool city centre and Walton on Saturday 3 August..\n\nThe orders were put in place at 2pm today (Sunday 4 August) and will stay active for a 12-hour period until 2am on Monday.\n\nThey have has been introduced to prevent incidents of disorder and criminality.\n\nThe Orders, under S60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994, give officers enhanced powers to stop and search individuals across areas of Liverpool and Southport and are designed to prevent serious violence.\n\nInspector Al McKeon said: \"The scenes we saw yesterday in Liverpool and Walton, and on Tuesday in Southport, were despicable. They left dozens of officers requiring hospital treatment and have already led to the arrests of a total of 33 suspects. \"These orders will give officers on the ground the ability to stop and search anyone suspected of carrying weapons or planning any criminality.\n\n\"The ultimate aim of this tool is to prevent violence and disorder and keep the public safe. \"People across the areas covered will see targeted and highly visible police patrols over the next 12 hours. I hope their continued presence is reassuring for all of our communities, and I would ask anyone with concerns to speak to those officers.\n\n02:47 PM BST\n\nWatch: Police and rioters battle in Bolton\n\nSocial media footage shows rioters battling with mounted police on the streets of Bolton.\n\nGreater Manchester Police earlier issued a Section 34 dispersal notice covering Bolton until 10pm, which gives the force extra powers to remove people causing anti-social behaviour.\n\n02:44 PM BST\n\nPictured: Rioters break into Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n02:32 PM BST\n\nPictured: Police injured during riot at Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n02:22 PM BST\n\nWatch: Riot at Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n02:06 PM BST\n\nPictured: People take cover as objects thrown during protest outside Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n01:51 PM BST\n\nPolice issue dispersal notice in Bolton\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a section 34 dispersal notice has been authorised covering Bolton until 10pm on Sunday.\n\nUnder a Section 34 notice, officers have extra powers to deal with anyone causing anti-social behaviour in defined areas.\n\nThe force said officers will be able to instruct anyone who is causing - or very likely to cause - harassment, alarm, or distress to leave an area immediately.\n\nChief Inspector Natasha Evans said: \"These powers have been authorised in response to increased protest activity.\n\n\"We have been working with organisers of pre-planned protests to help facilitate peaceful and lawful protests, to prevent serious disruption and ensure everyone can go about their lives without fear or risk of harm.\n\n\"We will continue to have an increased police presence around these areas to deal with any incidents that may arise, and with these additional powers, officers are more equipped to intervene early to ensure people feel safe and are safe.\"\n\n01:46 PM BST\n\nPictured: Protester on mobility scooter outside Rotherham hotel\n\n01:03 PM BST\n\nProtesters mass at migrant hotel in Rotherham\n\nProtesters have gathered outside the Holiday Inn Express in Manvers, Rotherham, which has been used as an asylum hotel.\n\nBoth anti-immigration protesters and counter-protesters have been pictured outside the hotel in South Yorkshire (see our posts at 12.47pm and 12.07pm).\n\nThe number of protesters is not as large as was seen during Saturday's protests, but there is a police presence at the scene.\n\n12:48 PM BST\n\nPictured: Saturday's protests\n\n12:47 PM BST\n\nPictured: Demonstrators wearing St George's cross flags stand outside Rotherham migrant hotel\n\n12:17 PM BST\n\nStarmer should cancel 'Nero-esque' holiday, says Jenrick\n\nTory leadership hopeful Robert Jenrick has said that Sir Keir Starmer should \"cancel this Nero-esque holiday\".\n\nIt would be \"completely wrong for the Prime Minister to holiday while parts of Britain are burning\", Mr Jenrick added.\n\nThe comments came after reports circulated that Sir Keir Starmer was set to take his first holiday as Prime Minister at the start of next week.\n\nHowever, sources close to No 10 have suggested to the PA news agency that Sir Keir will not be going on holiday with the prospect of further unrest looming.\n\n12:07 PM BST\n\nPictured: Counter-protesters outside a migrant hotel in Manvers, Rotherham\n\n11:53 AM BST\n\n'Wanton criminals' behind attack on a Liverpool library\n\n\"Wanton criminals\" were behind the riots in Liverpool which saw a library set on fire, the city's council leader has said.\n\nSpellow Lane Library Hub, in Walton, north Liverpool, was set ablaze on Saturday evening, and footage showed people laughing as flames consumed the building.\n\nLeader of Liverpool City Council, Liam Robinson, said: \"The violence we have seen on our streets is the manipulation of tragic events, an attack on our community by wanton criminals.\n\n\"We can't allow a minority of mindless thugs to win. They are not representative of our city and we will be working with partners to ensure the perpetrators are swiftly brought to justice.\n\n\"Our priority is to assess the damage to Spellow Library and to bring it back into use as quickly as possible.\n\n\"I want to pay tribute to Merseyside Police, the emergency services and Liverpool City Council staff for their fast response in cleaning up, and also to those residents who came out to help - it has been heartening to see, and that is the real spirit of our city.\"\n\n11:51 AM BST\n\nPictured: Syrian shop damaged during rioting in Belfast\n\n11:42 AM BST\n\nPolice commissioner criticised for 'justifying riots'\n\nBritain's most senior police commissioner has been criticised for \"appearing to justify\" the riots.\n\nDonna Jones, who is police and crime commissioner for Hampshire and the Isle of Wight, and a Conservative Party politician, said the only way to stop the violent scenes was to \"acknowledge what is causing it\" and by \"understanding the views\" of the rioters.\n\n\"Whilst the devastating attacks in Southport on Tuesday were a catalyst, the commonality amongst the protest groups appears to be focused on three key areas: the desire to protect Britain's sovereignty; the need to uphold British values, and, in order to do this, stop illegal immigration,\" she said.\n\nShe said arresting people was \"treating the symptom and not the cause\" and that the Prime Minister had questions to answer about how the new Labour government would tackle immigration and uphold British values.\n\nFormer chief prosecutor Nazir Afzal called her comments \"totally unacceptable\" and said she was \"appearing to justify rioting and criminality that police officers are bravely having to deal with right now\".\n\nMs Jones is also chair of the Association of Police and Crime Commissioners in the UK.\n\n11:35 AM BST\n\nPictured: Damage to a library in Liverpool after rioting\n\nSpellow Hub library on County Road in Liverpool was set ablaze during far-Right rioting on Saturday (see our posts at 9.29am and 9.54am).\n\nMerseyside Police said that protesters attempted to stop firefighters at the scene putting out the blaze.\n\n11:21 AM BST\n\nStreet cleaning teams work throughout the night in Hull\n\nStreet cleaning teams in Hull worked overnight to ensure the city would be open for business on Sunday, the city council said.\n\nVolunteers also arrived with brushes early on Sunday morning to assist the council crews.\n\nCouncillor Jack Haines of Hull City Council said: \"Yesterday we saw the worst of Hull but already today we have seen the best.\n\n\"The cleaning teams have made fantastic progress overnight. The main streets are largely clear and the interchange has reopened.\n\n\"We have already seen the power in our community with volunteers turning up from 7am this morning with brushes to assist council teams. I thank all volunteers and council staff.\n\n\"With the clean-up largely completed and areas clear, the best way anyone can help today is to come together, enjoy our city and support local shops and business.\"\n\n11:08 AM BST\n\nPolice deny rumours of acid attack on Muslim woman shared by Labour MP\n\nCleveland Police has denied rumours circulating online that a Muslim woman was attacked with acid in Middlesbrough during unrest on Saturday.\n\nThe force said it had not received \"any formal complaint\" from a victim or anyone on their behalf. It also said it had not received notification from medical colleagues of any such incident.\n\nOn Saturday, reports of the attack were shared on social media by Nick Lowles, chief executive of Left-wing group Hope not Hate, and Josh Fenton-Glynn, the Labour MP for Calder Valley.\n\n\"Reports are coming in of acid being thrown out of a car window at a Muslim woman in Middlesbrough. Absolutely horrendous,\" Mr Lowles posted on X.\n\nIn response to Mr Lowles' post, Mr Fenton-Glynn wrote: \"Far right cowards attacking women. When people show you who they are, believe them.\"\n\nBoth Mr Lowles and Mr Fenton-Glynn have since retracted their statements.\n\n10:46 AM BST\n\nRioters will receive a 'knock at their door', says policing minister\n\nRioters who have taken part in the unrest on Britain's streets will receive a \"knock at their door\" and there is room for them in jail, the policing minister has said.\n\nDame Diana Johnson insisted there will be \"consequences\" for those responsible for looting after far-Right supporters clashed with police in cities across the country.\n\n\"People need to be aware [that] if they were looting, there will be a knock on their door, they will be brought before the police and the court and there will be consequences,\" Dame Diana told Times Radio.\n\n\"I want people punished for causing mayhem and disruption to our communities. We need to stamp on that small minority who have engaged in dreadful violent disorder on our streets.\"\n\nDespite plans to release prisoners being released less than halfway through their sentences to ease the jail crisis, Dame Diana said there were \"places available\" for offenders.\n\nThe MP for Kingston upon Hull North added: \"I am absolutely appalled about what happened in my city yesterday. That people felt they could rampage through the city, could throw bricks and missiles at police officers. That is not the Britain I know and has to be dealt with quickly.\"\n\n10:34 AM BST\n\nPictured: Vape shop owner watches footage of business being looted\n\nThe owner of King Vape Store on County Road in Liverpool reviews CCTV footage of looters swarming around his shop and ransacking his stock.\n\n10:23 AM BST\n\nCafe and supermarket burnt out in Belfast\n\nA cafe and a supermarket in south Belfast were badly damaged following unrest in the city on Saturday.\n\nCars were also set on fire as police attempted to deal with disorder in the Donegall Road area, which lasted through the night and into Sunday morning.\n\nThe supermarket's manager, Bashir, said that the Islamic community was being targeted.\n\n\"People attacked this place, racism against Islam and Muslims, especially the Muslim community,\" he said.\n\nHe added: \"All of that happened and the police did nothing, I am telling you the truth.\n\n\"What kind of police are letting the people burn everything down?\"\n\n10:06 AM BST\n\nNo need to bring in the army, says Home Office minister\n\nThere is \"no need\" to bring in the army to deal with unrest in parts of the UK, a Home Office minister has said.\n\nDame Diana Johnson, the policing minister, told BBC News: \"There is no need to bring in the Army and there has been no discussion about that.\n\n\"As I say, the police have made it very clear that they have all the resources they need at the moment... they have the powers that they need.\"\n\nAsked about the spread of misinformation online, Dame Diana added: \"Obviously we need to do more because you're absolutely right there has been that spread of misinformation which has caused problems this week.\"\n\n09:54 AM BST\n\nRioters set fire to 'library of the future' in Liverpool\n\nFar-Right rioters set fire to a library in one of the UK's most deprived areas, leaving parts of it \"completely destroyed\".\n\nSpellow Lane Library Hub, in Walton, north Liverpool, was set ablaze on Saturday evening, and footage showed people laughing as flames consumed the building.\n\nThe library, which was reopened last year by the city's Lord Mayor, was hailed as the 'library of the future' and helped provide routes into education and employment for the community.\n\nThe area lies in the third most deprived ward in the UK.\n\nSpeaking about the damage to the library, a spokesperson for Liverpool City Council told The Telegraph: \"It's such a shame because it's such a community asset. It's really sad.\n\n\"Elements of it are completely destroyed. Even the bits that look ok, there will probably be some smoke damage.\"\n\nCouncil officials were visiting the library on Sunday morning to inspect the damage.\n\n09:46 AM BST\n\n'An abhorrent, senseless act of violence against our police officers'\n\nA police leader has condemned the recent rioting and violence against police officers.\n\nTiffany Lynch, from the Police Federation of England and Wales, said on BBC Breakfast: \"It is an abhorrent, senseless act of violence against our police officers, towards our public buildings who are there to serve the community.\n\n\"[These acts are those of] a small minority and it doesn't represent the community of Great Britain. It is absolutely abhorrent.\"\n\nMs Lynch also said that everyday crime fighting would suffer due to police officers being redirected to tackle the riots (see our post at 9.41am).\n\n09:41 AM BST\n\nCrime fighting will suffer while officers tackle riots, police leader says\n\nPolice forces across the UK will struggle to attend everyday crime incidents while officers are redirected to tackle rioting, a police leader told the BBC.\n\nTiffany Lynch, from the Police Federation of England and Wales, said on BBC Breakfast: \"We're seeing officers that are being pulled from day-to-day policing to... go out there and essentially protect our communities.\n\n\"But while that's happening, the communities that are out there that are having incidents against them - victims of crime - unfortunately, their crimes are not being investigated.\n\n\"We're not going to be able to attend all of the incidents that are coming in on the 999s because we're having to direct the priorities of what's happening on the streets.\"\n\n09:29 AM BST\n\nPictured: Rioters torch a library in Liverpool\n\nRioters torched Liverpool's new Spellow Hub Library in the Walton area of the city on Saturday.\n\nMerseyside Police said agitators prevented firefighters from putting out the blaze.\n\n09:24 AM BST\n\nArrests made across Britain\n\nPolice forces across the UK arrested more than 90 people in connection with anti-immigration rioting on Saturday.\n\nMerseyside Police said a total of 23 people were arrested, including 12 arrests for the disorder in the city centre, nine arrests for the disorder on County Road and two in connection with the unrest in Southport.\n\nIn Hull, Humberside Police said they had arrested 20 people.\n\nIn Bristol, police made 14 arrests because of violent disorder in the city centre.\n\nLancashire Police said more than 20 people were arrested and dispersal orders were issued in parts of Blackpool, Preston and Blackburn.\n\nStaffordshire Police said 10
