{"uri": "2024-08-443882447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:20:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:20:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/13285815/yobs-thugs-hotel-migrants-rotherham-violence-far-right/", "title": "Yobs light fires & hurl missiles at migrant hotels as violence sweeps UK", "body": "THUGS smashed up two hotels for asylum seekers amid more shameful scenes of violence across the UK.\n\nYobs lit fires and hurled missiles at Holiday Inns in Rotherham and Tamworth, Staffs. There were clashes in other towns.\n\nPM Sir Keir Starmer said those involved would face the \"full force of the law\".\n\nIn a hard-hitting message from Downing Street, the PM told them: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nHe went on: \"This is not a \u00adprotest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\n\n\"All right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe.\n\n\"And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted.\n\n\"I won't shy away from calling this what it is: Far-right thuggery.\"\n\nTowns and cities hit -- the fifth day of violence -- included Rotherham, Aldershot in Hants, Middlesbrough, Bolton, Manchester, Hull and Weymouth, Dorset.\n\nTerrifying footage from Rotherham showed masked yobs kicking out windows to storm the \u00adHoliday Inn Express, which houses migrants.\n\nAnother Holiday Inn where asylum seekers are thought to stay was set alight in Tamworth, Staffordshire.\n\nThe thugs in Rotherham forced their way past cops into the hotel after pelting them with bricks, \u00adbottles and even fence panels. Some then hurled chairs.\n\nFire broke out as they chanted: \"Get them out.\"\n\nPlacards carried by far-right \u00adsupporters had slogans such as \"stop the boats\" and, in a cruel barb aimed at asylum seekers: \"Men don't flee war.\"\n\nAnother made reference to Enoch Powell's inflammatory 1968 Rivers of Blood speech.\n\nThe thugs chased away around 100 counter-protesters.\n\nAt least one injured cop was seen being carried by colleagues, while a number of protesters were handcuffed as police battled to regain control.\n\nThe nationwide disorder has been fuelled by online lies following the murders of three girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nPosts wrongly claimed suspect Axel Rudakubana, 17, was a Muslim asylum seeker.\n\nDemonstrations were promoted on X/Twitter by former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson -- from the safety of an all-inclusive resort on the outskirts of Ayia Napa, Cyprus.\n\nThe 41-year-old is understood to be staying at a \u00a3400-a-night chalet bungalow with his family.\n\nHe has been seen lazing on sun loungers and taking dips in a pool.\n\nA series of inflammatory posts he shared with his 800,000 followers include ones blasting the PM and police for cracking down on rioters.\n\nBut last night he insisted: \"I am not at fault.\"\n\nMeanwhile another migrant hotel, this time in Aldershot, was also targeted.\n\nA group of men outside Potters International Hotel brandished a banner insisting: \"We're not far right, we're just right.\"\n\nAt Middlesbrough's Cenotaph, hundreds of protesters squared up to police before throwing slate, cans and pots at the officers.\n\nA group of masked yobs walked through a residential area using metal bars and wooden posts to smash car windscreens and the windows of terraced houses.\n\nVehicles were torched, along with wheelie bins.\n\nOne victim, a white man in his 40s who did not want to be named, said: \"I'm born and bred in Middlesbrough and these morons target my house just for the hell of it. I could hear them yelling about immigrants, but they were smashing cars and house windows indiscriminately.\n\n\"They're the scum of the earth.\"\n\nCleveland Police confirmed \u00ada number of arrests had been made and warned the public to avoid the area.\n\nIn the centre of Bolton, large crowds of anti-immigration demonstrators gathered along with \u00adcounter-protesters while police tried to keep them apart.\n\nAn anti-immigrant rally on Weymouth seafront was met by a counter-protest.\n\nThree far-right sympathisers were said to have been handcuffed and arrested trying to break through police lines.\n\nThere was a large turnout in Hull, scene of earlier violence.\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a Section 34 dispersal notice had been authorised until 10pm yesterday, giving officers extra powers to deal with anyone causing anti-social behaviour.\n\nChief Inspector Natasha Evans said the force was acting to \"prevent serious disruption and ensure everyone can go about their lives without fear or risk of harm\".\n\nMerseyside Police introduced two Section 60 orders in Liverpool and Southport between 2pm yesterday and 2am today, giving officers greater stop-and-search powers.\n\nLast night faith leaders in Merseyside issued a joint statement calling for calm and urging people to hold the families of Southport stabbing victims Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at \"the forefront of all our thoughts\".\n\nThey said: \"Division can destroy the very relationships and environment that we depend upon every day of our lives and there is no place for hate in our communities.\n\n\"It can -- and has -- left communities in fear and has put people in danger. At this difficult time, let us remember that there is far more that unites than divides us.\n\n\"The people of all faiths and none who came out to sweep the streets, to rebuild walls and have so generously donated money in memory of those three girls -- that is the spirit that will help us through this incredibly challenging time.\"\n\nSince the horror a week ago, the country has been plagued by riots.\n\nOn Wednesday, 111 people were arrested in London and 11 more in Hartlepool, two in Manchester and two in Aldershot.\n\nOn Friday, violence erupted outside a Liverpool mosque.\n\nSaturday saw forces pushed to the brink with more than 100 arrests and dozens of \u00adofficers hurt.\n\nTrouble flared in Belfast, Blackpool, Stoke, Leeds, Hull, Manchester, Liverpool, Nottingham, Bristol and Portsmouth.\n\nLast night National Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order, BJ Harrington, said leave had been cancelled by many forces and 4,000 officers put on standby.\n\nMr Harrington warned those involved in disorder: \"Make no mistake, if you haven't had a knock on the door yet, your time will come.\"\n\nHe said fake news inflamed the trouble and urged social media users to be careful what they share, adding: \"Think twice before you act.\"\n\nPolicing minister Dame Diana Johnson suggested courts could sit overnight to ensure \"thugs who maraud our streets\" are brought to justice.\n\nThose at risk of violent disorder will be offered additional security personnel.\n\nShe said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme.\"", {"uri": "2024-08-443913585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:36:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:36:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:10:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/rioters-in-middlesbrough-ask-drivers-to-disclose-their-ethnicity-while-blocking-traffic-in-violent-protests-with-police-advising-people-to-avoid-the-town/", "title": "Rioters in Middlesbrough ask drivers to disclose their ethnicity while blocking traffic in violent protests, with police advising people to avoid the town. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Far-right mobs in Middlesbrough stopped people to ask them if they are 'white and English' before letting them through as vile riots continue to sweep the nation.\n\nUnsettling video shows thugs standing at a crossroads and confronting drivers in cars as they tried to pass.\n\n'Are you English? Are you white?' one could be heard shouting at a car trying to cross the intersection where hundreds marched with anti-immigration groups earlier today.\n\n'Yes, he is!' someone else was heard shouting back.\n\nTwo cars narrowly avoided colliding as they sped away from the mob, prompting one of the agitators to whine he had 'nearly been run over' and calling out 'where's your police?'\n\nRows of officers wielding riot shields were seen near the commotion as thugs circled on BMXs and continued stopping cars, standing in the middle of the road.\n\nCleveland Police said this afternoon they are continuing to deal with 'disorder' in Middlesbrough, claiming to have arrested nine people 'relating to violent disorder offences'.\n\n'We are urging members of the public to stay away from Middlesbrough while officers respond to violent disorder in the town,' Assistant Chief Constable David Felton said in a statement.\n\nThe horrifying TikTok video of the 'checkpoint' on Linthorpe Road in Middlesbrough drew outcry as it was shared across social media.\n\n'This is a pretty concerning development. I thought we were supposed to be moving towards a more inclusive and equitable society, not regressing back to the days of segregation,' one user wrote.\n\n'So utterly disappointed with this country and this disgusting behaviour,' another said.\n\n'This is beyond sad... what is going on fgs,' a third user added.\n\nMiddlesbrough has seen a thoroughly disturbing spate of violence over the weekend as far-right groups torched cars and hurled bricks.\n\nA so-called protest organised by anti-immigration groups was organised to travel along the Linthorpe Road, where a mob was later seen screening drivers.\n\nBuses announced they would change their schedules to avoid the disorder.\n\nHooligans set fire to cars and wheelie bins, pushed towards police trying to restore order.\n\nAbout 300 people gathered in front of a mosque in Waterloo Road in the town to guard it while police blocked off nearby streets.\n\nOne resident told the PA news agency: 'We're going to be paying for this, and for what?\n\n'This has got nothing to do with three little girls that have lost their lives. They've used it to cause utter mayhem on our streets.'\n\nA person was seen being stretchered into an ambulance after an incident at the Swatters Carr pub.\n\nPolice in riot gear were forced to retreat to get away from a group dressed in hoods and face coverings at one point.\n\nHumza Yousaf has called for the army to be called in to stop 'thugs' causing disorder on the streets as violence continued unabated through Sunday.\n\n'It doesn't look like, to me, the police have a handle on the situation,' the former first minister of Scotland said.\n\n'The police have not been able to protect those that are in the Holiday Inn [in Rotherham],' he added.\n\n'The army can help to get control where the police are unable.'\n\nDespite calls for police to have more powers to clamp down on the riots, Dame Diana Johnson, the Minister for Policing, said police have said they have 'all the resources they need' to deal with the disorder.\n\nIn Hull last night police used tear gas against thugs who smashed the windows of a hotel housing asylum seekers, while cars were set alight and vandalised through the afternoon.\n\nSimilar horror rocked Rotherham today as groups stormed a Holiday Inn housing asylum seekers.\n\nAround 700 violent anti-immigration protesters clad in balaclavas and draped in St George's flags clashed with officers trying to protect the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, South Yorkshire since around 2pm this afternoon.\n\nObjects and pieces of wood were flung at officers who had lined up in front of the building with at least one cop in riot gear being carried away by their colleagues.\n\nThe grass around the hotel appears to have been set on fire as well.\n\nSome were seen preparing to throw bricks of concrete as the violence spiralled.\n\nIt is unclear if the migrants and asylum seekers housed in the property have been able to evacuate.\n\nMailOnline has contacted the Home Office.\n\nJohn Healey MP urged anyone with information about the disorder at the Holiday Inn, Manvers and the wider area to report it by contacting SYP on 101, quoting 'incident number 239' of August 4, 2024.\n\nPolice said late this evening that officers were 'aware and responding proactively' to 'protest activity' in Tamworth, a small town in Staffordshire.\n\n'Robust action will be taken against those responsible for violence and disorder,' a statement read.\n\nFootage shared showed crowds standing around a Holiday Inn believed to be housing asylum seekers.\n\nBottles were launched at police, witnesses said.\n\nVideo appeared to show red flares being lit outside.\n\nA small group of demonstrators carried St George's Flag through Lancaster, shouting at a much larger crowd of counter-protestors in the main shopping district of the small university city.\n\nPolice were on guard to separate the groups, chanting back and forth at each other.\n\nChants of 'refugees are welcome here' were heard from the counter-protestors.\n\nOthers sang 'There are many many more of us than you' from the steps of the Town Hall.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police said several of its officers were injured during 'deplorable acts of violence' outside the Holiday Inn Express in the Manvers area of Rotherham today.\n\nAt least ten officers have been injured as a result of the violence, with one left unconscious following a head injury, another suffering a suspected fractured elbow and other suffering suspected broken bones.\n\nNo hotel employees or residents have been injured, police said.\n\nA heavy police presence will remain outside the hotel and in the surrounding area over the course of the rest of this evening and into tomorrow.\n\n'The behaviour we witnessed has been nothing short of disgusting,' said Assistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield.\n\n'While it was a smaller number of those in attendance who chose to commit violence and destruction, those who simply stood on and watched remain absolutely complicit in this.\n\n'Those who choose to spread misinformation and hate online, also need to take responsibility for the scenes today - this was not a protest, just angry people, reacting to a false narrative who have their own motivations for doing so.'\n\nThe Prime Minister this evening condemned the 'thuggery' of the far-right mob who stormed the hotel, promising those involved in the violence would 'regret it' as the government introduced emergency measures to bring rioters to justice.\n\nUK courts are to operate for 24 hours to expedite prosecutions of those involved in the riots, the government confirmed yesterday as violence erupted on the streets of Belfast, Hull, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester and Stoke.\n\nSaturday was the second night of violent confrontations after riots broke in Sunderland on Friday.\n\nA Citizens Advice bureau in Sunderland was set alight on Friday amid the senseless attacks on community pillars.\n\nITV journalist Jonny Blair wrote on Twitter/X on Saturday: 'Its manager this morning told me they're devastated and now trying to figure out how to help the people they were supposed to see.'\n\nSix people are due to appear in court following the night of disorder on Friday.\n\nThousands of protestors, including children as young as six, gathered in Keel Square in the city centre in response to the Southport stabbings.\n\nNorthumbria Police launched an investigation which has so far seen 14 people arrested for their role in the clashes with officers.\n\nFive men, aged 48, 41, 31, 29, 27, and a 43-year-old woman have been charged with violent disorder.\n\nThe 27-year-old man has also been charged with one count of burglary.\n\nAll are due to appear before Magistrates' tomorrow.\n\nAnd last night, thugs in Merseyside set fire to a library, which also functioned as a food bank, intended to help support deprived people in the community.\n\nAs firefighters tried to put on the flames that engulfed Spellow Lane Library Hub rioters threw a missile at the engine, before breaking the rear window of a nearby cab.\n\nHeartbreaking video of the centre as it opened last year went viral on Twitter/X as users denounced the shameless attacks.\n\nMany police units were pushed to breaking point last night as clashes continued in multiple cities.\n\nProtesters tried to kick down police officer's riot gear, while other demonstrators threw objects at their shields.\n\nLooters took advantage of the chaos, stealing phones, shoes and wine from the shelves of every-day stores, smashing their windows with bricks and stones.\n\nIn Liverpool, shameless yobs squealed 'get the phones! Get the phones!' as a group surrounded and battered their way into a phone repair and vape shop in the city centre.\n\nKicking the shutters with the feet and wrenching them up in a wild frenzy, the mob battered at the glass with what appeared to be a bollard before leaving the road outside strewn with packaging after they emptied the shelves.\n\nThe riots have swept across several UK cities following the deaths of three young girls in Southport.\n\nAxel Rudakubana, a 17-year-old from Lancashire, was identified as the suspect in the case, charged with murdering three children at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on July 29.\n\nHe is accused of killing Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, with a kitchen knife on Monday.\n\nEight other children sustained knife wounds, with five of them left in critical condition.\n\nJudge Menary KC cited 'idiotic rioting' in parts of the UK in his reasoning for lifting the automatic anonymity given to Rudakubana, as misinformation spread online about the suspect's identity.\n\nClaims falsely circulated social media that the suspect was a Muslim asylum seeker.\n\nRudakubana was born in Cardiff, described as a 'quiet choir boy' with a family involved in the local Christian church.\n\nSammy Woodhouse, a high-profile victim of the Rotherham child grooming gang scandal, said of the suspect in a broadcast: '[People] feel like they are not being told any information.\n\n'They know the guy's not a British guy. They know he's of a different ethnicity. There's talk of him being a Muslim as well.'\n\nThe clip was shared by Tommy Robinson, real name Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, after police had clarified that the claims were false, The Times reports.\n\nRobinson, 41, had a UK arrest warrant issued against him last Monday after he skipped a court appearance.\n\nMailOnline revealed exclusively that he has been staying at a five-star hotel in Cyprus as riots sweep England.\n\nCommunity leaders and families of the victims of the murders in Southport have criticised the unrest.\n\n'While this should be a time for quiet reflection and {"uri": "8259654472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:51:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:51:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:51:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://nationaldailyng.com/uk-vows-action-against-violent-anti-immigration-protesters/", "title": "UK Vows Action Against Violent Anti-Immigration Protesters", "body": "Prime Minister Keir Starmer has issued a stern warning to those involved in violent anti-immigration protests, promising that they will face the full force of the law.\n\nIn a Sunday address, Starmer condemned the protests as \"organized violent thuggery\" and vowed that arrests would be made.\n\nThe demonstrations, which erupted in several UK cities over the weekend, were sparked by a knife attack at a dance school event in Southport on July 29 that left three young girls dead and eight other children injured.\n\nThe attack occurred during a Taylor Swift-themed event at the school, and misinformation quickly spread that the suspect was an immigrant and a radical Islamist. This false narrative fueled anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim sentiment, leading to violent riots.\n\nREAD ALSO: 14-Year-Old Nigeria killed in London sword attack\n\nRiots first broke out the day after the attack, with large crowds gathering outside a mosque and throwing bottles and bricks at police vans. Despite police clarification that the 17-year-old suspect was born in Britain and came from a Christian family, the unrest continued to escalate.\n\nBy Saturday, the violence had spread to Liverpool, Bristol, and Manchester, resulting in dozens of arrests. Shops and businesses were vandalized and looted, and several police officers were injured.\n\nIn the latest wave of violence, rioters attacked a hotel in Rotherham that houses asylum seekers, throwing objects, spraying fire extinguishers at police officers, and smashing windows.\n\nStarmer denounced the attacks, stating that there was no justification for such violence and urging all right-minded individuals to condemn the disorder. \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or by whipping up this action online and then running away,\" he warned.\n\nEarlier, Starmer pledged the government's full support to police forces to take decisive action against \"extremists\" attempting to \"sow hate.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper also issued a strong warning, stating that those engaging in \"unacceptable disorder\" would face imprisonment, travel bans, and other severe punishments. \"Criminal violence and disorder have no place on Britain's streets,\" Cooper said, adding that \"sufficient\" prison spaces had been made available to detain those arrested.", "source": {"uri": "nationaldailyng.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "National Daily NG"}, {"uri": "2024-08-443886962", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:28:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:28:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:14:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/far-muslims-clash-fresh-riots-211426651.html", "title": "Far-Right and Muslims clash in fresh riots", "body": "Far-Right and Muslims clash in fresh riots\n\nNick Gutteridge\n\n4 August 2024 at 11:14 pm\n\nViolent clashes broke out between far-Right rioters and Muslim counter-protesters on Sunday in a sixth day of unrest on Britain's streets.\n\nThe disorder that has spread since the Southport killings showed no sign of abating over the weekend amid escalating community tensions.\n\nIn Rotherham, a hotel used to house asylum seekers was set ablaze, and another in Tamworth was targeted by anti-immigration protesters.\n\nIn Bolton, Muslim groups shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" clashed with far-Right rioters.\n\nA mob in Middlesbrough shouted \"smash the p -- s\" and \"there ain't no black in the Union Jack\" while targeting the homes of migrants, while footage on social media from elsewhere in the city appeared to show groups of Asian men attacking white men.\n\nIn an emergency address from Downing Street, Sir Keir Starmer warned the rioters would regret taking part and vowed to do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible\".\n\nHe said: \"The police will be making arrests. Individuals will be held on remand. Charges will follow. And convictions will follow.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder. Whether directly or those whipping up this action online, and then running away themselves.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is not protest. I won't shy away from calling this what it is - far-Right thuggery.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister was warned not to be \"selective\" in his response to the groups involved in the disorder.\n\nRobert Jenrick, a frontrunner to become the next Tory leader, said the Prime Minister must not show any \"squeamishness or selectivity\" in tackling all those responsible.\n\nHe said the streets should be flooded with tens of thousands of police, with all leave cancelled and officers diverted from unaffected areas to riot hotspots.\n\n\"The ringleaders should be arrested, swiftly prosecuted and jailed for the longest possible time,\" the former immigration minister told The Telegraph.\n\n\"Groups that gather in town or city centres that become violent must be immediately dispersed, with violent thugs arrested.\n\n\"If force is needed to achieve this, it should be used. There must be no squeamishness or selectivity whatsoever to robust law enforcement.\"\n\n'Law breaking is not the answer'\n\nNadhim Zahawi, the former Chancellor, also warned that there must be zero tolerance for anyone taking part in riots, including those \"taking matters into their own hands\".\n\nHe said: \"There needs to be a clear, consistent message for all those rioting, even if they think they are 'taking matters into their own hands'; law breaking is not the answer and there must be a zero tolerance response.\n\n\"The Government needs to realise that there is legitimate frustration and pain felt in communities across the country, with recent murders and other violence becoming emblematic of people feeling that their society is becoming unrecognisable. But the violence must be punished.\n\n\"Similarly, the Government needs to say to those thugs who hijack Islam that it will not be tolerant of intolerance. If you settle in Britain like I did, you respect its values and traditions, integrate and be proud of this country, otherwise you must go somewhere else.\"\n\nProtests broke out in the wake of the Southport killings after false information was spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker.\n\nOn Sunday more than 200 hooded rioters descended on the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, which has previously been used to house asylum seekers.\n\nAfter smashing several ground floor windows, the attackers then attempted to set the hotel on fire, torching bins and then using them to blockade the exits.\n\nMosques have been targeted on previous days of the unrest and the Home Office on Sunday announced that extra police and security forces will be deployed to protect mosques after they were targeted by far-Right rioters.\n\nAmid escalating community tensions, in Bolton there were scuffles on the town's streets between anti-immigration protesters and Muslim counter demonstrators.\n\nBy early afternoon the counter-protesters, who were mostly Asian and many in Muslim dress, outnumbered the anti-immigration protest by two to one.\n\nFootage on social media also appeared to show groups of Asian men attacking white males in Middlesbrough.\n\nA reporter for Channel 4 News said groups of Asian and white men were on the streets of the town \"looking for trouble\".\n\nSir Keir is under increasing pressure to bring the violence under control.\n\nIn his statement on Sunday, he opened the door to tougher prison sentences for rioters and announced suspects will be held on remand and locked up immediately after being charged, mirroring action to tackle the 2011 riots when he was Director of Public Prosecutions.\n\nThe Prime Minister will lead a meeting of the Government's emergency Cobra committee on Monday alongside Cabinet ministers and senior police figures.\n\nHowever doubts have been raised over whether there are enough jail places available for Sir Keir to mount a 2011-style response to the unrest.\n\nLabour inherited a system that is running at almost full capacity, with only around 700 spaces available in male prisons around the country.\n\nAround 150 arrests have been made across England since Saturday evening, the National Police Chiefs' Council said, with that number expected to rise.\n\nCassia Rowland, a researcher at the Institute for Government, said locking up all the rioters was \"not an option\" unless more prisoners are released.\n\nShe said: \"The situation in prisons is desperate. We simply don't have the prison spaces available for mass arrests like we saw in 2011.\"\n\nThe Government has announced that, as of Sept 10, thousands of prisoners will be freed when they have served 40pc of their sentence to free up cells.\n\nBut that date has been written into law, meaning the scheme could only be brought forward if Parliament were recalled from recess to amend the legislation.\n\nGovernment sources insisted that internal modelling of prisoner numbers showed there would be enough space to lock up all the rioters.\n\nNo 10 was forced to scotch rumours that Sir Keir was planning to go on holiday on Monday insisting he would be working at Downing Street all week.\n\nThe Prime Minister is now facing demands to recall Parliament so that MPs can debate his response, as Lord Cameron did at the same point during the 2011 unrest.\n\nSir Iain Duncan Smith, a former Tory leader, added that Sir Keir \"needs to bring people back to explain what he's doing\".\n\nMeanwhile officials were forced to dampen down speculation they could call the Army in if police forces are stretched to breaking point in the coming days.\n\nHumza Yousaf, a former Scottish first minister, and Tobias Ellwood, an ex-Armed Forces minister, were among those urging Sir Keir to use the military.\n\nMr Yousaf warned the UK was experiencing \"far-Right race riots\" which amounted to \"pogroms against the Muslim community, against people of colour\".\n\nNeil Basu, a former assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard, said the riots had made him feel afraid to be black for the first time in decades.\n\nHe said: \"I was born a few weeks before Enoch Powell made a speech that changed my parents' lives. I am the son of immigrants and I am not a white person.\n\n\"I spent 30 years as a police officer feeling pretty secure in my ability to handle myself, I don't feel like that this week and that is a terrible thing for a man in his 57th year to say.\n\n\"But I remember growing up in the 1970s, I watched the National Front march down streets, and this feels very much like that.\"", "source": {"uri": "8259107272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:20:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:20:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:17:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/far-muslims-clash-fresh-riots-211426087.html", "title": "Far-Right and Muslims clash in fresh riots", "body": "Violent clashes broke out between far-Right rioters and Muslim counter-protesters on Sunday in a sixth day of unrest on Britain's streets.\n\nThe disorder that has spread since the Southport killings showed no sign of abating over the weekend amid escalating community tensions.\n\nIn Rotherham, a hotel used to house asylum seekers was set ablaze, and another in Tamworth was targeted by anti-immigration protesters.\n\nIn Bolton, Muslim groups shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" clashed with far-Right rioters.\n\nA mob in Middlesbrough shouted \"smash the p -- s\" and \"there ain't no black in the Union Jack\" while targeting the homes of migrants, while footage on social media from elsewhere in the city appeared to show groups of Asian men attacking white men.\n\nIn an emergency address from Downing Street, Sir Keir Starmer warned the rioters would regret taking part and vowed to do \"whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice as quickly as possible\".\n\nHe said: \"The police will be making arrests. Individuals will be held on remand. Charges will follow. And convictions will follow.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder. Whether directly or those whipping up this action online, and then running away themselves.\"\n\nHe added: \"This is not protest. I won't shy away from calling this what it is - far-Right thuggery.\"\n\nThe Prime Minister was warned not to be \"selective\" in his response to the groups involved in the disorder.\n\nRobert Jenrick, a frontrunner to become the next Tory leader, said the Prime Minister must not show any \"squeamishness or selectivity\" in tackling all those responsible.\n\nHe said the streets should be flooded with tens of thousands of police, with all leave cancelled and officers diverted from unaffected areas to riot hotspots.\n\n\"The ringleaders should be arrested, swiftly prosecuted and jailed for the longest possible time,\" the former immigration minister told The Telegraph.\n\n\"Groups that gather in town or city centres that become violent must be immediately dispersed, with violent thugs arrested.\n\n\"If force is needed to achieve this, it should be used. There must be no squeamishness or selectivity whatsoever to robust law enforcement.\"\n\nNadhim Zahawi, the former Chancellor, also warned that there must be zero tolerance for anyone taking part in riots, including those \"taking matters into their own hands\".\n\nHe said: \"There needs to be a clear, consistent message for all those rioting, even if they think they are 'taking matters into their own hands'; law breaking is not the answer and there must be a zero tolerance response.\n\n\"The Government needs to realise that there is legitimate frustration and pain felt in communities across the country, with recent murders and other violence becoming emblematic of people feeling that their society is becoming unrecognisable. But the violence must be punished.\n\n\"Similarly, the Government needs to say to those thugs who hijack Islam that it will not be tolerant of intolerance. If you settle in Britain like I did, you respect its values and traditions, integrate and be proud of this country, otherwise you must go somewhere else.\"\n\nProtests broke out in the wake of the Southport killings after false information was spread online that the suspect was an asylum seeker.\n\nOn Sunday more than 200 hooded rioters descended on the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, which has previously been used to house asylum seekers.\n\nAfter smashing several ground floor windows, the attackers then attempted to set the hotel on fire, torching bins and then using them to blockade the exits.\n\nMosques have been targeted on previous days of the unrest and the Home Office on Sunday announced that extra police and security forces will be deployed to protect mosques after they were targeted by far-Right rioters.\n\nAmid escalating community tensions, in Bolton there were scuffles on the town's streets between anti-immigration protesters and Muslim counter demonstrators.\n\nBy early afternoon the counter-protesters, who were mostly Asian and many in Muslim dress, outnumbered the anti-immigration protest by two to one.\n\nFootage on social media also appeared to show groups of Asian men attacking white males in Middlesbrough.\n\nA reporter for Channel 4 News said groups of Asian and white men were on the streets of the town \"looking for trouble\".\n\nSir Keir is under increasing pressure to bring the violence under control.\n\nIn his statement on Sunday, he opened the door to tougher prison sentences for rioters and announced suspects will be held on remand and locked up immediately after being charged, mirroring action to tackle the 2011 riots when he was Director of Public Prosecutions.\n\nThe Prime Minister will lead a meeting of the Government's emergency Cobra committee on Monday alongside Cabinet ministers and senior police figures.\n\nHowever doubts have been raised over whether there are enough jail places available for Sir Keir to mount a 2011-style response to the unrest.\n\nLabour inherited a system that is running at almost full capacity, with only around 700 spaces available in male prisons around the country.\n\nAround 150 arrests have been made across England since Saturday evening, the National Police Chiefs' Council said, with that number expected to rise.\n\nCassia Rowland, a researcher at the Institute for Government, said locking up all the rioters was \"not an option\" unless more prisoners are released.\n\nShe said: \"The situation in prisons is desperate. We simply don't have the prison spaces available for mass arrests like we saw in 2011.\"\n\nThe Government has announced that, as of Sept 10, thousands of prisoners will be freed when they have served 40pc of their sentence to free up cells.\n\nBut that date has been written into law, meaning the scheme could only be brought forward if Parliament were recalled from recess to amend the legislation.\n\nGovernment sources insisted that internal modelling of prisoner numbers showed there would be enough space to lock up all the rioters.\n\nNo 10 was forced to scotch rumours that Sir Keir was planning to go on holiday on Monday insisting he would be working at Downing Street all week.\n\nThe Prime Minister is now facing demands to recall Parliament so that MPs can debate his response, as Lord Cameron did at the same point during the 2011 unrest.\n\nSir Iain Duncan Smith, a former Tory leader, added that Sir Keir \"needs to bring people back to explain what he's doing\".\n\nMeanwhile officials were forced to dampen down speculation they could call the Army in if police forces are stretched to breaking point in the coming days.\n\nHumza Yousaf, a former Scottish first minister, and Tobias Ellwood, an ex-Armed Forces minister, were among those urging Sir Keir to use the military.\n\nMr Yousaf warned the UK was experiencing \"far-Right race riots\" which amounted to \"pogroms against the Muslim community, against people of colour\".\n\nNeil Basu, a former assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard, said the riots had made him feel afraid to be black for the first time in decades.\n\nHe said: \"I was born a few weeks before Enoch Powell made a speech that changed my parents' lives. I am the son of immigrants and I am not a white person.\n\n\"I spent 30 years as a police officer feeling pretty secure in my ability to handle myself, I don't feel like that this week and that is a terrible thing for a man in his 57th year to say.\n\n\"But I remember growing up in the 1970s, I watched the National Front march down streets, and this feels very much like that.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-443891967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:44:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:44:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/12109216/yobs-thugs-hotel-migrants-rotherham-violence-far-right/", "title": "Yobs light fires & hurl missiles at migrant hotels as violence sweeps UK", "body": "THUGS smashed up two hotels for asylum seekers amid more shameful scenes of violence across the UK.\n\nYobs lit fires and hurled missiles at Holiday Inns in Rotherham and Tamworth, Staffs. There were clashes in other towns.\n\nPM Sir Keir Starmer said those involved would face the \"full force of the law\".\n\nIn a hard-hitting message from Downing Street, the PM told them: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nHe went on: \"This is not a \u00adprotest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\n\n\"All right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe.\n\n\"And yet, we've seen Muslim communities targeted.\n\n\"I won't shy away from calling this what it is: Far-right thuggery.\"\n\nTowns and cities hit -- the fifth day of violence -- included Rotherham, Aldershot in Hants, Middlesbrough, Bolton, Manchester, Hull and Weymouth, Dorset.\n\nTerrifying footage from Rotherham showed masked yobs kicking out windows to storm the \u00adHoliday Inn Express, which houses migrants.\n\nAnother Holiday Inn where asylum seekers are thought to stay was set alight in Tamworth, Staffordshire.\n\nThe thugs in Rotherham forced their way past cops into the hotel after pelting them with bricks, \u00adbottles and even fence panels. Some then hurled chairs.\n\nFire broke out as they chanted: \"Get them out.\"\n\nPlacards carried by far-right \u00adsupporters had slogans such as \"stop the boats\" and, in a cruel barb aimed at asylum seekers: \"Men don't flee war.\"\n\nAnother made reference to Enoch Powell's inflammatory 1968 Rivers of Blood speech.\n\nThe thugs chased away around 100 counter-protesters.\n\nAt least one injured cop was seen being carried by colleagues, while a number of protesters were handcuffed as police battled to regain control.\n\nThe nationwide disorder has been fuelled by online lies following the murders of three girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nPosts wrongly claimed suspect Axel Rudakubana, 17, was a Muslim asylum seeker.\n\nDemonstrations were promoted on X/Twitter by former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson -- from the safety of an all-inclusive resort on the outskirts of Ayia Napa, Cyprus.\n\nThe 41-year-old is understood to be staying at a \u00a3400-a-night chalet bungalow with his family.\n\nHe has been seen lazing on sun loungers and taking dips in a pool.\n\nA series of inflammatory posts he shared with his 800,000 followers include ones blasting the PM and police for cracking down on rioters.\n\nBut last night he insisted: \"I am not at fault.\"\n\nMeanwhile another migrant hotel, this time in Aldershot, was also targeted.\n\nA group of men outside Potters International Hotel brandished a banner insisting: \"We're not far right, we're just right.\"\n\nAt Middlesbrough's Cenotaph, hundreds of protesters squared up to police before throwing slate, cans and pots at the officers.\n\nA group of masked yobs walked through a residential area using metal bars and wooden posts to smash car windscreens and the windows of terraced houses.\n\nVehicles were torched, along with wheelie bins.\n\nOne victim, a white man in his 40s who did not want to be named, said: \"I'm born and bred in Middlesbrough and these morons target my house just for the hell of it. I could hear them yelling about immigrants, but they were smashing cars and house windows indiscriminately.\n\n\"They're the scum of the earth.\"\n\nCleveland Police confirmed \u00ada number of arrests had been made and warned the public to avoid the area.\n\nIn the centre of Bolton, large crowds of anti-immigration demonstrators gathered along with \u00adcounter-protesters while police tried to keep them apart.\n\nAn anti-immigrant rally on Weymouth seafront was met by a counter-protest.\n\nThree far-right sympathisers were said to have been handcuffed and arrested trying to break through police lines.\n\nThere was a large turnout in Hull, scene of earlier violence.\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a Section 34 dispersal notice had been authorised until 10pm yesterday, giving officers extra powers to deal with anyone causing anti-social behaviour.\n\nChief Inspector Natasha Evans said the force was acting to \"prevent serious disruption and ensure everyone can go about their lives without fear or risk of harm\".\n\nMerseyside Police introduced two Section 60 orders in Liverpool and Southport between 2pm yesterday and 2am today, giving officers greater stop-and-search powers.\n\nLast night faith leaders in Merseyside issued a joint statement calling for calm and urging people to hold the families of Southport stabbing victims Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at \"the forefront of all our thoughts\".\n\nThey said: \"Division can destroy the very relationships and environment that we depend upon every day of our lives and there is no place for hate in our communities.\n\n\"It can -- and has -- left communities in fear and has put people in danger. At this difficult time, let us remember that there is far more that unites than divides us.\n\n\"The people of all faiths and none who came out to sweep the streets, to rebuild walls and have so generously donated money in memory of those three girls -- that is the spirit that will help us through this incredibly challenging time.\"\n\nSaturday saw forces pushed to the brink with more than 100 arrests and dozens of \u00adofficers hurt.\n\nTrouble flared in Belfast, Blackpool, Stoke, Leeds, Hull, Manchester, Liverpool, Nottingham, Bristol and Portsmouth.\n\nLast night National Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order, BJ Harrington, said leave had been cancelled by many forces and 4,000 officers put on standby.\n\nMr Harrington warned those involved in disorder: \"Make no mistake, if you haven't had a knock on the door yet, your time will come.\"\n\nHe said fake news inflamed the trouble and urged social media users to be careful what they share, adding: \"Think twice before you act.\"\n\nPolicing minister Dame Diana Johnson suggested courts could sit overnight to ensure \"thugs who maraud our streets\" are brought to justice.\n\nSimilar action was taken in the wake of the 2011 London riots.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper announced new emergency measures to protect mosques.\n\nThose at risk of violent disorder will be offered additional security personnel.\n\nShe said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme.\"", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The US Sun"}, "authors": The anti-immigrant hooligans chanted \"get them out\", \"you're not welcome anymore\" and \"Yorkshire\" as they encouraged each other to attack the hotel.\n\nAnother young group of men held a banner saying: \"Stopping the boats means stopping the stabbings\" and other offensive chants could be heard targeting Muslims and immigrants.\n\nHome secretary condemned the incident in a statement on Twitter and warned those taking part of the repercussions.\n\n\"The criminal, violent attack on a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham is utterly appalling,\" she said. \"Deliberately setting fire to a building with people known to be inside. South Yorkshire Police have full Government support for the strongest action against those responsible.\n\nTensions in Rotherham had been running high earlier in the day as the protesters gathered outside the hotel to be met by anti-racism protesters who chanted \"refugees welcome\". It escalated out of control as the anti-immigrant protesters hurled missiles at the hotel and attacked police officers with pieces of wood and chairs. One officer has been dragged away from the scene with a suspected injury.\n\nRotherham's MP Sarah Champion, said: \"I'm extremely concerned at the escalating violence we are seeing at Holiday Inn, Manvers. The people causing damage and attacking police do not represent our town and I am disgusted by their actions. This is criminal disorder and intimidation - not protest.\"\n\nAnd Shadow home secretary James Cleverly hit out at the scenes, saying: \"There is not and can never be any excuse, justification or rationale for behavior like this.\n\n\"This should be condemned by everybody, and those taking part should expect to be met with the full weight of the law.\"\n\nIt marks another day of far-right violence on the streets of Britain after battles between police and anti-immigrant thugs on Saturday in various cities such as Liverpool, Manchester and Hull.\n\nThe far-right has drawn widespread condemnation after disorder in multiple towns and cities in the wake of the killings of three young girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nFalse claims had spread online that the suspect, later identified as 17-year-old Axel Rudakubana from Lancashire, was an asylum seeker who had arrived in the UK by boat.\n\nSir Keir held crisis talks with ministers on Saturday over the unrest, with Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood telling colleagues \"the whole justice system is ready to deliver convictions as quickly as possible\".\n\nElsewhere, more than 300 members of the far-right started marching through Middlesbrough at 4.25pm after gathering at the city's Cenotaph.\n\nThey carried a banner saying: \"Tom Jones is Welsh, Axel Rudakubana isn't\" and chanted \"We want our country back\" as they made their way through the city centre.\n\nAt one point police used dogs to keep the group back and stop them breaking through and running ahead of the officers patrolling the march.\n\nAt least two people were taken away in handcuffs within the first half hour, while several pieces of slate were thrown, along with vapes and full plastic bottles.\n\nSome people kicked bollards into the road so that police vehicles driving ahead of the group could not get through, and one man sat on the bonnet of a police car to stop it from moving.\n\nBusinesses including McDonald's locked their doors as {"uri": "8258848792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:09:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:09:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:09:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/keir-starmer-condemns-far-right-29675623", "title": "Keir Starmer condemns 'far-right thuggery' after days of violent disorder - Liverpool Echo", "body": "The Prime Minister said: \"This is not a protest, it is organised, violent thuggery\"\n\nSir Keir Starmer condemned \"far-right thuggery\" and said those participating in violence, including those \"whipping up this action online\", would \"regret\" it. The Prime Minister addressed the nation following days of disorder across the UK, including in Liverpool.\n\nViolent disorder took place in Liverpool city centre and in Walton on Saturday, August 3. The staging of a protest at the Pier Head led to scenes of destruction and looting across the city centre before rioters descended on Walton on Saturday evening, causing major damage on County Road in what police described as \"serious violent disorder\".\n\nChaos, violence and destruction followed as looters targeted businesses, bins were used to start fires and the Spellow Library & Community Hub was set alight. The chaos started when people began to assemble near County Road Mosque.\n\nAddressing the nation from Downing Street, the Prime Minister said: \"Be in no doubt, those that have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law. The police will be making arrests. Individuals will be held on remand, charges will follow and convictions will follow.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves. This is not a protest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\"\n\nViolence has also taken place on the streets of Sunderland, Rotherham, Manchester, Belfast and many other cities this week, with ethnic minorities targeted. Sir Keir said he wanted those who \"feel targeted because of the colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country, and we will bring them to justice\".\n\nHe said: \"There is no justification, none, for taking this action. And all right-minded people should be condemning this assault of violence.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe. And yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery. To those who feel targeted because of the colour of your skin or your faith, I know how frightening this must be.\n\n\"I want you to know that this violent mob do not represent our country, and we will bring them to justice. Our police deserve our support as they tackle any and all violent disorder that flares up. Whatever the apparent cause or motive, motivation, we make no distinction: crime is crime, and this Government will tackle it.\"", "source": {"uri": "liverpoolecho.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "PAN PYLAS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLONDON | RIOTING\n\nLONDON -- U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer strongly condemned an attack Sunday on a hotel housing asylum seekers that saw at least 10 police officers injured, one seriously, describing it as \"far-right thuggery,\" as more violence broke out across the country in the wake of a stabbing rampage at a dance class that left three girls dead and many more wounded.\n\nIn a statement from 10 Downing Street on Sunday afternoon, the prime minister vowed that the authorities will \"do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice\" and that justice will be swift.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves,\" he said. \"This is not a protest, it is organized, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nTimeline: Deere has cut 2,700 jobs in 10 months in Iowa and the Year: Jesup's Jack Miller Waterloo man arrested following short chase\n\nStarmer was speaking after another day of far-right violence, which was particularly acute in the north of England town of Rotherham where police struggled to hold back hundreds of rioters who sought to break into a Holiday Inn Express hotel being used as accommodation for asylum seekers.\n\nBefore bringing the riot under some sort of control, police officers with shields had faced a barrage of missiles, including bits of wood, chairs and fire extinguishers. A large bin close to a window of the hotel was also set alight but the small fire was extinguished.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police, which is responsible for Rotherham, said at least 10 officers were injured, including one who was left unconscious.\n\n\"The behavior we witnessed has been nothing short of disgusting. While it was a smaller number of those in attendance who chose to commit violence and destruction, those who simply stood on and watched remain absolutely complicit in this,\" said Assistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield. \"We have officers working hard, reviewing the considerable online imagery and footage of those involved, and they should expect us to be at their doors very soon.\"\n\nFar-right agitators have sought to take advantage of last week's stabbing attack by tapping into concerns about the scale of immigration in the U.K., in particular the tens of thousands of migrants arriving in boats from France. Tensions were also running high Sunday in the northeastern town of Middlesbrough, where some protesters broke free of a police guard. One group walked through a residential area smashing the windows of houses and cars. When asked by a resident why they were breaking windows, one man replied, \"Because we're English.\"\n\nStarmer said anyone targeting people for the color of their skin or their faith is far-right.\n\n\"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques, other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery,\" he Masked rioters threw wooden planks and sprayed fire extinguishers at police officers outside the hotel. A police helicopter hovered above, and at least one injured officer in riot gear was removed from the scene as tensions escalated.\n\nPrime Minister Keir Starmer sharply condemned the attack on the hotel housing asylum seekers on Sunday, denouncing it as \"far-right thuggery\".\n\nThe government pledged tough action against those it said were exploiting the murder of three girls to stir up disorder. Starmer on Sunday pledged to put an end to the ongoing violent protests against immigration, asserting that those responsible will face the full force of the law.\n\n\"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves. This is not a protest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online,\" he added.\n\nTiffany Lynch, from the Police Federation of England and Wales, told the BBC, \"We're seeing officers that are being pulled from day-to-day policing. But while that's happening, the communities that are out there that are having incidents against them -- victims of crime -- unfortunately, their crimes are not being investigated.\"\n\nThe hotel is said to have been used to accommodate migrants, but it is uncertain whether any are still residing there after the previous Conservative government pledged to shut down over a hundred such facilities this year.\n\nAnti-Immigration Protests Hit Parts Of UK\n\nSimilar protests are anticipated in Bolton, Lancaster, Middlesborough, Weymouth, and Newcastle upon Tyne. Since Saturday evening, approximately 150 arrests related to the disorder have been made across England, with the National Police Chiefs' Council expecting the number to increase in the coming days.\n\nOn Saturday, far-right activists clashed with anti-racism protesters throughout the UK, leading to violent incidents in cities including Belfast, Liverpool, and Bristol. Additional arrests are expected as police examine CCTV, social media, and body-worn camera footage.\n\nThe violence erupted after false rumours circulated online claiming that the suspect in the dance {"uri": "2024-08-443872835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:00:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:00:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:51:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/uk-news/chaos-tamworth-far-right-protesters-29676720", "title": "Chaos in Tamworth as far-right protesters set fire to hotel asylum seekers", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth, Staffordshire, became the scene of chaos as a far-right group celebrated while setting fires inside the property amidst violent demonstrations. Dramatic footage captured the moment when yobs smashed their way into the hotel through a window, while onlookers from the far-right crowd cheered as flames took hold within.\n\nAnother fire was seen outside the hotel as rioters hurled missiles into the building. Tension escalated at the hotel following the arrival of numerous protestors earlier in the evening, which resulted in clashes with police officers. The officers moved to disperse the demonstrators from the entrance of the hotel.\n\nIn the midst of the disorder, at least one police dog was present at the scene as authorities attempted to push the crowd away from the hotel, which is currently accommodating asylum seekers.\n\nRead more: Ten people arrested amid protest disorder after clashes in Midlands town\n\nVideos shot by the rioters themselves showed projectiles such as bottles and bricks being thrown towards police lines. Despite the use of riot shields, windows were shattered.\n\nOther footage revealed flares being launched and crowd members confronting police. Officers were also heard repeatedly shouting \"get back\" during the face-off. Another video provided a clearer view of windows that had been shattered at the hotel. The mob did nothing to intervene or confront those who were hurling projectiles.\n\nPolice had put out the fire, it has been confirmed. Graffiti was spotted sprayed on the side reading: \"Get out England (sic).\" Alarms were also heard ringing either inside or near the Holiday Inn as people yelled nearby.\n\nTamworth Police, a division of Staffordshire Police, informed The Mirror: \"A large number of officers are deployed in the area in specialist public order equipment. We are working to balance the right to peaceful protest, reassuring the local community and protecting the public. Robust action will be taken against those responsible for violence and disorder.\"\n\nAn unverified image, thought to depict the same hotel, showed several individuals preparing to enter the building. In the video, one man could be heard saying: \"We've had a f****** nuff haven't we (sic).\"\n\nThe Holiday Inn is the second in the hotel chain to be targeted by far-right mobs today. Earlier today, hooligans targeted a Holiday Inn in Rotherham that also housed asylum seekers. Far-right rioters clashed with police outside the building and were seen throwing projectiles at officers.\n\nA fire was ignited outside a ground-floor window and later, protesters managed to break into the building. South Yorkshire Police reported one arrest on suspicion of public order offences in Rotherham.\n\nA group of men inside the hotel expressed their fear for their lives as the mob attempted to break into the building. They shared with The Mirror that despite fleeing from war zones, they had never experienced such terror. It's estimated that around 235 men have been residing at the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham for as long as seven months. It will involve relevant ministers and police representatives.\n\nSources have suggested this should be seen in the context of meetings that have already taken place, such as one between the prime False rumors about the suspect quickly spread online, fueling an outburst of violence.\n\nOn Sunday, two hotels where asylum seekers are believed to be living, were targeted by mobs in what has turned into the worst disorder the U.K. has seen in years.\n\nIn the northern town of Rotherham, video shared by U.K.'s public broadcaster BBC and Reuters showed protesters, some masked and carrying Union Jack flags, chanting \"get them out\" as they smashed windows of a Holiday Inn Express hotel which was being used to house asylum seekers as people inside looked on with horror.\n\nThe rioters can also be seen setting plastic cans on fire next to the hotel, and hurling planks of wood and profanities at police officers in riot gear on the scene.\n\nThe South Yorkshire police, where Rotherham is, later said its officers were also targeted with glass bottles and beer cans by a crowd of about 700 people. mosques amid nationwide 'far-right thuggery'", "body": "North London will see increased police patrols this week and support for mosques amid a wave of \"violent disorder\" following a stabbing in Southport.\n\nCamden Council is among the local authorities to have addressed the spate of trouble which has erupted since three young girls were killed in the attack last week (July 29).\n\nLeader Richard Oslzewski said that he wanted to reassure local people that the council is \"being vigilant and...taking action\".\n\nHe added that police have stepped up patrols in the borough, particularly around places of worship.\n\nThe council has also written to mosques to remind them how best to report \"any incidents or concerns\".\n\nLeader of Haringey Council, Peray Ahmet, also released a similar statement over the weekend, affirming that \"there is no place for hate in Haringey\".\n\nShe added that she was \"outraged at the wave of violence\" across the country, claiming it is \"tearing communities apart\".\n\nBrent Council leader, Muhammed Butt, said that while the borough had been \"spared specific protests\", the authority understands \"the unease and fear some residents may feel\".\n\nHe urged anyone with concerns to reach out directly to their ward councillor.\n\nThe intervention by senior politicians in north London comes amid a sixth day of disorder.\n\nRiots have been reported in Middlesbrough, Rotherham and Tamworth, with hundreds of arrests made up and down the country.\n\nYesterday evening (August 4), anti-immigration rioters in Rotherham smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nChief of the Defence Staff Admiral Sir Tony Radakin (middle) arriving at colour of their skin\" to know \"this violent mob do not represent our country\".\n\nFormer home secretary Dame Priti Patel also said she would not feel safe in some of the areas that have seen {"uri": "8259094734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:03:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/602122-uk-riots-fire-rotherham/", "title": "WATCH British rioters torch migrant hotel  --  RT World News", "body": "Right-wing protesters in the English town of Rotherham have set fire to a hotel housing asylum seekers, as demonstrations against immigration and Islam continue across the country. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has vowed that the rioters will \"face the full force of the law.\"\n\nHundreds of people gathered outside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham on Sunday afternoon, pelting police officers with wood and bottles and chanting \"get them out,\" referring to the 130 asylum seekers housed in the hotel since 2022.\n\nSouth Yorkshire police said at least ten officers were injured in clashes with the rioters, who broke windows and set dumpsters ablaze outside the building, before setting a fire inside the hotel's ground floor.\n\nMultiple arrests were made, and the fire was extinguished shortly afterwards.\n\nDozens of British towns and cities have been rocked by right-wing protests and riots since Monday, when a British teenager of Rwandan descent stabbed three children to death and injured ten others in the town of Southport, near Liverpool. Although initially sparked by a false rumor that the knifeman responsible for the stabbings was Muslim, the demonstrations have since grown into a wider backlash against Islam, mass immigration, and the perception that political leaders are more concerned with suppressing right-wing dissent than tackling immigrant crime.\n\nMore than 150 people were arrested after riots in Liverpool, Manchester, Stoke, Leeds and other cities on Saturday. Similar riots took place in locations including Middlesbrough, Blackburn, and Tamworth on Sunday. Mobs of Muslim protesters, some armed with knives and machetes, have been seen in some cities, including Bolton and Stoke.\n\nIn a speech on Sunday, Starmer warned that more arrests would follow. \"Those who have participated in this violence will face the full force of the law,\" he declared, warning that those responsible \"will regret taking part in this disorder.\" In Sunday's address and in a similar speech earlier this week, Starmer did not discuss any of the root causes of the unrest. Instead he pinned all blame for the violence on \"far right hatred\" and online \"misinformation.\"\n\nRotherham is infamous for its Muslim 'grooming gang', a group of predominantly British-Pakistani men who sexually abused around 1,400 young girls between the late 1980s and 2013. Three separate reports published in 2013, 2014, and 2015 found that local politicians and police covered up the gang's crimes, partly out of fear that identifying and punishing the perpetrators would The violence followed the stabbing of three young girls in Southport earlier in the week. Far-right groups have exploited the incident, spreading false claims about the attacker's immigration status to incite anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant sentiment. Authorities confirm the suspect is British-born.Thank you for reading this post, don't forget to subscribe!\n\nFootage verified by CNN shows protesters attacking two Holiday Inns: one in Tamworth, previously criticized by a local politician for housing asylum seekers, and another in Rotherham. In Tamworth, rioters threw projectiles, smashed windows, and started fires, injuring one police officer. In Rotherham, protesters used fire extinguishers against officers, set fires near the hotel, and smashed windows to enter the building, which was occupied by terrified residents and staff.\n\nBritish Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the violence, calling it \"far-right thuggery\" and emphasizing that those involved will face legal consequences. At least 147 people have been arrested since Saturday night.\n\nUK Policing Minister Dame Diana Johnson announced a \"nick them quick\" approach for handling rioters but stated there is currently no need for military intervention. She emphasized that the police have sufficient resources and support.\n\nThe unrest, the worst since the 2011 riots, presents a significant challenge to the Labour government of Keir Starmer.
