"https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13710135/Met-Police-boss-Sir-Mark-Rowley-grabs-microphone-grilled-two-tier-policing-storms-emergency-COBRA-meeting-Keir-Starmer-scrambles-contain-riots-hundreds-far-right-thugs-arrested-Britain.html", "title": "Met Police boss grabs microphone when grilled over 'two-tier policing'", "body": "Met Police boss Sir Mark Rowley grabbed a microphone as he left emergency talks this morning as the Government scrambles to contain widespread riots.\n\nAs he exited the Cabinet Office, the Scotland Yard chief was asked whether he was 'going to end two-tier policing'.\n\nIn astonishing footage, Sir Mark was then shown grabbing and clutching the microphone before letting it go and heading towards a waiting car.\n\nThe Met Police Commissioner was described as reacting 'angrily' to the question in a 'quite surprising' response from Britain's most senior police officer.\n\nIt came after Sir Keir Starmer chaired an emergency Cobra meeting following a fresh night of rioting across the UK.\n\nThe Prime Minister and other senior ministers met with police chiefs and prison bosses in response to the violence being waged by far-right thugs.\n\nThey updated on efforts to deploy officers to trouble hotspots, to boost court capacity and to tackle online criminality and misinformation.\n\n'Two-tier policing' is a phrase used to described an impression that some protests are dealt with more harshly than others.\n\nA narrative of 'politicised' or 'two-tier policing' has been pushed by far-right figures, including England Defence League founder Tommy Robinson.\n\nMet Police boss Sir Mark Rowley grabbed a microphone as he left emergency talks this morning as the Government scrambles to contain widespread riots\n\nAs he exited the Cabinet Office, the Scotland Yard chief was asked whether he was 'going to end two-tier policing'\n\nThe PM's official spokesman said Sir Keir 'wouldn't recognise that characterisation of policing', although noted he had not seen the incident involving Sir Mark.\n\n'There is no justification at all for the scenes we have seen,' the spokesman added.\n\nDuring the Cobra meeting, the PM paid 'tribute to hard work of police officers and sent best wishes to those who have been injured protecting our streets', Downing Street said.\n\nHundreds of far right thugs have been arrested in riots, which saw attacks on police and buildings set alight on the sixth day of escalating disorder.\n\nSir Keir has vowed rioters would 'regret' engaging in 'far-right thuggery' and promised those involved in unrest would 'face the full force of the law' as he addressed the nation on Sunday.\n\nMonday's Cobra meeting involved relevant ministers and police representatives who discussed the response in the coming days to ensure Britain is brought back from the edge of nationwide chaos.\n\nShadow Home Secretary James Cleverly said this week's violence is 'clearly far-right extremism' that is 'driven by racism' and said he would have called a Cobra meeting sooner.\n\nRiots have broken out across the country fuelled by misinformation on social media since three little girls were stabbed to death at a Taylor Swift themed dance class in Southport on Monday.\n\nHundreds of police officers have been injured in clashes with thugs, as far-right activists led the way in attacking police officers, mosques and hotels thought to house asylum seekers this week.\n\nIslamophobic chants were heard and in some areas of the country rioters were filmed stopping cars and interrogating drivers about whether they were 'white and English'.\n\nSpeaking ahead of the Cobra meeting, the Home Secretary said the Government is not recalling Parliament 'right now': 'That's not what we're doing right now. What we're doing right now is keeping in close contact with MPs.'\n\nCommunities are now coming together to begin the massive clean-up operation in areas including Rotherham, Middlesbrough and Tamworth.\n\nScenes after last night's riots in Middlesbrough saw burnt out cars and debris scattered across the town\n\nFires in Middlesbrough caused serious damage to homes and businesses over the weekend\n\nRacist graffiti was pictured in Tamworth this morning with phrases 'Get out England' and 'F*** P****'\n\nHundreds of police officers have been injured in clashes with thugs, as far-right activists led the way in attacking police officers, mosques and hotels thought to house asylum seekers this week\n\nIslamophobic chants were heard and in some areas of the country rioters were filmed stopping cars and interrogating drivers about whether they were 'white and English'\n\nFar-right protests spread across much of England and into Northern Ireland after the deaths of three little girls, fuelled by false information on social media (Pictured: Attendees confront police in Belfast)\n\nOutside hotels in the north of England, thugs tried to force their way inside and threw chairs, bins and bricks\n\nShadow Home Secretary James Cleverly condemned arson attacks on hotels on Sky News this morning\n\nHundreds of arrests have been made and many officers injured, with some having t be taken to hospital\n\nRiots spread from Southport across the country last week in horror scenes that have terrified communities\n\nIn response to the violence, the Home Office announced on Sunday that mosques would be offered greater protection under a new 'rapid response process' designed to quickly tackle the threat of further attacks on places of worship.\n\nPolice crack down on suspected rioters\n\nPolice have today announced a number of arrests and charges against those suspected in participating in riots over the past week.\n\nBelfast\n\nA 53-year-old has been charged with assaulting police, resisting police and disorderly behaviour.\n\nA 46-year-old man has also been charged with resisting police and disorderly behaviour.\n\nA 38-year-old man has been charged with possession of an offensive weapon with intent to commit an indictable offence, possession of fireworks without a licence, riotous behaviour and disorderly behaviour.\n\nA 34-year-old man has been charged with taking part in an unnotified public procession.\n\nBristol\n\nAdrian Croft, 45, of Holywell, Flintshire, was charged with a Section 4 public order offence and possession of a Class A drug.\n\nDamien Williams, 39, of Stockwood Crescent, Knowle, was charged with a Section 4 public order offence.\n\nBoth men have been bailed and will appear at Bristol Magistrates' Court on Thursday September 5.\n\nLiverpool\n\nGareth Metcalfe, 44, and John O'Malley, 43, both of Cambridge Gardens in Southport, have been charged with violent disorder after a group was seen showing aggression towards police last Tuesday.\n\nA 14-year-old boy from Toxteth, has been charged with violent disorder in Liverpool city centre on Saturday after officers in Clayton Square had fireworks set off in their direction.\n\nAdam Wharton, 28, and Ellis Wharton, 22, Walton, have both been charged with burglary other than a dwelling after a group entered the Spellow Hub library on County Road on Saturday.\n\nAdam Wharton indicated a guilty plea and will be sentenced on August 29.\n\nEllis Wharton was also charged with assault on an emergency worker.\n\nSunderland\n\nJosh Kellett, 29, of Southcroft, Washington, admitted violent disorder at South Tyneside Magistrates Court on Monday.\n\nKellett was remanded in custody until his sentencing at crown court on September 2, after a district judge said his case was 'too serious for this court'.\n\nAndrew Smith, 41, also pleaded guilty to violent disorder and has been remanded in custody until the same date.\n\nShaun Doran, 48, of Sunderland, pleaded not guilty to the same offence.\n\nClinton Morrison, 31, of Sunderland, was remanded in custody today after being accused of violent disorder - he did not make a plea.\n\nA date for a crown court hearing was set for September 2.\n\nWeymouth\n\nThree people were arrested and dispersal orders put in place for several teenagers.\n\nA 42-year-old man from Yeovil was arrested on suspicion of a public order offence, a 62-year-old man from Yeovil was arrested for being drunk and disorderly and a 27-year-old man from Weymouth was arrested for assault.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA large crowd gathered outside a mosque in Middlesbrough on Sunday night and others have also been targeted.\n\nOn Saturday night Spellow Lane Library in Liverpool was torched while in Sunderland local travel agents Hays Travel, known for its commitment to raising money for charity, had its storefront smashed.\n\nIn Rotherham, anti-immigration rioters smashed the windows of the Holiday Inn Express before starting fires in an apparent attempt to set the building alight while dozens of people were inside it.\n\nAt least 10 officers were injured there, including one who was knocked unconscious, South Yorkshire Police confirmed later, saying one person had already been arrested and others involved should 'expect us to be at their doors very soon'.\n\nMasked men hurled lengths of wood, chairs and bottles, and sprayed fire extinguishers at officers outside after some 700 people gathered.\n\nIslamophobic and racist chants were heard at multiple riots across the country, with images appearing to show some members of the mobs performing Nazi salutes.\n\nA similar incident played out at a Holiday Inn hotel in Tamworth into Sunday evening, where reports suggested asylum seekers were also being housed.\n\nPeople threw projectiles, smashed windows, started fires and targeted officers, Staffordshire Police said.\n\nA group of rioters in Middlesbrough smashed the windows of houses and cars and threw objects at officers on Sunday afternoon, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: 'It's our f****** country.'\n\nVideo footage showed groups of youths and young men running from house to house and smashing windows and cars parked outside, throwing bricks, traffic cones and other objects.\n\nYouths also appeared to loot a branch of Iceland, with one teenager running out triumphantly while holding a bottle of Friji.\n\nAnd footage from a local park appeared to show a group of white men and boys with faces covered surrounding and attacking a group, with violence erupting before they fled the scene.\n\nNearby, a Muslim leader at a mosque told community members who had turned out to protect their place of worship to 'show the world what Muslims are really like'.\n\nAddressing far-right violence in the town, he said: 'They are doing all the wrong things. We don't want to be part of it.'\n\nOther local Muslims were seen carrying tea and coffee to police officers on the front line of the town amid fierce violence from the far-right.\n\nThere were 43 arrests, and significant damage was caused to the Crown Court and the University, Cleveland Police said.\n\nGreater Manchester Police issued a Section 60AA order amid disturbances in Bolton, requiring people to 'remove face coverings used to disguise or conceal their appearance'.\n\nAnd in Weymouth, police said three people were arrested and dispersal orders put in place for several teenagers.\n\nA 42-year-old man from Yeovil was arrested on suspicion of a public order offence, a 62-year-old man from Yeovil was arrested for being drunk and disorderly and a 27-year-old man from Weymouth was arrested for assault.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Mark Callaghan said two officers were injured - one when a bottle his them in the face and a second who was punched in the head.\n\nHe said: 'There were rumours circulating that asylum seekers currently housed on the Bibby Stockholm would be moved to Portland, Weymouth or the wider Dorset Council area but the Home Office have confirmed this is not the case.\n\n'In addition, there are no asylum seekers housed in hotels in the Weymouth area.'\n\nHundreds of people came together in Middlesbrough on Monday to begin a huge clean-up operation\n\nLocal people in Middlesbrough clear broken glass and other hazards from the scene\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper appeared on the media round this morning as she condemned far-right violence\n\nRiot police officers push back violent far-right activists outside the Holiday Inn Express Hotel after attempts were made to set fire to it - with dozens thought to be inside at the time\n\nRioters attacked police officers in Rotherham on Sunday as far-right thugs led unrest\n\nThugs in balaclavas hurled chairs, wood and bricks at hotels on Sunday, causing thousands of pounds of damage\n\nAt one of the hotels attacked on Sunday the damage was clear to see once far-right thugs had left the scene\n\nSerious damage has been done to buildings including hotels, libraries, local shops and homes since disorder started last week\n\nA police dog handler during the far-right demonstration outside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham\n\nThe widespread unrest poses the biggest challenge yet to Sir Keir's premiership, with MPs including Ian Byrne and Dame Priti Patel saying Parliament should be recalled as it was in 2011 so the Commons could debate the riots.\n\nThe race riots have spread from Southport to cities including London, Leeds, Rotherham, Manchester, Blackbool, Belfast and Aldershot.\n\nIt comes after Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said there would be a 'reckoning' following unrest across England, as she pledged that anyone involved in the riots will 'pay the price'.\n\nShe told Sky News: 'It's a total disgrace and there has to be a reckoning. Those individuals who are involved in the disorder need to know that they will pay a price.'\n\n'I've made clear to the police they have my full support in going after the full range of offenders, from those who turned up at the last minute and joined in the looting, to some of the most serious offenders who were pursuing really dangerous arson, really dangerous damage and criminal violence, because we simply cannot stand for this.\n\n'So we should be clear, there will be people who were thinking they were going on their summer holidays this week, and instead they will face a knock on the door from the police.\n\n'They will face arrest and... a police cell, while they wait for trial in order to make sure that they do pay the price for what they have done,' she added.\n\nMs Cooper claimed that social media has put 'rocket boosters' under far-right organisations.\n\nBut she said the courts are on 'stand-by' to ensure 'swift justice': 'We have made sure that the courts are on stand-by. We've made sure that there are additional prosecutors in place this weekend, and hundreds of arrests have already taken place. So we do expect swift justice to take place.'\n\nScenes in Middlesbrough on Monday morning after residents wake up to the after-effects of rioting\n\nResidents saw their car windows smashed and businesses suffered attacks including arson\n\nAsked if the Army would be called upon, Ms Cooper said: 'So, the police have the expertise and also the powers in terms of dealing with public order and crime, because this is crime.\n\n'There are also significant additional numbers of public order-trained police, who were not deployed this weekend, so there are considerable additional policing resources that forces can call upon.'\n\nPressed on whether the Government will take action against Tommy Robinson, who has been accused of stoking tensions from afar, Ms Cooper said: 'If it's a crime offline, it's a crime online.'\n\n'You can't just have the the armchair thuggery or the people being able to incite and organise violence and also not face consequences for this,' she added.\n\nShadow Secretary James Cleverly said: 'The things that we have seen are completely unjustified. These are the actions of people who are clearly responding to disinformation online but are obviously motivated by racism.\n\n'We've seen people with Swastika tattoos and making the Nazi salute... attacking people who have no link at all to the terrible incidents that we saw in Southport last week and it is absolutely right that the government is taking firm action.\n\n'When you've people giving Nazi salutes with Swastika tattoos that is clearly far-right extremism.\n\n'It's clearly these attacks on mosques on hotels these are clearly driven by racism and should be unequivocally condemned.'\n\nBut he also criticised Starmer's new government for not reacting quickly enough: 'They could and should have been quicker, it's worrying that it's only today that cobra is meeting.\n\nA masked thug faces off with police officers at the Holiday Inn in Rotherham while fire rages in the background\n\nMembers of the public with bin bags, dustpans and brushes took to the streets today\n\nVolunteers pick up rubbish and debris from outside the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham\n\nRacist graffiti was daubed on the side of the hotel in Tamworth and windows and doors were smashed before thugs attempted to set the building on fire with people still inside\n\nOne man was filmed threatening to slit the throats of those inside the hotel\n\n'We want to support the government taking firm action against this violence but they have to move much more quickly and they have to be more agile, more decisive. Had I still be Home Secretary I would have called a Cobra much earlier than this.'\n\nHe continued: 'I'm really uncomfortable with the idea that somehow this violence reflects a wider national move. This is a group of extreme people.\n\n'People committing arson, attacking mosques, targeting asylum hotels, they are not reflective of the country. This is a generous and open hearted country. The people in this country are not represented by the thugs that are attacking people, committing arson and targeting places of worship.'\n\nThe former first minister of Scotland Humza Yousaf said the army should be called in to stop 'thugs' causing disorder on the streets.\n\nMinisters have so far insisted police have the resources required to respond and have rejected calls to bring in the army.\n\nSir Keir said he wanted those who 'feel targeted because of the colour of their skin' to know 'this violent mob do not represent our country'.\n\nIn his message to rioters, the Prime Minister said: 'I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.'\n\nDame Sara Khan, who was Rishi Sunak's independent adviser for social cohesion and resilience until May, blamed the Conservative government for leaving the country open to far-right violence.\n\n'The writing was clearly on the wall for some time,' she told the Guardian.\n\nWriting in The Times, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said 'there will be reckoning' for people who took part in the unrest and those who 'whipped them up on social media and in online chat forums'.\n\n'Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities,' she said.\n\n'They are thugs, criminals and extremists who betray the values our country is built on.'\n\nShe said those responsible would be 'paying the price for years to come'.\n\nMs Cooper slammed actions taken by rioters this week after more than 420 people were arrested, as she warned 'many more will follow' as authorities scour CCTV footage to identify all those involved.\n\nClashes, sparked by the murder of three little girls in Southport last Monday, deteriorated further yesterday when a second migrant hotel was set ablaze in Tamworth, while hundreds cheered and clinked beers outside.\n\nIn Middlesbrough far-right yobs were filmed stopping traffic to interrogate the passengers to check they were 'white and English'.\n\nKeir Starmer also waded in to warn far-Right rioters 'you'll regret taking part' as he tried to stamp his authority over the first major test of his Premiership.\n\nHe blasted 'far-Right thuggery', for which he promised swift justice as he is expected to call a COBRA meeting today.\n\nMeanwhile, the Tories were forced to reprimanded Shadow Wales Secretary Lord Davies of Gower after The Mail on Sunday columnist Dan Hodges said there was 'no political justification' for the riots and Lord Davies retorted: 'Labour blocked the Rwanda Bill 130+ times, of course it's politically justified!'\n\nThis comes as:\n\nRioters descend on second migrant hotel as far-right mob try to set fire to Holiday Inn housing asylum seekers in TamworthTommy Robinson suns himself at an all-inclusive five-star hotel in Cyprus while his foot soldiers run riot in violent protests The Tory Police and Crime Commissioner claimed far-right protesters are trying to 'protect Britain's sovereignty and identity' Malaysia becomes the first country issues warning over travelling to the UK amid the violent protests The Tories were forced to reprimanded Shadow Wales Secretary after he justified the rioting by saying: 'Labour blocked the Rwanda Bill 130+ times, of course it's politically justified!'\n\nROTHERHAM: Police defend themselves as far-right thugs launch planks of wood on Sunday\n\nROTHERHAM: Violent thugs yesterday attacked a hotel reported to be housing asylum seekers\n\nROTHERHAM: A rioter throws blocks of concrete towards a hotel on Sunday\n\nThis came after Tommy Robinson posted a video of a confrontation in Stoke and falsely claimed two 'protesters' had been stabbed 'by Muslims'. The post was viewed two million times on X.\n\nTwo hours later, Staffordshire Police confirmed the information was false. Those injured were hit by something thrown by their own side.\n\nRead MoreEXCLUSIVE Tommy Robinson suns himself at an all-inclusive five-star hotel in Cyprus while followers run riot\n\nActor Laurence Fox has also shared a string of false claims. On Friday night, he posted a list of dozens of acts of violence he alleged had been committed by immigrants under the caption: 'Anyone else had enough?'\n\nAmong them was the claim that a 'woman [was] beaten to death by two Somalis while walking her dog' - understood to have been a reference to last month's murder of Anita Rose, 57, in Brantham, Suffolk.\n\nThree people have been arrested in connection with the murder, but Suffolk Police last night confirmed Fox's tweet was not correct.\n\nHundreds of people gathered as a group of masked thugs threw a burning bush inside the side entrance of the Hotel Inn Express, Leisure Island, in Tamworth yesterday evening.\n\n'Get out England' was graffitied on the side of the building, as police worked to extinguish the fire inside the hotel's stairwell.\n\nSome people could be heard chanting 'England, England, England,' while others threw objects at police and set off flares and fireworks. One man could be seen running towards police with what appeared to be a large speaker.\n\nOfficers clad in riot gear were seen standing in a line guarding the entrance to the hotel. One police officer has suffered a suspected broken arm.\n\nPolice have said the violent disorder has been 'successfully dispersed' as they appeal to anyone with information to help identify those responsible.\n\nA group of protesters were kept apart from counter protesters in Bolton this afternoon\n\nA fire extinguisher is sprayed at riot police in Rotherham\n\nProperty is vandalised as far-right activists in Middlesbrough\n\nThugs try to cram into the migrant hotel through a damaged fire exit in Rotherham\n\nROTHERHAM: Police have been trying to fend off agitators outside the hotel yesterday\n\nYvette Cooper slammed actions taken by rioters this week, as more than 420 people have been arrested, warning 'many more will follow' as authorities scour CCTV footage for criminals\n\nStarmer blasted 'far-Right thuggery', for which he promised swift justice amid another day of violent scenes nationwide.\n\nHe is today expected to hold an emergency COBRA Cabinet meeting, attended by police chiefs, in a bid to ensure the crisis does not spiral further out of control.\n\nHe also opened the door yesterday to tougher sentences to act as a 'deterrent', saying he will do 'whatever it takes' to crack down on the violence. He said the sentences would mirror action taken to deal with thuggery during the 2011 riots, when he was Director of Public Prosecutions.\n\nRead More Rioters descend on second migrant hotel in Tamworth\n\nAn asylum seeker who was staying at the Holiday Inn in Tamworth when it was set alight, told the Times of his terror as he was beaten up by the mob when they broke in.\n\n'They came onto this floor and hit me until the police drove them down the corridor.'\n\nWhile another 55-year-old Palestinian said his window was pelted with rocks thrown at his window.\n\n'I was taking some tea when they ran down shouting f***, f***, f***. A shirtless man was shouting and making so much noise. They broke the windows. There were eight on my floor.'\n\nWhile John Woodcock, a former Labour MP, called for MI6, MI5 and GCHQ to be given additional powers that would allow them to ask social media firms to take down accounts that try to 'fan the flames of British extreme actors'.\n\nMalaysia has become the first country to warn its citizens about the dangers of visiting Britain at the moment.\n\nThe statement released by Malaysia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said: 'Malaysians residing in or travelling to the United Kingdom are urged to stay away from protest areas, remain vigilant and follow the latest updates and guidance provided by local authorities.'\n\nMore than 300 started marching through Middlesbrough after gathering at the city's Cenotaph.\n\nThe thugs chanted 'We want our country back' as they made their way through the city centre, before at least two people were taken away in handcuffs.\n\nPolice officers stand near the broken windows of the hotel during an anti-immigration riot\n\nROTHERHAM: Police try to control the deplorable violence after a mob attacked a hotel\n\nA thug throws a brick at a parked car during an anti-immigration riot in Middlesbrough\n\nPolice have said that there was a 'staggering' surge of violence which led to 35 people being arrested in Middlesbrough on Sunday.\n\nRioters smashed the windows of houses and cars and hurled objects at officers, with one seen shouting a racial slur and another telling police: 'It's our f****** country.'\n\nThere was significant damage to the crown court, the university and a number of properties in the Parliament Road area.\n\nCleveland Police said it has now arrested 55 people because of the violence that has swept across Teesside as 20 suspects were also arrested after rioting in Hartlepool on Wednesday.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable David Felton said: 'The level of violence we have seen today is staggering.\n\n'We know the shocking scenes across Middlesbrough today will have caused alarm amongst communities.\n\n'I want to reassure the people of Teesside that we will continue to identify those involved in these acts of violence and arrest them and put them before the courts.'\n\nAt one point police used dogs to keep the group back and stop them breaking through and running ahead of the officers patrolling the march. Several pieces of slate were also thrown, along with vapes and full plastic bottles.\n\nSome people kicked bollards into the road so that police vehicles driving ahead of the group could not get through, and one man sat on the bonnet of a police car to stop it moving.\n\nIn Bolton, Greater Manchester, violent clashes between rioters and police broke out, with footage showing the activists pushing against officers who had formed a human barricade.\n\nThere was also an counter protest in Bolton, where it was reported that large groups of Asian men could be heard shouting 'Allahu Akbar' as they clashed with the far-right.\n\nLast night experts condemned the 'dangerous' behaviour and also called for stricter action against those spreading misinformation.\n\nFestus Akinbusoye, a former police and crime commissioner, said: 'Of course there are discussions to be had about the level of immigration, the type of immigration and issues like integration.\n\n'But misinformation and xenophobic narratives are wrong, irresponsible and dangerous. These actions are having real world consequences and the people spreading dangerous lies need to be brought to book.'\n\nMIDDLESBROUGH: A car burns on Parliament Road after it was set alight by far-right thugs\n\nMIDDLESBROUGH: Police raced off with far-right agitators on Parliament Road yesterday\n\nA man is detained as Far-right activists hold a demonstration in Middlesbrough\n\nAn thug wearing a Union Jack mask outside of the Holiday Inn Express\n\nAn aerial view of the rioters gathering outside of the Holiday Inn Express\n\nCounter-protesters shout at police officers as they push against a cordon in Bolton\n\nObjects thrown at the hotel as trouble flares during an anti-immigration attack outside the Holiday Inn Express\n\nLIVERPOOL: Police officers attend to a shell-shocked colleague after a face-off with thugs on Saturday\n\nMr Akinbusoye, who was Britain's first black PCC, added: 'Our entire criminal justice system is going to have to be revisited in terms of how the authorities are going to be able to legitimately counter and pre-empt these narratives.\n\n'I understand that police forces need to be careful about what they put into the public domain but they need to... publish safe information whenever possible.'\n\nTory leadership hopeful Mel Stride said the scrapping of pilots of rapid-response police units, introduced by the Tories last March, may make it harder to tackle the current disorder.\n\nIt comes after an angry far-right mob stormed into a hotel in Rotherham yesterday, hurling chairs and spraying fire extinguishers at riot police, while setting bins, a generator and furniture alight.\n\nAround 700 violent thugs clad in balaclavas and draped in St George's flags clashed with officers trying to protect the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, South Yorkshire since around 2pm this afternoon.\n\nAt least 10 officers have been injured in the chaos outside the hotel on the northern outskirts of the post-industrial town. One was left unconscious following a head injury, another suffered a suspected fractured elbow and other suspected broken bones.\n\nIt marks yet another day of violent riots of Britain's streets, with crowds in Middlesbrough setting fire to a car and pushing burning wheelie bins at police, while thugs in Rotherham smash windows and doors as riot police use shields to push them back.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Police said one person has been arrested on suspicion of public order offences.\n\nSimilar scenes could be seen in Weymouth, as around 400 protesters from opposing sides gathered on the seafront to chant at each other. At least one officer in riot gear was carried away by his colleagues.\n\nOne person was fully covered in a Union Jack mask as he waved a large English flag outside the hotel, while others waved cans of beer inside and chanted offensive slogans.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Mayor Oliver Coppard said he was \"deeply shocked by the violence\" in Rotherham.\n\n\"What we are seeing is not a protest, but brutal violence targeting some of the most vulnerable people in our society,\" he said in a statement.\n\nProtesters in Rotherham. Rudakubana has since been charged with murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe misinformation sparked far-right protests across the country, with violence breaking out last night in Hull, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast - with many police forces pushed to the limit.\n\nMeanwhile, as rioters tore through Sunderland on Friday night, the crowd of protesters attacked the Masjid E Anwaar E Madinah mosque.\n\nSunderland Church leader Zaf Iqbal and three other people had to lock themselves in the place of worship to avoid the dangerous crowds outside.\n\nSpeak with the BBChe burst into tears as he recalled the \"very frightening\" ordeal.\n\nZaf Iqbal (pictured), a taxi driver and co-chair of the Sunderland Interfaith Forum, says the riots in Sunderland have left members of the Muslim community terrified and unwilling to leave their homes.\n\nHe said: \"We had to close the mosques on Friday night and could not continue our normal activities because we did not want our elderly to be put at risk.\n\n\"It's very scary because you have a mob attacking a building that is a place of worship. Like a church or a Sikh Gurdwara or a Hindu temple.\"\n\nShocking images from outside the mosque show mounted police officers trying to keep the rioters at bay.\n\nMr Iqbal said Friday night's events had left some Muslims in the area too scared to leave their homes. {"uri": "2024-08-444167547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:58:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:58:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:50:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/another-night-of-chaos-as-hundreds-of-individuals-attack-police-with-bricks-and-petrol-bomb-a-hotel-in-uk-cities/", "title": "Another night of chaos as hundreds of individuals attack police with bricks and petrol bomb a hotel in UK cities. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "THUGS petrol bombed a migrant hotel last night as chaos descended on UK cities for another day of carnage.\n\nRiot cops guarding Holiday Inns in Rotherham and Tamworth, Staffs, were targeted by yobs who lit fires and threw missiles during violent clashes in numerous UK towns and cities.\n\nRioting broke out across the UK this week fuelled by online lies following the murders of three girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nPosts wrongly claimed suspect Axel Rudakubana, 17, was a Muslim asylum seeker. He was actually born in Cardiff and raised Christian.\n\nTerrifying days of violence followed the attack in Southport, before spreading to Hartlepool and Manchester on Wednesday, Sunderland and Blackpool on Friday then 11 more cities by Saturday.\n\nFootage from Rotherham on Sunday showed masked yobs kicking out windows to storm the \u00adHoliday Inn Express, which houses migrants.\n\nAnother Holiday Inn where asylum seekers are thought to stay was petrol bombed in Tamworth, Staffordshire, as those inside watched through windows.\n\nMeanwhile, in Weymouth cops were tasked with keeping protesters and counter-protesters separate along the beach. Cops confirmed two officers were injured, one hit in the face with a bottle while the other was punched.\n\nThe thugs in Rotherham forced their way past cops into the hotel after pelting them with bricks, glass \u00adbottles and even fence panels. Some then hurled chairs.\n\nA towering blaze broke out as the group of 700 outside the hotel chanted: \"Get them out.\"\n\nOne injured cop was seen being carried to safety by colleagues.\n\nCops later confirmed at least 10 were injured, including an officer who was knocked unconscious, another who suffered a suspected broken elbow and another suffering from suspected broken bones.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield said: \"Today in Rotherham we have seen our officers attacked and at least ten injured, significant damage caused and a fire set outside a hotel full of terrified residents and staff.\n\n\"The behaviour we witnessed has been nothing short of disgusting.\"\n\nLater in the night hundreds descended on the Holiday Inn in Tamworth, where three petrol bombs were used to start \"a series of fires,\" according to Staffordshire Police.\n\nFootage shared widely online showed a towering blaze ignite inside a smashed window of the hotel.\n\nOfficers were assaulted, with one left with a suspected broken arm.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Stuart Ellison said: \"The senseless violence and acts of despicable thuggery in Tamworth tonight are completely inexcusable. The local community do not deserve to be subject to this behaviour, and neither do the brave officers putting themselves in harm's way to keep everyone safe.\"\n\nMeanwhile another migrant hotel, this time in Aldershot, was also targeted.\n\nA group of men outside Potters International Hotel brandished a banner insisting: \"We're not far right, we're just right.\"\n\nBy 6.45pm a crowd of some 200 \"got involved in criminal activity, throwing objects and subjecting people to racist abuse,\" according to Hampshire Police.\n\nThe force confirmed five men were arrested aged 32, 25, 18, 28 and 60.\n\nAt Middlesbrough's Cenotaph, hundreds of protesters squared up to police before throwing slate, cans and pots at the officers.\n\nA group of masked yobs walked through a residential area using metal bars and wooden posts to smash car windscreens and the windows of terraced houses.\n\nVehicles were torched, along with wheelie bins.\n\nOne victim, a white man in his 40s who did not want to be named, said: \"I'm born and bred in Middlesbrough and these morons target my house just for the hell of it. I could hear them yelling about immigrants, but they were smashing cars and house windows indiscriminately.\n\n\"They're the scum of the earth.\"\n\nCleveland Police confirmed \u00ad43 people were arrested by 1.28am on Monday, adding: \"A full investigation is now underway.\"\n\nACC David Felton, said: \"The level of violence we have seen today is staggering. We know the shocking scenes across Middlesbrough today will have caused alarm amongst communities.\n\n\"I want to reassure the people of Teesside that we will continue to identify those involved in these acts of violence and arrest them and put them before the courts.\"\n\nIn the centre of Bolton, large crowds of anti-immigration demonstrators gathered along with \u00adcounter-protesters while police tried to keep them apart.\n\nAn anti-immigrant rally on Weymouth seafront was met by a counter-protest.\n\nThree men, aged 42, 62 and 27, were arrested trying to break through police lines.\n\nAssistant Chief Constable Mark Callaghan said: \"There were rumours circulating that asylum seekers currently housed on the Bibby Stockholm would be moved to Portland, Weymouth or the wider Dorset Council area but the Home Office have confirmed this is not the case. In addition, there are no asylum seekers housed in hotels in the Weymouth area.\"\n\nThere was a large turnout in Hull, scene of earlier violence.\n\nGreater Manchester Police said a Section 34 dispersal notice had been authorised until 10pm yesterday, giving officers extra powers to deal with anyone causing anti-social behaviour.\n\nChief Inspector Natasha Evans said the force was acting to \"prevent serious disruption and ensure everyone can go about their lives without fear or risk of harm\".\n\nMerseyside Police introduced two Section 60 orders in Liverpool and Southport between 2pm yesterday and 2am today, giving officers greater stop-and-search powers.\n\nLast night faith leaders in Merseyside issued a joint statement calling for calm and urging people to hold the families of Southport stabbing victims Alice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, at \"the forefront of all our thoughts\".\n\nThey said: \"Division can destroy the very relationships and environment that we depend upon every day of our lives and there is no place for hate in our communities.\n\n\"It can -- and has -- left communities in fear and has put people in danger. At this difficult time, let us remember that there is far more that unites than divides us.\n\n\"The people of all faiths and none who came out to sweep the streets, to rebuild walls and have so generously donated money in memory of those three girls -- that is the spirit that will help us through this incredibly challenging time.\"\n\nSince the horror a week ago, the country has been plagued by riots.\n\nOn Wednesday, 111 people were arrested in London and 11 more in Hartlepool, two in Manchester and two in Aldershot.\n\nOn Friday, violence erupted outside a Liverpool mosque.\n\nSaturday saw forces pushed to the brink with more than 100 arrests and dozens of \u00adofficers hurt.\n\nTrouble flared in Belfast, Blackpool, Stoke, Leeds, Hull, Manchester, Liverpool, Nottingham, Bristol and Portsmouth.\n\nLast night National Police Chiefs' Council lead for public order, BJ Harrington, said leave had been cancelled by many forces and 4,000 officers put on standby.\n\nMr Harrington warned those involved in disorder: \"Make no mistake, if you haven't had a knock on the door yet, your time will come.\"\n\nHe said fake news inflamed the trouble and urged social media users to be careful what they share, adding: \"Think twice before you act.\"\n\nPolicing minister Dame Diana Johnson suggested courts could sit overnight to ensure \"thugs who maraud our streets\" are brought to justice.\n\nSimilar action was taken in the wake of the 2011 London riots.\n\nIn a hard-hitting message from Downing Street, the PM said: \"I guarantee you will regret taking part in this disorder, whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves.\"\n\nHe went on: \"This is not a \u00adprotest, it is organised, violent thuggery and it has no place on our streets or online.\n\n\"All right-minded people should be condemning this sort of violence. People in this country have a right to be safe.\n\n\"And yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: Far-right thuggery.\"\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper announced new emergency measures to protect mosques.\n\nThose at risk of violent disorder will be offered additional security personnel.\n\nShe said: \"Britain is a proud and tolerant country, and nobody should make any excuses for the shameful actions of the hooligans, thugs and extremist groups who have been attacking police officers, looting local shops or attacking people based on the colour of their skin.\n\n\"In light of the disgraceful threats and attacks that local mosques have also faced in many communities, the Government is providing rapid additional support through the Protective Security for Mosques Scheme.\"", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asylum_seeker", travel warning issued as violent riots continue", "body": "Angry mobs went on the rampage in a third day of shameful violence yesterday, even trying to torch a hotel housing migrant families.\n\nThose disgraceful scenes broke out in Rotherham, leaving at least ten police injured, with trouble also flaring in Tamworth, Middlesbrough and Bolton.\n\nThey came after Saturday saw rioters wreak havoc across the country, with running battles between the far-Right and police before looting broke out and even a library in Liverpool was set on fire.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer warned troublemakers taking part in \"far-Right thuggery'\" that: \"You will regret it\".\n\nMeanwhile mosques were being offered protection from \"rapid response\" units after being targeted by yobs, fuelled by online lies, in the wake of last week's knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport that left three primary school pupils dead.\n\nIn Rotherham on Sunday, hundreds of masked thugs yelling 'Yorkshire, Yorkshire, Yorkshire!' stormed a Holiday Inn Express thought to be housing asylum seekers.\n\nProtesters shoved blazing wheelie bins through fire escapes before blocking exits.\n\nBrendan Cox, whose Labour MP wife Jo Cox was murdered by a far-Right fanatic in Birstall, WestYorkshire, in 2016, accused the Rotherham mob of an \"attempt to murder the men, women and children inside by burning them alive\".\n\nAt one point, after smashing windows, they broke into the hotel building, hurling chairs from inside at police before being chased out again.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Labour Mayor Oliver Coppard slammed the \"brutal thuggery directed against some of the most vulnerable people in our society\".\n\nThe injured police officers included one who was left unconscious. But no hotel staff or residents were hurt.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Assistant Chief Constable Lindsey Butterfield said: \"The mindless actions today have achieved nothing other than sheer destruction and leaving members of the public and the wider community in fear.\"\n\nAnother Holiday Inn Express accused of housing migrants was attacked by a mob in Tamworth, Staffordshire, last night.\n\nThe crowd chanted \"our streets\" before smashing windows on the hotel's bottom floor.\n\nViolence also engulfed Middlesbrough where yobs hijacked a \"peaceful\" \"pro-British\" march and attacked cars and houses before turning on TV crews.\n\nIn Bolton, around 300 masked Muslims shouting \"Allahu Akbar\" - or \"God is greatest\" - charged towards anti-immigration marchers, with rival groups throwing missiles at each another.\n\nThis came as clean-up efforts began in cities blighted by violence on Saturday, including in Liverpool where demonstrators targeting a mosque set fire to a community library, which also hosts a foodbank.\n\nOne distraught resident said: \"Nazis burned books - these have gone one step further and burned a library.\"\n\nAmong other victims of the anarchy were Filipino nurses who had rocks thrown at them on their way to provide \"emergency cover\" at a hospital in Sunderland on Friday.\n\nAs footage of the violence spread globally, Malaysia - where almost two-thirds of the population are Muslims - became the first country to update its travel advice in Britain, telling its citizens to \"stay away from protest areas\" and \"remain vigilant\".\n\nFormer Scottish First Minister Humza Yousaf labelled the Rotherham anarchy a \"pogrom against Muslims and people of colour\" and called for the Army to be sent in to protect them.\n\nIn chilling scenes in South Yorkshire - where tensions have festered over a long-running child sex grooming scandal involving men of mainly Pakistani origin - heavily outnumbered police had to retreat from masked gangs.\n\nAfter initially being forced to pull back, officers brought in reinforcements and pushed yobs away, leaving a tense stand-off.\n\nIn Middlesbrough, demonstrators went on the rampage, smashing cars and windows, telling terrified residents that the violence was \"because we're English\".\n\nIn a reference to the Cardiff-born teenage suspect in the Southport killings, they carried a banner saying \"Tom Jones is Welsh, Axel Rudakubana isn't\".\n\nCrowds chanted \"We want our country back!\" before some pelted police with bottles and pieces of slate or set wheelie bins alight.\n\nIn Dorset, police moved people off Weymouth beach as evening fell and rival marches faced off, one side shouting in support of English Defence League founder Tommy Robinson, while the other side bellowed \"Nazis go home\".\n\nThe latest scenes came after a mob who had attempted to target a mosque in the Walton area of Liverpool on Saturday evening torched a community library that only opened last year after locals helped raise \u00a3900,000.\n\nAs firefighters tried to put out the flames that engulfed Spellow Lane library hub - which also functions as a food bank - rioters threw missiles, breaking the rear window of a fire appliance.\n\nFaith leaders across Merseyside yesterday called on communities to \"remain calm and peaceful\" and ignore those seeking to \"use the Southport tragedy to create division and hate\".\n\nElsewhere on Saturday, looters took advantage of the mayhem, stealing everything from phones, shoes and even gingerbread men and cookies from shops.\n\nIn parts of Belfast, stores and cafes were set on fire and destroyed by anti-Muslim mobs on Saturday, with shopkeepers claiming police \"did nothing\".\n\n\"What kind of police are letting the people burn everything down?\" one asked.\n\nThe Police Service of Northern Ireland said it was treating reports of criminal damage as hate crimes and had so far made four arrests.\n\nBy last night, police across the UK had made more than 150 arrests in connection with the trouble since Saturday.\n\nLast week a judge took the unusual step of allowing Axel Rudakubana, 17, to be identified as the suspect in the Southport knife attack.\n\nFalse claims that he was a Muslim illegal migrant prompted police to reveal he was born in Cardiff before moving to Merseyside with his Christian parents, who are originally from Rwanda.\n\nSouth Yorkshire Assistant Chief Constable Butterfield said: \"Those who choose to spread misinformation and hate online also need to take responsibility for the scenes today - this was not a protest, just angry people reacting to a false narrative who have their own motivations for doing so.\"\n\n\"Those who stood on and watched the violence and Several protesters were spotted spraying police with fire extinguishers until they made it inside the hotel's lobby.\n\nThe crowd could be heard chanting, \"Get them out\" as people staying at the hotel watched the chaos unfold below them, The Telegraph reports.\n\nCounter-protesters from the Stand Up to Racism group were initially at the scene, but reportedly left the area when the chaos unfolded.\n\nIt remains unclear if there were any asylum seekers inside the hotel or if it had been evacuated following previous protests, according to the BBC.\n\n\"The safety and security of our guests and colleagues is always our priority,\" IHG, the company that owns Holiday Inn Express, said in a statement.\n\nA separate protest has broken out in Middlesbrough with more than 300 people marching on the streets after breaking free of a police barrier and smashing taxis in the town center.\n\nBritish police have issued orders of dispersal on Sunday in Southport, Liverpool and Bolton, where other protests have broken out.\n\nThe protests broke out last week after viral posts from far-right groups on social media claimed - without evidence - that the 17-year-old arrested for killing three little girls at a dance class was a Muslim asylum seeker.\n\nPolice have said the claims are incorrect and that the suspect was born in Britain.\n\nThe suspect, identified as Axel Rudakubana, Rudakubana has since been charged with murder and attempted murder.\n\nThe misinformation sparked far-right protests across the country. Violence last night broke out in Hull, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast - with many police forces being pushed to breaking point.\n\nMeanwhile, when rioter tore through Sunderland on Friday night the mob of protesters attacked the Masjid E Anwaar E Madinah mosque.\n\nSunderland Faith Leader Zaf Iqbal and three other people were forced to lock themselves inside the place of worship to avoid the dangerous crowd outside.\n\nSpeaking to the BBC, he broke down in tears as he recalled the 'very frightening' ordeal.\n\nZaf Iqbal (pictured), a taxi driver and co-chair of the Sunderland Interfaith Forum, says the riots in Sunderland has left members of Muslim community terrified and unwilling to leave their homes\n\nHe said: 'We had to close the mosques on Friday night and not go about our normal business, because we didn't want our elders to be put at risk.\n\n'It is very frightening because you have a mob who are attacking a building which is a place of worship. Just the same as a Church or a Sikh Gurdwara or a Hindu Temple.'\n\nRead More Britain's disturbing underbelly hijacking the Southport tragedy\n\nShocking footage from outside the mosque shows horse-mounted police attempting to keep the rioters at bay.\n\nMr Iqbal says that the events of Friday night have led to some Muslims in the area feeling too scared to leave their homes. Meanwhile members of the Sikh community also told the faith leader that they were being more vigilant.\n\nA horrifying video taken in Hull shows a a mob of rioters charging towards a grey vehicle in a car park, as they yell racial slurs at the driver.\n\nAs the video goes on, onlookers can be heard shouting for police, as a group of men surround the vehicle.\n\nA shopping trolley can be seen mounted on the front of the car, as one rioter, covered by a cap and a bandana around his face, can be seen reaching inside it.\n\nThe man recording can be heard explaining that there are 'foreigners in the car'.\n\nThe windscreen also appears to be smashed, and the wipers appear to have been pulled upwards.\n\nA police car set on fire in Sunderland. {"uri": "2024-08-443701848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:36:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:36:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:19:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/violent-mob-in-balaclavas-attack-migrant-hotel-throw-chairs-at-police-and-set-furniture-on-fire-as-asylum-seekers-watch-in-fear/", "title": "Violent Mob in Balaclavas Attack Migrant Hotel, Throw Chairs at Police, and Set Furniture on Fire as Asylum Seekers Watch in Fear - Internewscast Journal", "body": "An angry far-right mob have stormed into a hotel housing migrants and asylum seekers, hurling chairs and releasing fire extinguishers on riot police, while setting bins and furniture alight.\n\nHundreds of violent anti-immigration protesters clad in balaclavas and draped in St George's flags have clashed with officers trying to protect the Holiday Inn Express in Rotherham, South Yorkshire this afternoon. At least one cop has been injured in the chaos outside the hotel on the northern outskirts of the post-industrial town.\n\nIt marks yet another day of violent riots of Britain's streets, after chaos ensued this week leaving cops with broken bones, cars set on fire and innocent pedestrians targeted on the streets. The outburst comes after three young girls were stabbed to death in Southport by alleged knifeman Axel Muganwa Rudakubana on July 29.\n\nWhile photos from the scene have shown some occupants looking out of the hotel window onto rioters, it is still unclear if the migrants and asylum seekers housed in the property have been able to evacuate. MailOnline has contacted the Home Office.\n\nObjects and pieces of wood were flung at officers who had lined up in front of the building with at least one cop in riot gear being carried away by their colleagues.\n\nOne person's face was seen completely covered with a Union Jack mask while they waved a large England flag outside the hotel while others swung back cans of bears while chanting offensive slogans.\n\nA group of young men held a banner that read 'we're not far right we're just right' while another placard being waved around said: 'Stopping the boats means stopping the stabbings'.\n\nThe protest has already been strongly criticise by anti-racism groups as well as campaigner Brendan Cox, whose MP wife Jo Cox was killed in her West Yorkshire constituency in 2016.\n\nHe said: 'The scenes in Rotherham aren't a protest, they aren't even a far right riot, they are an ongoing attempt to murder the men, women and children inside by burning them alive.\n\n'The stench of these days will hang around those who incited and justified it for the rest of their lives.'\n\nAn anti-racism counter protest at the scene has increased tensions for police, who arrived to find banners reading: 'Refugees welcome: Stop the far right.'\n\nWatching the scenes of chaos unfold, former home secretary and Tory party leader hopeful James Cleverly said rioters should be hit with 'the full weight of the law'.\n\n'There is not and can never be any excuse, justification or rationale for behaviour like this,' he tweeted. 'This should be condemned by everybody, and those taking part should expect to be met with the full weight of the law.'\n\nIGH, the parent company of the Holiday Inn chain, told the BBC: 'The safety and security of our guests and colleagues is always our priority.'\n\nElsewhere in Middlesbrough, more than 300 protesters started marching towards the city's Cenotaph.\n\nThey carried a banner that read: 'Tom Jones is Welsh, Axel Rudakubana isn't' Rudakubana is the 17-year-old accused for murdering the three little girls in Southport and is charged with attempted murder of 10 others.\n\nHis parents were born in Rwanda before moving to the UK in 2002. Rudakubana was born in Cardiff in 2006 before moving to near Southport in 2013.\n\nOthers marching through the city chanted 'we want our country back' as they made their way through the city centre.\n\nAt least two people were taken away in handcuffs within the first half hour, while several pieces of slate were thrown, along with vapes and full plastic bottles.\n\nSome people kicked bollards into the road so that police vehicles driving ahead of the group could not get through, and one man sat on the bonnet of a police car to stop it from moving.\n\nThe fresh day of riots comes as Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer is set to go on holiday with his family, it is understood, a decision which has been slammed by MPs.\n\nTory leadership hopeful Robert Jenrick criticised Sir Keir for the getaway plan, branding it 'completely wrong' amid a period of chaos in the country.\n\nNo10 did not dispute the claims when approached by MailOnline but said the Prime Minister is working this weekend and next week.\n\nThe disruption across England and Northern Ireland began on Tuesday in Southport, after three little girls were killed in a knife attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class.\n\nSlamming Sir Keir's alleged plans to go on holiday, Mr Jenrick told GBN Live: 'I think it would be completely wrong for the Prime Minister to go on holiday whilst parts of Britain are burning.\n\n'I'm sure that the government, like the whole country, sees the severity of the situation.'\n\nThe politician added: 'I know they're trying to get a grip on it and I welcome some of the measures they've already taken, like having more persecutors, having the courts sit weekends, but this is a very serious situation.'\n\nHowever, Chris Webb, the Labour MP for Blackpool South, said Sir Keir 'has to have family time'.\n\nHe told LBC's Matthew Wright: 'The government will continue and we've got an excellent Deputy Prime Minister.\n\n'Keir has to have family time, there's no doubt about it. Every Prime Minister has to have that family time and that break but from what I know of Keir - and I've met him many times, and sitting here in Blackpool several times - he will be continuing to work and monitor the situation wherever he is on holiday.'\n\nCities such as Hull, Liverpool, Bristol, Manchester and Belfast have seen vehicles burned, shops destroyed, pedestrians attacked and police officers injured this week following the Southport stabbings on Monday.\n\nArrests have been made across the country, with police warning of more to come once CCTV, social media and body-worn camera footage has been scoured.\n\nThere was violence on Saturday in towns and cities such as Hull, Liverpool, Stoke-on-Trent, Nottingham, Bristol, Manchester, Blackpool and Belfast, which saw several police officers injured. It followed a riot in Sunderland on Friday evening.\n\nA community library on the Merseyside that only opened last year after months of fundraising was set on fire last night as more than 300 people descended on the streets of a deprived city suburb.\n\nAs firefighters tried to put on the flames that engulfed Spellow Lane Library Hub - which also functions as a food bank - rioters threw a missile at the engine, before breaking the rear window of a nearby cab.\n\nShocking photos from this morning show the burnt out interior of the library, with bookshelves tipped on their side, and glass surrounding the remaining computers.\n\nOne officer was shoved off his motorbike while another was looked after by colleagues after appearing shell-shocked following a violent confrontation with a protester.\n\nElsewhere, shameless looters took advantage of the violent mayhem, stealing everything from phones, shoes and wine from local shops.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8259854671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:05:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:05:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:04:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/29688530/rioters-drivers-white-english-middlesbrough/", "title": "Moment rioters ask drivers if they're 'white & English' before letting them pass", "body": "CHILLING footage shows rioters asking drivers if they're \"white and English\" before letting them pass.\n\nMore than 420 people have been arrested after social media lies whipped up riots across the UK.\n\nMosques and asylum hostels across the country have been attacked and shops owned by ethnic minority Brits have been looted.\n\nPhone footage from Middlesbrough shows far-right rioters stopping people to ask if they are \"white and English\".\n\nOne thug can be heard shouting \"Are you white? Are you English?\" at a driver trying to cross an intersection where rioters were marching.\n\nAnother rioter is heard replying: \"Yes, he is!\"\n\nTwo other cars nearly collided as they steered to avoid the racist mob.\n\nFar-right thugs have been warned they face a \"reckoning\" as the Prime Minister holds a Cobra meeting after a weekend of chaos.\n\nHundreds of thugs petrol-bombed a hotel housing asylum seekers in Rotherham, near Sheffield, yesterday.\n\nRioters in balaclavas hurled bricks and fire extinguishers at cops who tried in vain to stop them torching the hotel.\n\nTen riot cops were injured - including one who was knocked out after suffering a head injury.\n\nYobs also petrol-bombed a Holiday Inn hosting asylum seekers in Tamworth, Staffordshire.\n\nA children's library in Liverpool and a Citizens' Advice centre in Sunderland were also torched over the weekend.\n\nToday Sir Keir Starmer will summon ministers and police chiefs for the first Cobra meeting since the riots started.\n\nLast night the PM said the \"far-right thugs\" behind the riots would regret their actions.\n\nHome Secretary Yvette Cooper slammed the \"disgraceful\" riots - saying they betray Britain's values.\n\nWriting in The Times, Cooper said: \"Make no mistake - there will be a reckoning for the individuals who took part in this violence.\n\n\"Whatever they and some of their political supporters may tell us, these are not patriots standing up for their communities.\n\n\"They are thugs, criminals, and extremists who betray the very values our country is built on.\"\n\nShadow Home Secretary James Cleverly told Times Radio: \"Mosques are being targeted, asylum hotels are being targeted.\n\n\"We are seeing people with swastika tattoos and giving Nazi salutes - this is self-evidently driven in significant part by the far right.\n\n\"We know that there is a very active online community stirring up hatred, stirring up the kind of attitudes which trigger events like this.\n\n\"So we know where this is coming from. It is absolutely right to describe the actions of these people as the far right.\"\n\nTory leadership contender Cleverly said the government had been \"slow\" to crack down on the riots.\n\nHe said: \"When the government gets things right, I will support them, because this issue is absolutely key.\n\n\"But I'm also concerned that they have been slow. It's only today that Cobra is going to sit.\"\n\nReform UK leader Nigel Farage called for Parliament to be recalled this morning.\n\nPosting on X, Farage added: \"We should not discount the use of the army if the situation were to deteriorate further.\"\n\nViolent clashes broke out in dozens of UK towns and cities last week and continued over the weekend.\n\nThey have been fuelled by online lies following the murders of three girls in Southport on Monday.\n\nAt Middlesbrough's Cenotaph, hundreds of protesters squared up to police before throwing slate, cans and pots at the officers.\n\nA group of masked yobs walked through a residential suburb of the city.\n\nThey used metal bars and wooden posts to smash car windscreens and the windows of terraced houses.\n\nVehicles were torched, along with wheelie bins.\n\nMeanwhile, in Weymouth cops were tasked with keeping protesters and counter-protesters separate along the beach.\n\nCops confirmed two officers were injured, one hit in the face with a bottle while the other was punched.\n\nAnother migrant hotel in the Hampshire town of Aldershot was also targeted.\n\nA group of men outside Potters International Hotel brandished a banner insisting: \"We're not far right, we're just right.\"\n\nBy 6.45pm a crowd of some 200 \"got involved in criminal activity, throwing objects and subjecting people to racist abuse,\" according to Hampshire Police.\n\nIn the centre of Bolton, large crowds of anti-immigration demonstrators gathered along with \u00adcounter-protesters while police tried to keep them apart.\n\nTrouble also flared {"uri": "8259925930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:49:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:49:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:48:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.somersetcountygazette.co.uk/news/national/uk-today/24497573.riots-happening-across-uk-moment/", "title": "Why are there riots in the UK? Reasons for violent disorder explained", "body": "A number of riots have taken place across the UK in the past week, fueled by anti-immigration sentiment from the far-right.\n\nPlenty of vandalism and violence has occurred, with cars and buildings burnt, projectiles thrown at mosques, police attacked and hotels believed to be housing asylum seekers broken into.\n\nPrime Minister Sir Keir Starmer gave a televised address on Sunday (August 4) and warned those involved that they would \"regret\" taking part.\n\nHe said: \"People in this country have a right to be safe, and yet we've seen Muslim communities targeted, attacks on mosques.\n\n\"Other minority communities singled out, Nazi salutes in the street, attacks on the police, wanton violence alongside racist rhetoric, so no, I won't shy away from calling it what it is: far-right thuggery.\"\n\nBut why have the riots taken place and why has it escalated as the week has gone on?\n\nThe riots happened in the wake of the killing of three young girls at a dance studio in Southport on Monday (July 29).\n\nAlice Dasilva Aguiar, nine, Bebe King, six, and Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, were killed and eight others were injured, some severely.\n\nRumours emerged on social media claiming that the attacker was a man called Ali Al-Shakati who was a Muslim asylum seeker.\n\nHowever, this wasn't true, with the individual being identified as 17-year-old Axel Rudakubana in court.\n\nJudge Andrew Menary made the exceptional decision to lift reporting restrictions despite his age in an attempt to stop misinformation.\n\nRudakubana was born in Cardiff to parents of Rwanda heritage, before moving to the village of Banks just outside of Southport.\n\nA vigil in Southport was held on Tuesday (July 30) but on the same evening, hundreds of protestors gathered outside a mosque in the town.\n\nThere were chants expressing Islamophobic and anti-immigration sentiment alongside support for Tommy Robinson, the founder of the EDL (English Defence League).\n\nObjects were also thrown at the mosque and at riot police who came in to deal with the disorder, with a police van being set alight.\n\nRecommended reading:\n\nAfter that, similar riots followed across the UK for the rest of the week in places such as Rotherham, Hull, Middlesbrough, Bristol, Tamworth and Liverpool.\n\nMuch of the reasoning for {"uri": "8259471713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:26:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:26:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:25:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.tortoisemedia.com/2024/08/05/anti-immigration-riots-erupt-across-uk/", "title": "Anti-immigration riots erupt across UK - Tortoise", "body": "Keir Starmer said yesterday that those involved in \"far-right thuggery\" in dozens of cities over the weekend would soon regret their involvement.\n\nSo what? Previous warnings didn't work. The British prime minister announced a nationwide violence disorder unit last week, after protests broke out following the murder of three little girls at a dance class in Southport. He hoped the threat of sharing intelligence and advanced technologies between police forces would deter further rioting. Instead:\n\nThe X factor. The riots have been organised and livestreamed on social media platforms, which helped foment the initial unrest by allowing disinformation about the Southport murders to spread largely unchecked, amplified by the likes of Tommy Robinson and Andrew Tate.\n\nElon Musk, who runs X, where the false claim that the Southport suspect was a Muslim asylum-seeker was rapidly disseminated last week, has been silent on his site's role in the riots. Instead the billionaire replied to a post suggesting the disorder was caused by mass migration and open borders by writing that \"civil war is inevitable\". It's worth emphasising that the suspect was born in Britain to Rwandan parents.\n\nIn Rotherham, a far-right mob, some draped in England and Union Jack flags, started a fire outside a Holiday Inn housing asylum-seekers; a crowd smashed a glass door to gain access to the hotel, chanting \"get them out\". One police officer was knocked unconscious. Violence also erupted in:\n\nStarmer has vowed to \"do whatever it takes to bring these thugs to justice\", saying those who took part \"whether directly or those whipping up this action online and then running away themselves\" would face justice. The prime minister has repeatedly used the term thugs.\n\nBut one month into the job, Starmer is facing:\n\nBack to the future. Starmer has experience dealing with public unrest. Back in 2011, he was director of public prosecutions when riots broke out after Mark Duggan, a black British man, was shot dead by police officers. It led to civil unrest across the country and more than 3,000 arrests. Starmer kept courts going around the clock, with heavy sentences handed out, in a bid to restore order.\n\nBut... even if the government utilises so-called \"Nightingale Courts\" to fast-track sentencing, there is no guarantee that British prisons will have the space to take them. And unlike in 2011, police and eyewitnesses suggest the rioters are not local to the communities that have been targeted.\n\nWhat's more. As in 2011, this year's wave of unrest is taking place during a heatwave. Rain is forecast and may bring some respite. Tackling the underlying anger of protesters will take longer.\n\nThanks for reading. This article is part of our Daily Sensemaker, a free newsletter from Tortoise.
